INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the House that Mr Alexander Dubcek, the Chairman of the Federal Assembly of the Czech and Slovak Federal Republic, is within the precincts. With the concurrence of honourable members, I propose to provide him with a seat on the floor of the House.

INTERJECT.PARA: Honourable members-Hear, hear!

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Would the Serjeant-at-Arms please admit President Dubcek.

INTERJECT.PARA: President Dubcek thereupon entered the chamber, and was seated accordingly.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, as Speaker of this House it is a privilege for me to welcome to the floor of the chamber a man whose name is synonymous with the struggle for democracy in central and eastern Europe. This is the first time since this House was opened that we have had an honoured guest seated on the floor of the chamber. I am sure that all members would agree with me that there would not be a more suitable person to grace this House than you, Mr Chairman.

INTERJECT.PARA: Honourable members- Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of my colleagues, I bid you welcome.

—Mr Speaker, may I very briefly congratulate you on the initiative that you have taken in inviting President Dubcek to take his place on the floor of the House. I and the Leader of the Opposition had the opportunity on an earlier occasion to express the depth of our feelings towards Mr Dubcek. I agree with you that there could be no more appropriate first occasion for the honour that you have extended. I would, in the precincts of the Parliament, extend to Mr Dubcek the deep feelings of gratitude that both I and the Leader of the Opposition expressed at some length to him on an earlier occasion in Melbourne. It is a great honour, Sir, to have you with us.

—With your indulgence, Mr Speaker, I would like to join with the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in congratulating you on the initiative that you have shown in inviting Mr Dubcek to sit on the floor of the Parliament today. I similarly welcome Mr Dubcek to the Parliament. I hope that he enjoys the proceedings. We will make them as entertaining as we can. On a recent occasion I shared with the Prime Minister the opportunity to express our views on the enormous contribution that Mr Dubcek has already made in his career. On behalf of the coalition parties, I welcome you, Sir.

—I inform the House that the Minister for Trade and Overseas Development, Dr Blewett, left Australia on 23 April on Government business overseas. He will return to Australia on 11 May. The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Senator Evans, is the Acting Minister, with Mr Duffy taking questions in this House. The Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, Mr Hand, is also overseas on Government business. He departed on 3 May and will return on 11 May. In his absence, the Minister for Local Government, Ms Fatin, is the Acting Minister.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hewson Dr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister, who stated on 12 April 1991, in defence of his decision not to stand down Mr Brian Burke:

QUESTION.PARA: I have no reason to believe on my knowledge of Brian Burke that he would engage in anything illegal or that involved impropriety.

Now that Mr Burke's own testimony has confirmed that he was involved in improper actions, will the Prime Minister insist that he stand down as our ambassador immediately, so as to avoid further damage to Australia's international reputation? And when will the Prime Minister begin to show the leadership that our country desperately needs?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have expressed the view in this House on a number of occasions that, in regard to the allegations that have been made against Mr Burke, we were not prepared on the basis of those allegations to take the action that in the first place the Leader of the Opposition wanted us to take on the basis of mere innuendo.
—We are talking about admissions now.

—I am coming to that. On the basis of the evidence that has been given up to this stage by Mr Burke to the Western Australian Royal Commission into Commercial Activities of Government and Other Matters, let me say this: I and the Government believe that many of the actions that have been taken by Mr Burke have been unwise in the extreme.

—Mr Speaker, I have not finished. But on the basis of the advice that has been given to Senator Evans-who has the primary carriage of this matter and with whom I have had significant discussions-by his Department, while there was action taken by Mr Burke that, had it been known at the time, would have required reprimand by the Department and a cease and desist order from the Department to him, the advice is that, on the evidence that it has to this stage, including what Mr Burke has said, there would have been no grounds for his dismissal.

ANSWER.PARA: May I say that Senator Evans has indicated in writing to this effect and on those bases, while I repeat that many of the things that, as now revealed, Mr Burke has done I think have been unwise in the extreme and improper on some accounts, I also repeat that no advice has been received from the Department that that would require dismissal. Indeed, the advice is that none of that action would in fact constitute grounds for dismissal.
Let me say, Mr Speaker, that in regard to much of this I think the position has been well put by the Opposition's Senator Hill. He said:
These are the issues that will be examined-

and he was referring to the full facts of the handling of the leader's account. I believe that those matters should be left to the Royal Commission to establish. I believe it is not for this Government or this House to make judgments on those matters. Indeed, Senator Hill said on 29 April:
But these are the issues that will be examined no doubt in depth and when there's a finding we would respond to them further.

As I say, Senator Evans is of the view-and I agree-for instance, that the operating and controlling of party political funds for the purpose of directly supporting political campaigns would be imprudent and inappropriate for a serving ambassador, and the Department has advised Senator Evans that if such conduct had been established, the Department would have considered appropriate a reprimand and an instruction to cease his involvement in such activity. Without making any judgment about the facts of the matter, Senator Evans has written to Mr Burke directing him not to engage in such activity while he remains an ambassador.

TALK.START.PARA: —Presumably the Opposition is implying that it is not appropriate for Senator Evans to write in those terms. I am advised that such activity is not contrary to the Bowen Committee's code of conduct or the guidelines on official conduct of official public servants, but the view of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade and of the Government is that more stringent standards should apply to ambassadors because of their special status. Senator Evans has asked his Department to consider the desirability and practicality of establishing a specific code of conduct to guide ambassadors.
—Could I ask the Prime Minister to table that written advice and the correspondence to which he referred?
—Is the Prime Minister quoting from a document?
—I am not quoting from that. If the Leader of the Opposition is asking--

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr Reith

TALK.START.PARA: —You just read it.

INTERJECT.PARA: Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Prime Minister has said he was not quoting it.

—Mr Speaker, I understand that the Leader of the Opposition's question is going beyond that from the notes I was referring to. If he is asking whether we will make the advice available, I will seek advice on that and let him know.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Has the Minister seen reports that the farm adjustment measures he announced recently provided very little new money for the rural adjustment scheme? How much new money has in fact been provided, and what is the importance of this for farm businesses?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 17 April I announced a package of rural assistance measures to take effect from 1 July this year. The centrepiece of that package is an additional $96m for the rural adjustment scheme in 1991-92, and a foreshadowed further increase of an extra $80m for 1992-93. It was a disappointment to me to find that the response to these increases, particularly from the farm organisations in Western Australia and New South Wales, was that the package was a con. These unhelpful political responses fail to take account of a number of facts.

ANSWER.PARA: First of all, the increases in RAS funds-rural adjustment scheme funds-are the largest single increases ever made, reflecting the serious view that this Government takes of the current income difficulties for the wool, wheat and some smaller sectors. The amount of new money we have allocated is based on the most careful and thorough predictions about the future of farm incomes that we have ever produced, and on a detailed appraisal of the rural adjustment scheme using information from farm surveys, the rural adjustment scheme authorities themselves, the banks and rural councillors. Every one new dollar we allocate to debt reconstruction under part A of the scheme is effectively a commitment of $7 over seven years, because that is the way part A is structured.

The main complaint from the New South Wales Farmers Association seems to be based on two things: first of all, an out and out error. Some of its people are quoted as saying that there is only $2.5m extra for household support and rehabilitation for next year when in fact cabinet had agreed to $52.5m extra. Secondly, they have complained that there is not enough extra debt reconstruction money, and that the RAS authority will run out of funds in the next few months. This is again wrong, but on several accounts.

The New South Wales authority has additional money for part A to be paid to it for the months of May and June this year. It, like some of the other authorities, has financial reserves. From 1 July it will begin to receive its share of the new part A funds allocated. If New South Wales wants additional money for debt reconstruction, it can get it in the new financial year by the State Government matching the DRIS program-that is the debt reconstruction and interim subsidy scheme-that we have put in place.

I have already indicated the Government's intention to review the RAS allocations, the States' responses and the demand on the scheme in December of this year. The money available for debt reconstruction after 1 July under part A and the special new DRIS will be sufficient to subsidise between $1.1m and $1.7 billion worth of borrowing, depending obviously on the amount of subsidy applied, but that is up to a seventh of institutional farm debt.

These discussions on RAS were announced in conjunction with the decision to pay $35m in compensation to wheat growers, to provide enough money to double the number of rural councillors, and to establish a new rural access program. As I said, this package was carefully prepared and targeted, and costs over $100m extra in the next financial year. So those who describe it as a con should ask themselves whether their attitude is helpful to their constituents, particularly in the light of the review of RAS due next December, and whether other people, like machinery dealers and shopkeepers, would not object to being subject to such a con. It is the farmers in some States who pay their dues to farm organisations who are being conned. From some of their leaders they get no analysis and no constructive proposals-just cantankerous self-promotion.

I end on a positive note: we have provided a very significant boost to the capacity of the State rural adjustment scheme authorities because we believe the rural adjustment scheme is the best way to assist those with long term prospects who are in financial difficulty and to assist others to make the necessary structural change and leave the industry. It is now up to the State governments to maximise the available RAS funds by matching our money for part B; we pay the whole of the allocations to parts A and C. It is also up to the banks to do all they can to help with carry-on funds, especially for wheat growers.

Recently I met with the Executive Director of the Australian Bankers Association. I have been assured of the banks' understanding and cooperation. I only hope that this high level cooperation will be translated into flexibility and cooperation in the banks' regions and branches, where it will really count for farmers. A positive attitude by the State farm organisations would really be a most helpful thing in all of this.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Prime Minister. It relates to the still serving Ambassador to Ireland and the Holy See, Mr Brian Burke, who received donations of $400,000 to his leader's account from Mr Lang Hancock. Why did the Government approve a visit by Mr Burke to Romania, in company with an employee of Mr Hancock, in April 1989? Was the Prime Minister personally involved in the decision to give Mr Burke a special role in promoting trade in eastern Europe? Did Mr Burke meet with the late Nicolae Ceausescu on that visit? Was Mr Burke discussing interests associated with Mr Lang Hancock when he was in Romania in April of 1989?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Soon after Mr Burke took up his post in Dublin, he raised with the Department the possibility that he might continue his involvement in matters relating to Australia's trade with eastern Europe. The Department recommended to Senator Evans that, in view of Mr Burke's established links with eastern Europe and with Australian companies which did business there and the consequent potential benefit to Australia from his activities, continued involvement in this area by Mr Burke as an Australian official would be acceptable subject to certain conditions, such as keeping other areas of the Department informed about his activities to ensure that they were properly coordinated.

ANSWER.PARA: I understand that Mr Burke made only one visit to Eastern Europe under this arrangement. I understand that that visit was to Romania in April 1989. It was made at the request of Lang Hancock. I understand that Mr Burke was accompanied by an employee of Mr Lang Hancock and by Australia's Ambassador and Trade Commissioner in Belgrade, who are responsible for Romania.

In 1990 it was decided, in the light of events in eastern Europe, that the arrangement was no longer of much potential benefit to Australia, and it was brought to an end. There was nothing secret in this arrangement. I understand that it was raised by the office of the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock) with Senator Evans's office in January 1990. As to whether on that visit Mr Burke met the President of Romania, I do not know. As to my own involvement, I have some recollection that I knew that he may be going there, but the actual arrangements and clearing of it and the conditions under which he did it were, as I have indicated in the answer to this question, a matter for the Department.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Prime Minister to table the departmental advice to which he has just referred.
—Did the Prime Minister quote from a document?
—I give the same answer I gave before. I will seek advice as to whether it is appropriate to do that.
—Order! If the Prime Minister is saying that it is a confidential document which he will clear at a later date, he may do that.

—Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. The Prime Minister did not say that it was a confidential document. I submit to you, Mr Speaker, that it was you who said that. The only condition by which the Prime Minister or any other Minister can refuse to table a document is if it is confidential. I suggest that it is for you to ask the Prime Minister whether that is so, not for you to presume that it might be.
—Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. Standing order 321 states--
—We have all read our Standing Orders this weekend.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr Tim Fischer

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in support of the point of order of the right honourable member for New England. In conjunction with that, standing order 321 states:

INTERJECT.PARA: A document relating to public affairs quoted from by a Minister or an Assistant Minister, unless stated to be of a confidential nature or such as should more properly be obtained by address, shall, if required by any Member, be laid on the Table.
That is relevant to this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —If the right honourable member for New England and his successor as the Leader of the National Party recall the practice of the House, they will understand that if the Minister says or implies that it is a confidential document, he is not required to table it. The Prime Minister said that he would get the matter cleared. If it suits honourable members on my left that I formally ask him whether it is a confidential document that he will get cleared, I am quite happy to do that. Is it a confidential document, Prime Minister?

—Let it be quite clear. I was making my response from my notes here. What I said to the Leader of the Opposition on this occasion, as I said in answer to the earlier question, was that I would make inquiries as to whether the documents to which I referred-not from which I was quoting; I was not quoting from any secret documents or confidential documents-were available. I think the Leader of the Opposition understands this. As I said before-and as I say in respect to this question-I will ascertain whether the advice to which I have referred in my answers is available. If so, I will make it available to honourable members opposite.
—Honourable members on my left should be aware that members are not required to table notes.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the House. Since the House last met there has been a series of reports concerning political donations and full disclosure. In light of these later reports, can the Minister inform the House whether the Government intends to proceed with disclosure legislation in accordance with its previous plan?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. It is a most timely one given the cant and hypocrisy that has come from the Opposition in the first two questions that those opposite have managed to ask here so far this afternoon-and what hypocrisy there has been from them too. What approach have those opposite made to Robin Gray as Leader of the Liberal Party in Tasmania to stand down since he has been a matter of interest at the royal commission in Tasmania? On the standards that those opposite set, what approach have they made to Robin Gray for him to step down as Leader of the Liberal Party? We do not think he should, but those opposite do.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Dr Hewson

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. On the same argument that the Leader of the House is now putting, the Prime Minister should stand down.

INTERJECT.PARA: Opposition members-Hear, hear! Burke's mate!

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Leader of the Opposition will not make facetious points of order.

—My friend, we are not putting those arguments. The Leader of the Opposition is putting those arguments-not us-and he has to answer the questions on it. A deal has been said about political donations.
—Order! Members on my left will cease interjecting.
—What about them?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Mayo will cease interjecting. Order! I warn the honourable member for Mayo.

INTERJECT.PARA: Dr Charlesworth interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Perth!

—There has indeed been a great deal of material on the subject of public donations, as the honourable member mentioned in the preamble to his question. We had of course the questioning of Premier Nick Greiner of New South Wales by Laurie Oakes. He said:

ANSWER.PARA: Bob Carr conceded that the W.A. Inc allegations are lead in Labor's saddlebag but before the last State election you ran-
a similar covert fund raising operation, didn't you?
The answer from Nick Greiner to a comment about a similar covert fundraising operation was `Absolutely'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Mackellar!

—I am going to. And it was all made public-every donation was publicly disclosed subsequently. We have done research. We find no disclosure of the $180,000 minimum that went into the community polling organisation-none whatsoever. We have found no adequate disclosure in relation to those five independent candidates supported by the community polling organisation-none whatsoever. There has been no disclosure of the donations to the community polling organisation-that organisation opposite the office suite of Mr Greiner and which was operated effectively with directors of that company being members of his staff. Indeed, when the Liberal Party tried to bring them to book, the Liberal Party Secretary of the day was sacked. Nick Greiner has said that, absolutely, he ran exactly the same sort of political covert operation. But he is not the only one.

ANSWER.PARA: I have here a very interesting letter from a representative of those hypocrites opposite when considering these matters. The letter is entitled `Liberal Fighting Fund Election '89' and is dated 5 January 1988. It begins, `Dear friend of Western Australia' and contains the usual Liberal Party guff. Honourable members may recollect the hypocrisy of the last couple of weeks about how leaders and politicians, unless they are Fred Chaney, never get involved in raising money. Fred Chaney is different; otherwise leaders and politicians do not get involved.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. I wonder whether the Minister would mind observing the forms of the Parliament and refer to the honourable member for Pearce in the appropriate terms.
—The Minister might refer to the honourable member for Pearce by his title.
—Nobody is permitted to get involved except the honourable member for Pearce. The letter, which is addressed to business, concludes:

ANSWER.PARA: In the interim, the Liberal Party must communicate its policies effectively-and that takes money.
Your contribution can help me in the fight for government.
As I indicated at the outset, there are only a few days left for the Liberal Party to set the seal on victory.
If you want to help change the government and get Western Australia back on track, this is your opportunity.
I urge you to take it-and thank you in anticipation.
There is a postscript in Barry MacKinnon's handwriting:
PS. By completing the enclosed form you will be acknowledging that your contribution is for the State election campaign. Accordingly, it will not need to be disclosed to anyone.

What a load of cant and hypocrisy it is for those opposite to come into this chamber and criticise those on this side of the House over the raising of funds. They have been in it up to their eyeballs for years and years: letters to business-letters advising business on how it can avoid disclosure. They have been up to their eyeballs in that year in, year out.

There are a couple of facts that can be established from this, and they are: firstly, both political parties have over the course of the last decade raised funds from the business community and, secondly, most of those funds have been from the same businessmen. One wonders why in Western Australia one ever bothered to get involved in all those endless and interminable fundraising lunches. We were getting most of our funds from the supporters of the Liberal Party. Of course, the Liberal Party donors were contributing to those opposite on exactly the same basis as they were contributing to us.

There has been a load of cant and hypocrisy, but there are a couple of things which stand like rocks in the current debate. There is one party in this country which, at the State and Federal level of political organisation, supports disclosure. It is the Australian Labor Party and not the Liberal Party. There is one party and one party only which at the State as well as at the Federal parliamentary level supports the position on disclosure. It is the Labor Party and not the Liberal Party. Those opposite are the ones who are going to have to establish their runs on the board--

TALK.START.PARA: —You know all about it!
—Order! The honourable member for Higgins will cease interjecting.

—There is no point in their coming into this place and portraying themselves on these matters as though they are crystal clear and perfectly pure about the way in which they have conducted themselves. Their leaders have raised funds and have advised people on how to avoid disclosure.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr Tuckey

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order. Mr Speaker, I draw your attention to both standing order 145 and standing order 146. Of course, standing order 145 is the one on relevance. Standing order 146 states that a question fully answered cannot be renewed. The Minister has been asked on, I think, three occasions to specifically tell this Parliament when we are going to see his legislation. He talks about everything else which is not relevant. We want the legislation and we want it quickly.

INTERJECT.PARA: Honourable members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for O'Connor will resume his seat and cease interjecting. There is no point of order.

—As I said before, the leaders of those opposite collect political funds and it does not matter what they say in their rules. Their leaders advise people on how to avoid disclosure, and it does not matter what they say in their rules.
—And what about your Leader?
—Order! I warn the honourable member for O'Connor.
—As Nick Greiner did on Sunday, their leaders admit to operating covert political funds on exactly the same basis as was done in Western Australia.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. The Minister has publicly admitted that he spoke to Brian Burke about his current problems. I ask: why did the Minister tip off Brian Burke that unless he resigned he would be sacked later that day? Why did he negotiate the deal with his good mate Brian Burke where he received an unprecedented ex gratia retirement payment of $28,000? Was it because the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade did not want to be seen publicly to be associated with such a shonky deal for a Labor mate?

—That is more cant and hypocrisy from the other side of the House. The fact of the matter is that Brian Burke raised with me an intention on his part to stand down. I communicated that fact to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, and he received advice from his Department on what ought to be the terms and conditions of Mr Burke's standing down. The question of that payment that the honourable member referred to was not raised by Mr Burke; it was not raised by me; it was not raised by Senator Evans. It was put before him by his Department, as Senator Evans made clear in the Senate Estimates committee hearing last week.
—My question is directed to the Treasurer. Will he advise the House whether recent trends in Australia's trade account are strengthening Australia's balance of payments?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The March balance of payment figures released yesterday showed the strongest trading result for Australia in three years. It is the best signal yet that the Government's policies are working to rebalance our external accounts. The current account deficit is now running at about 24 per cent less than for the same period a year ago. It is well within the Budget forecasts. As well, the surplus on goods and services trade means that we are paying with our exports for all our imports of goods, all of the costs of bringing them here and all of the travel abroad. In other words, we are paying our way in terms of goods and services. This trend and this change are not a flash in the pan. We have to go back to the 1970s to find a consistent run of surpluses of this variety. Indeed, our merchandise trade balance has been in the black for 10 of the last 12 months.

—Apparently, there is some guffawing on the Opposition front bench, so I repeat: our merchandise trade balance has been in the black for 10 of the last 12 months. Another encouraging trend in our balance of payments has been the phenomenal growth of manufactured exports under this Government. Since the Government came to office, manufactured exports have increased by 300 per cent. Indeed, in the three months to March this year, manufactured exports were nearly 20 per cent up on exports for the same period in the year before. For those people who think that Australia has a terminal disease in regard to its exports, who think that the world no longer wants what we produce, let me remind them that merchandise exports have more than doubled since we came to office.

ANSWER.PARA: Our export volumes, goods and services together, have been growing at an annual average rate of 8.3 per cent over the life of this Government. I repeat: 8.3 per cent consistent growth in goods and services over the life of the Government. As any of the Statistician's releases show, export volumes have increased right through the 1980s, and have increased strongly. Therefore, what we are seeing is a structural change in the way in which this nation does business with the rest of the world. We are seeing a structural change in the trade accounts of this country. We are seeing a consistent shift to exports. That shift was only dented by the drawing power of domestic demand at the height of the boom through 1987, 1988 and into 1989. As domestic demand has come back, those goods have been released to the export markets again. The strength of exports in the 1980s has nothing to do whatsoever with the recession. It was a structural change brought about solely by this Government-solely by the moves to competitiveness, by a floating exchange rate, by changes in wage policies, shifts in the factor shares, changes in the tax system, enhanced productivity and, generally, a willingness on the part of Australians to engage the rest of the world in trade. That is why the structural change is there.

There is no doubt that our friends opposite saw the portents in yesterday's figures. They saw the first surplus in goods trade since 1988-which itself was a spike-and realised that this trend which we have seen is consistent with merchandise trade surpluses. One has to go back to the 1970s to find a similar trend. They could see what this means as we continue to strengthen the external side of the economy and what it means politically for them. It was therefore of no surprise that the numbers were bagged by the shadow Treasurer, as they always are. Any good news is put asunder in his manic determination to put Australia down for his own miserable political ends. We saw those references from him.

The fact is that what we saw in the March balance of payments was a structural improvement in Australia's trade accounts-structural not cyclical. For the year to March exports were up 13.5 per cent and imports were down 13.5 per cent. There could be no more stark statistic than the fact that exports were up 13.5 and imports were down 13.5 and that there has been a trend improvement in exports right through the 1980s. It is that which will deliver growth to the Australian economy. It is that which will underpin living standards through the 1990s. It is that shift to the external sectors which is coming from the success of the Government's policy in rebalancing our external accounts.

I repeat: yesterday's figures were very important in painting that picture. They were not a flash in the pan, and are a portent of a stronger, healthier internationalised economy as we go through the 1990s.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Does the Prime Minister agree with the Treasurer that the primary national income determining institution is the accord and not the Industrial Relations Commission?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —In profound agreement with my friend and colleague the Treasurer, I make this point: if we look at the period since 1983, by any objective assessment the accord has been fundamental not only to the economic but also to the social achievements that have occurred in this country since 1983.
—What are they?

—I am indebted to the honourable member from the Opposition for asking me what they are. I will tell him what they are. In 1983 we inherited a country, after seven years of coalition stewardship, which had produced the historically unique situation of having double digit unemployment and double digit inflation at the same time. That is what we inherited.

ANSWER.PARA: Under the accord, with the great cooperation of the Australian trade union movement, even with the loss of jobs that has occurred over the most recent period we have still created 1.4 million new jobs in this country. I remind the Leader of the Opposition, as I have on many occasions, that that is a rate of job creation twice as fast as the coalition managed to achieve during its period of office.

We had a situation where the profit share of national income was absolutely ruined. We have moved significantly from the wages share to profit share which has enabled investment over the past two years to reach record levels. We have had a shift from wages to profits, and we have had that because of the operation of the accord. As well as that, we have had a more than 10 per cent reduction in real non-farm unit labour costs under the accord.

It is recognised by leaders of industry that the trade unions, if they had wanted to exercise their industrial muscle, could have achieved significantly higher money wage increases than they did. In all of those circumstances, where we have also had a 60 per cent reduction in the level of industrial disputes in this country, it is impossible for anyone, whether the Treasurer or the Prime Minister, to come to any conclusion but that the accord has been fundamental to those economic achievements.

But it is not only those economic achievements because, as part of the preparedness of the trade union movement to accept lower money wage increases than it could otherwise have achieved in the field, it has accepted in return significant improvements in the social wage. It is not simply something that has been done between the trade union movement and the Government; all people in the Australian community are better off, because Medicare has been brought in, there has been a doubling of the access of young people to education and a massive increase in child-care provisions in this country. All those increases in the social wage have been brought to bear under the accord.

Of course, I agree with Paul Keating that the operation of the accord has been fundamental not merely in the operation of the wage fixing system but in the achievement of greater social justice in this country. Having said that, it is the position of the Government, including the Treasurer and myself, that in this country, given our history and social mores, there will continue to be a significant role for the Industrial Relations Commission.

As distinct from those opposite, who would abandon to the forces of the market those in the work force with the least bargaining power so that they would not have any sort of protection at all, we believe that it is the role of the Industrial Relations Commission to provide a basic standard below which no-one in this country shall be employed. We believe that the Commission will continue to have that role and continue to have a dispute settlement role. Of course, there is also a role for the Industrial Relations Commission in negotiations such as those that have taken place recently in the area of the waterfront, negotiations in which I have been involved, together with Senator Collins and Senator Cook.

I do not make any apology for the length of the answer, because it is an important question and the answer is also important. It is not a question of either the accord or the Industrial Relations Commission. True it is that, given the most recent decision of the Industrial Relations Commission, there is a period in which we are going to have to work out together how those respective roles are going to operate, but there will be a continuing important role for both the accord and the Commission.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Prime Minister advise the House of progress made by the Antarctic Treaty parties in Madrid in negotiating an agreement to protect the Antarctic environment? Did it fall short of achieving permanent protection of Antarctica?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset I want to say that the draft agreement was, in our judgment, a magnificent breakthrough. It was a fitting culmination to the campaign that was begun by Australia, in cooperation from the outset with the Government of France. When we first rejected the Antarctic minerals convention and, as the honourable member will recall, began arguing for a comprehensive environmental protection regime for the Antarctic, we were almost laughed out of court in many sectors in this country and certainly in most countries around the world. This was seen as the impossible dream. Our unstinting pursuit of this goal and the intrinsic merits of the arguments that were used in support of it gradually won the day in the international community and we gradually convinced other nations that they should support our efforts to preserve this superb and fragile area of the globe.

ANSWER.PARA: The draft agreement includes extremely tight provisions prohibiting mining and mineral resource exploration. It means that, even if a review conference is called after the initial 50-year period, any amendment to the prohibition would need the agreement of all current consultative parties such as Australia. I should also mention one very important aspect of this issue which has tended to be overlooked: not only did we get a prohibition and an effective veto by all the consultative parties, but we also made great progress in establishing a comprehensive environmental protection regime and the designation of the Antarctic as a natural reserve devoted to peace and science. There will be measures to ensure compliance with the environmental agreement.

As I think the honourable member will appreciate, Australia's negotiating team had a very tough job, not only in Madrid but also in the preceding international conferences that led up to Madrid. It had a very tough negotiating job against the entrenched position of some of the mightiest nations on earth-the United States and the United Kingdom.

Against that formidable opposition our negotiating team did a magnificent job with absolute meticulousness. It did its job quite brilliantly. I think not only on behalf of the Government but also on behalf of the people of Australia, members of the negotiating team should be congratulated for the job they did. I also want quite directly to thank and congratulate France for the continuing support we received from the French. I know that the draft has to be approved by governments, but we are extremely confident we will succeed in making sure that the Antarctic remains protected.

In conclusion-I know the honourable gentleman who asked the question has a profound interest in this issue-I hope that all treaty nations will now move quickly to give this draft agreement their full support.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Given that the Prime Minister was unwilling in his last answer to support the assertion of the Treasurer that the accord and not the Industrial Relations Commission was the primary national income determining institution in Australia, does he agree with another assertion of the Treasurer, which is that the Industrial Relations Commission is still dredging around trying to find a place for itself in the new economic society of Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Had the honourable member for Bennelong listened to the previous answer, he would have heard that the Treasurer and I were at one in terms of our assessment of the importance of the accord and its fundamental nature. Until the most recent decision, the accord was worked out between the trade union movement and the Government. May I say that that process was done with consultations with employer organisations. We worked out a framework which, I remind the honourable member for Bennelong, he would have loved to have done when he was Treasurer. Does he remember the sorts of wage outcomes he got? His last one was 18 per cent. He could not come within a bull's roar of getting any sort of sensible national wages aggregate outcome. Against the honourable member for Bennelong's 18 per cent wages blow-out, which came from his prescriptions as to how to handle industrial relations in this country, in each year since 1983, we have negotiated--
—On a point of order, Mr Speaker: the Prime Minister is deliberately and systematically avoiding my question, as he did that of the Leader of the Opposition.
—Order! There is no point of order.
—I can understand that the honourable member for Bennelong does not like the points I am making but they are entirely relevant to the question.

ANSWER.PARA: As distinct from the total incapacity of the honourable member for Bennelong under his philosophy, his policies and his principles of getting any acceptable aggregate national wage outcome, where he had his last effort of an 18 per cent blow-out in wages, under the accord-and fundamentally under the accord-the Government has sat down with the trade unions, had discussions with the employers as well, and said, `For the forthcoming financial year, the national aggregate wages outcome will be X per cent'. In every year that predicted aggregate national wage outcome has either been achieved or we have come in under it.

It is no wonder that the honourable member for Bennelong is very embarrassed and touchy about this issue. Would anyone not be embarrassed if his last effort in office-under his principles, his policies and his prescriptions-had produced an 18 per cent wages blow-out, where he saw the Government coming into office and saying, `This is the wages outcome we will get', and every year achieving it? No wonder the honourable member for Bennelong is very touchy about the subject, and well he might be. The great wonder of this is that, having seen the capacity of the accord process to achieve these given national wage outcomes, having remembered the blow-out he had, which absolutely ruined the Australian economy, and having seen the contrast, he now wants to condemn Australia to a return to what he did before. That is the massive surprise about the position of the honourable member for Bennelong. There is no difference between the Prime Minister--

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me finish. There is no difference between the Prime Minister and the Treasurer-no difference at all. It is the case that, given the decision that has just been made by the Industrial Relations Commission, there will have to be a period in which both the Government and the Industrial Relations Commission in a number of ways sort out what their roles will be.

ANSWER.PARA: We have had the good fortune up until this year that where the work has been done between the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) and the Government, in consultation with many employer groups, we have gone to the Commission and said, `Here are the results that we believe we can deliver for the benefit of the Australian people if the accord is implemented'. On every occasion up until this year the Commission has seen the good sense of saying yes. In particular, year after year it has seen the results delivered, not only in terms of national aggregate wage outcomes but in regard to the gradual movement to significant workplace reform. As the Commission has seen those results being delivered, it has made the very sensible decision to say, `Yes, we are going to be associated, through the Commission, with the implementation of that accord'.

On this occasion, for a variety of reasons, the Commission has chosen not to make that decision. It is inevitable that, in those circumstances, as the Treasurer said, the Commission is going to be looking at what its role is, and so will we. I am confident, given the good sense within the Government, within the trade union movement, within the employer organisations and, hopefully, within the Commission, that we will be able once again to reach a position where, together, the Commission, the Government, the unions and the employers are going to do what they could never do under the regime of the honourable member for Bennelong-that is, get a 60 per cent reduction in industrial disputes; get a 10 per cent reduction in real unit labour costs; and say, `This is what the given national aggregate wage outcome will be'.

Those are admirable achievements and they can only be done under the system which we are pursuing and not the alternatives of the honourable member for Bennelong which once before ruined the country and which would do so again if ever the Opposition had the chance of implementing them.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Why has the Government honoured the President of Turkey with the award of Companion of the Order of Australia when Turkey continues to flout United Nations resolutions on Cyprus and in view of Turkey's continuing poor human rights record?
—He is not happy, Andrew.
—Order! Honourable members on my left will cease interjecting.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me say that I fully understand the depth of the concerns of the honourable member for Calwell in the question that he has asked. Let me say this: the award of the honorary Companion of the Order of Australia is in recognition of President Ozal's distinguished personal contribution to the development of bilateral relations between Australia and Turkey. As the Leader of the Opposition and the Leader of the National Party of Australia will recall, that was most recently demonstrated during the successful pilgrimage to commemorate the seventy-fifth anniversary of the landing at Gallipoli. It is a personal award and it does not indicate in any way that there are no policy differences between Australia and Turkey. The honourable member should appreciate that.

ANSWER.PARA: The Turkish Government is aware of our position both on Cyprus and on human rights. Australia has consistently supported the United Nations Security Council resolutions on Cyprus-namely, resolutions 541, 550 and 649. This Government has consistently supported those resolutions. We have upheld the sovereignty and the territorial integrity of the Republic of Cyprus, consistently condemning the unilateral declaration of the Turkish Republic of Northern Cyprus in 1983. I think, as the honourable member knows, we have consistently done that.

We have been actively involved as well in a search for a solution to the problems of Cyprus. We have contributed the services of 20 Australian Federal Police personnel to the United Nations peacekeeping force in Cyprus. We have been supporting the United Nations Secretary-General's negotiating efforts, which we believe offer the best prospects for a just and lasting settlement of this question. This Government supports the universal application of internationally accepted standards of human rights. We remain concerned over continuing reports of human rights abuses in Turkey.

In response to information provided by the Amnesty International parliamentary group, our embassy in Ankara makes representations to the Turkish Government on cases of concern. In my discussions about important international and bilateral issues with President Ozal, I will of course raise these and other issues of concern to Australia, as, may I say, I did when I was in Turkey last year and speaking with the President then. But I note and I welcome President Ozal's significant personal contribution to recent reforms in a number of areas in Turkey. So I believe that I and the Government have a responsibility to take a comprehensive view of Australia's national interests.

It is the case, as I believe the Leader of the Opposition and the Leader of the National Party will agree with me, that last year President Ozal played a significant role in helping this nation to commemorate what for it is one of its most sacred institutions, and we are honouring the President of Turkey in respect of the contribution that he has made to the improvement of relations between us. But I emphasise to the honourable member for Calwell that our doing that, as we believe we should, responsibly, in regard to a proper understanding of Australia's overall interests, does not mean that we ignore or put aside our concerns on these other issues: the question of Cyprus and the question of human rights in Turkey. I repeat the answer I have given to the honourable member: that in the discussions I had with President Ozal, those issues will be raised and dealt with seriously.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is again directed to the Prime Minister. In view of his unwillingness to answer the last two questions, can I try again and ask very simply: who runs wages policy in this country-the Prime Minister or the Treasurer and his good mate Bill Kelty? Did the Prime Minister roll the Treasurer in Cabinet yesterday in reconfirming a significant role for the Industrial Relations Commission? Was this part of the Prime Minister's campaign against the Treasurer's forthcoming leadership challenge?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have heard some pathetic questions from the Leader of the Opposition; I think this one takes the cake. Let me say that there was no question in the Cabinet of trying to roll anyone. We had, as we always do on serious matters like this, a serious discussion about the issues involved. There is no doubt--
—Very serious? How serious?

—Mr Speaker, we are getting these funny little interjections, `How serious? Very serious?' Is he not profound, this bubblegum man of politics? He blows the little bubble, it explodes and it has gone away. Look, be quiet, Bubblegum; let us get on with the serious issue.
—The Prime Minister might refer to the Leader of the Opposition by his title.

—The fact is that in the Cabinet there was a very serious discussion about a serious issue. It is not a question of whether I or the Treasurer or Bill Kelty or some other individual runs wages policy in this country. What the Leader of the Opposition will not bring himself to understand is that a sea change occurred in 1983 in terms of the attitude of government to the organised work force of this country. His philosophy, the inherent philosophy of the tories of this country going back 100 years, is to take them on, to fight them.

ANSWER.PARA: On Saturday I was in Barcaldine, and in Barcaldine 100 years ago the tories of the time turned on the Nordenfelt and the Gatling guns against the organised workers of this country. And nothing has changed in 100 years; this Leader of the Opposition who has asked me this question said just recently that he would do the same thing as they did 100 years ago: he would put the troops onto the waterfront. Nothing has changed in 100 years. The tories hated working men and women 100 years ago, and they hate their organisations 100 years later. In 1983 a sea change occurred--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There is far too much noise.

—A sea change occurred in 1983. This Labor Government said that the organised working men and women of this country are a force for good. Whether we are going to get increased productivity, whether we are going to get better work practices, and whether we are going to get achievable aggregate national wages incomes depends on the Government sitting down in a constructive way and talking with the trade union movement. We have never made any apology about that. We have gone about it. The Minister for Industrial Relations, the Treasurer and the Prime Minister have been involved in sitting down and talking with the leadership of the trade union movement. We have achieved the outcomes to which I have referred-outcomes which honourable members opposite were never capable of achieving.

ANSWER.PARA: That does not mean that at some time the Treasurer will not be speaking with Mr Kelty. It does mean that that will be happening. For instance, when the present Minister for Finance was the Minister for Industrial Relations, he spoke with them. Senator Cook speaks with them; I speak with them. But we speak with them on the basis of a common policy and a common philosophy. The common philosophy is this: the organised working men and women of this country are an asset without whom we will not have growth, without whom we will not have increased productivity, and without whom we will not have restructuring.

The only way to get their involved, positive cooperation is by sitting down and talking with them. Sometimes it is the Treasurer, sometimes it is the Minister for Industrial Relations, sometimes it is the Prime Minister-but it is always on that common philosophy and on the common basis of trying to get what is best for this country. Against that position we have the unfortunate fact that 100 years on, in 1991, honourable members opposite have learned nothing. It was the use of troops against workers in 1891, and it is the same policy today.

All I can say is if that is their policy, if they want to go to the electorate in 1993 with that same approach, we will be happy to meet them. I know what the answer will be: they will be thrown out as they have been on the last four occasions, and so they should.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Land Transport. Is the Minister aware of a proposal to impose a toll on the F4 western freeway in Sydney? Will the imposition of a toll have a substantial adverse impact on the communities of western Sydney? Given the Federal funding implications of the freeway, can the Minister advise of the Government's intentions in this matter?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the proposal on the part of the New South Wales Government to impose the toll on the F4 freeway west of Sydney, and I thank the honourable member for Parramatta for the question. He raised this question in the Parliament at least on one occasion-on 18 February-and the concerns he expressed on that occasion vindicate the position that he adopted.

ANSWER.PARA: By way of background and for the benefit of members of the House, I would like to indicate briefly the circumstances surrounding this toll proposal and why it is causing such concern not only to me, but also to the local community in the vicinity of the freeway. The New South Wales Government plans to fund the so-called missing link section of the F4 freeway between May's Hill and Prospect, and some widening work further east, through a private toll road development. As the F4 is a State arterial road, and therefore the responsibility of the State Government, the imposition of a toll is a matter for the State to consider, and the Federal Government is not in the business of telling the State how to run its road system.

The location of the toll booths on the F4 is, however, of direct interest to the Federal Government. The section of this road on which the New South Wales Government proposes to collect revenue has already received substantial funding from the Federal Government. The New South Wales Government proposal is to place the toll collection booths some distance to the east of the eastern end of the missing link on the section to be widened. In between the booths and the eastern end of the missing link lies a section of road that was paid for by the Federal Government under the Australian bicentennial road development program, and at a total cost of $38.4m. This section of the road has already been paid for by the public, and under the New South Wales proposal the public would be required to pay for it again.

Should the toll be imposed, it is likely to force thousands of cars and trucks through adjacent streets in the area in an effort to avoid the toll. This raises very real concerns about safety and increased air and noise pollution in the local community areas.

In addition, I consider it to be unfair that commuters in the Parramatta area, represented so admirably by the honourable member for Parramatta, will be forced to pay the toll every day and that they should be expected to shoulder the burden of funding a section of road which will ultimately benefit a much wider section of the community. After considering the matter closely and at some length, I have come to the conclusion that, because of the implications of that for Federal programs and the social implications, there would be no social benefit which would justify bringing forward the construction of that road by the imposition of a toll and which would outweigh the social disadvantages that would be associated with it. For that reason, I will not give my approval.

I would also like to make it perfectly clear that that does not necessarily pre-empt any decision that might be made in the future by me, as Minister, or by the Government in connection with questions of that kind. We will continue to do as we have done in the past-consider questions of that kind on their merits. But in this particular case, I endorse the concerns raised by the honourable member and those of his colleagues who represent those areas west of Parramatta and who are looking after the interests of their constituents. As far as I am concerned, that road will not have a toll on it. We will not charge people again for a road for which they have already paid.

TALK.START.PARA: —How does the Prime Minister justify paying wharfies an extra 8.5 per cent plus national wage increases, making a total around 14 per cent, when they already earn $339 a week above the average wage for only a 27-hour working week at a time when nearly 800,000 Australians are unemployed, small businesses are going broke at record levels, and farmers are going bankrupt? Does the Prime Minister consider that caving in to the waterfront unions demonstrates the strength of leadership the country needs in this time of crisis?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —This mob opposite have been in top form today! The proposition which, I understand, underlies this question is that I caved in to the wharfies. What I suggest is this: ask Captain Setchell that question. Then honourable members opposite will see what a load of-let me be polite-nonsense underlies this question.
—The honourable member for Mackellar!

—We have had a situation where the employers unanimously-I am not talking about myself-applauded the Government for what it has been able to achieve in this matter. Did they say that this was a case of Hawke caving in to the wharfies? We had a position where unanimously the employers and everyone involved said that this was a necessary and appropriate and good outcome.

ANSWER.PARA: Let me make it quite clear that the agreement that was negotiated has the support of all parties to the in-principle agreement on waterfront reform. The employers, including Conaust which, through Captain Setchell, has been a regular critic of the process, are more than satisfied with the outcome. The union, whose executive is recommending its acceptance, is also supportive of it; and we have the Government and the Waterfront Industry Reform Authority. We have a position where we are going to have a $12 increase from May and then three increases of 2 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Mackellar!

—That is a situation in which, the employers themselves acknowledge, we are going to be looking at productivity increases of the order of 60 per cent. Are we really having those opposite flushed out now, saying that, where the employees are going to be involved in significant reform restructuring which is going to produce productivity increases of the order of 60 per cent, we should say, `Sorry, chaps, you are going to have a whole lot of your people going out of the industry; you are going to be retrained; you are going to have to do different jobs; you are going to have to do them differently; you are going to have to do them more productively; you are going to produce 60 per cent in productivity, but you are not getting any of the action.'?

ANSWER.PARA: Is the Opposition serious? Is this what those opposite mean by sensible industrial relations? Is this what they mean by reform? They say to an area of industry, `We're going to throw out several thousand of you workers; we're going to make you undertake retraining; we're going to make you do new jobs; we're going to make you do them more efficiently; we're going to produce 60 per cent productivity'. But I have news for you chaps: you will not.

TALK.START.PARA: —So they should.
—Listen to the troglodytes. The only interjection-`So they should'.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for the Northern Territory!

INTERJECT.PARA: Mr Carlton interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I warn the honourable member for Mackellar.

—Let the people of Australia know precisely what the Opposition is talking about. Those opposite are saying that there will be reform in this country-that there will be fundamental changes in work practices; that they will get rid of thousands of people; that they will make people retrain, do jobs differently and more productively; that they will produce a 60 per cent increase in productivity; but that the reward is to get nothing. I have news for those opposite: not only will the workers of this country not accept that nonsense but neither will the people. I hope again that as we go through the period up to 1993 those opposite attempt to go to the people saying that that is their concept of industrial and social justice-reform, change, getting rid of people, more productive employment, but nothing in it for the worker. If those opposite go to the people with that we will beat the hell out of them.

—Can the Minister for Community Services and Health inform the House of the effect of the new Medicare cards on Australian families? How will the new system make it easier for families? What should Australians do to get their new Medicare card? Will the card help to make even more efficient our universal and equitable health insurance system?

—Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. Standing order 144 states that questions should not ask Ministers to announce government policy. The honourable member is clearly asking for a ministerial statement with a great deal associated with the Government's policy announcement. As such, that question should be ruled out of order.
—Order! There is no point of order. The Government has already announced the policy; the honourable member is asking how it will be implemented.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Reid for hosting in his electorate the launch of the new Medicare card. I can certainly understand his interest in the administration of the Medicare system. Indeed, in many respects the Medicare card has been a symbol of a universal and equitable health insurance system. The new system will make it easier for families in a number of ways. For example, every family Medicare card will provide a reference number for each child so that claiming will be made easier, so that transfers can be more easily achieved and so that verification of each claim will be speedier.

ANSWER.PARA: The main reason that Medicare makes life easier for families, and always has done, is that it takes the worry out of health care. It is a fact that the Medicare system has been stable. It is a system which has reduced overall administrative costs. It has been efficient. It has been part of an equitable system of health care, which can be contrasted not only with what went before but also with the present alternatives to a universal health insurance. Up to this point we have heard very little from the Opposition about its approach to policy. Following the recent visit of the Leader of the Opposition to New Zealand--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Leader of the Opposition will cease interjecting.

—The Leader of the Opposition referred to the question of vouchers. It was an issue he raised. It was one of the Prime Minister's bubbles. It was the question of private health insurance, the question of shifting from Medicare to an alternative which the Leader of the Opposition began to speak about, but then he failed to develop his thinking. He talked about a voucher. He vaguely talked about a move to private health insurance. Indeed, he talked about the privatisation of welfare. We never hear any detail from the Leader of the Opposition, although it is clear from his interview with Matt Abraham yesterday that there are three central principles in the Opposition's policy over and against the principles which are implicit in Medicare of which--

—I raise a point of order, Mr Speaker. I refer to standing order 144 and specifically the part which states that questions asked of Ministers should not seek an expression of opinion. I ask you either to rule that the question was out of order, on the basis that the expressions of the Minister are expressions of opinion, or, alternatively, to refer to standing order 145 because the answer is not relevant to the question.

—We do not rule questions out of order retrospectively. If the honourable member for Isaacs wanted to raise a point of order on a question, he should have done so while the honourable member was asking his question, not when the Minister was into his answer. The Minister is answering the question he was asked. He might get back to the question.
—Mr Speaker, I was making the point that--
—You are expressing a point of view.
—Order! If the honourable member for Isaacs continues to interject, I will name him.

—The card has been a symbol of an approach to health care based on equity and principles of efficiency. The Opposition would seek to dismantle this system and this approach, but we do not have a great deal of understanding of the detail of what it is about. However, in terms of the interview with Matt Abraham yesterday on Australian Broadcasting Corporation radio, we see three central themes, if you like--

—I raise a point of order. Mr Speaker, I also refer you to the matter of relevance. I refer you to precedents in this Parliament and, in particular, rulings by Speaker Snedden on answers to questions. Further, I refer you to the point of order taken by Mrs Child prior to her being a Speaker. I would like to read you the precedent--
—Does the honourable member for O'Connor have a point of order? The honourable member for O'Connor will raise his point of order or he will resume his seat.
—My point of order relates to standing order 145. I have the right to draw your attention to precedence in this place, and I wish to do so as a member of parliament.
—Order! The honourable member for O'Connor has the right to raise a point of order.
—Yes, Sir, and I have the right to speak to my point of order.
—Honourable members do not get to speak to points of order; they get to raise them.
—They certainly do.
—They certainly do not. Therefore, the honourable member will resume his seat.
—With due respect, Sir, this is a democracy and I am an elected member of parliament. If we are going to have dictators in this place--

—Order! The honourable member for O'Connor will resume his seat. The honourable member for O'Connor has raised a point of order relating to standing order 145, concerning relevance. The Minister was answering the question he was asked. The Minister will answer the question.
—One can understand the sensitivity of the Opposition.

—The honourable member for O'Connor might just listen for a minute. I simply want to refer to what the Leader of the Opposition said on the public record. If the Leader of the Opposition wants to walk away every time any member of this Parliament repeats what he said yesterday, that gives us a measure of what the Leader of the Opposition is about. He is not able to sustain his view. Yesterday he made it clear that on three principles of social policy he was perfectly clear. One was that we needed to move towards a situation in which there was a greater sense of private responsibility, rather than responsibility resting, as it does, with--
—Mr Speaker, on a point of order: it is now almost 3.20 p.m. and it has taken an hour and 20 minutes for 14 questions to be asked and answered.
—Does the honourable member for Hume have a point of order?

—Mr Speaker, what is taking place now-the Minister answering this question and indeed other Ministers answering questions today-is a gross abuse of Question Time. I ask you either to rule that the statement by the Minister is a ministerial statement or to ask him to draw his answer to a close.
—The honourable member for Hume will resume his seat. There is no point of order. I call the Minister.
—What about relevance?
—Order! I warn the honourable member for Mackellar.
—I have been referring to the Medicare card-a card which goes to every family in Australia. The Leader of the Opposition said yesterday, `In principle--

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Dr Hewson

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. I draw your attention to standing order 145, which relates to relevance. Mr Speaker, I ask you for consistency in relation to Speakers' rulings on relevance. I cite, as a precedent, circumstance in August 1981, when the current Prime Minister raised a similar point of order seeking a ruling on consistency in rulings on relevance. The Speaker's response on that occasion was:

INTERJECT.PARA: The Minister will answer the question and not engage in irrelevancies, such as contrasting the Government and the Labor Party.
Mr Speaker, I put it that consistency of rulings on relevance would have you rule out of order the rest of the Minister's answer and have him sit down.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister has been trying to answer the question. For the life of me and, I am sure, other members, I do not know what the Minister is going to say about what the Leader of the Opposition said. For all I know, he may be going to say that the Leader of the Opposition supported him on the administration of Medicare. I think the House might hear the Minister. I think the Minister might get to the points that were raised in the question. We might thus find out what is in the answer.
—Mr Speaker, I raise a further point of order. Do you accept the need for consistency in rulings from the Chair in relation to relevance?

—The honourable member for Wentworth, who seems to be taking an interest in the Standing Orders, might use the yardstick which his colleague quoted to me of Speaker Snedden, and then come back and talk to me about consistency. I call the Minister.

—There is no more fundamental political question than that relating to public, as opposed to private, responsibility. I was simply wanting to refer to the Leader of the Opposition's statement yesterday, when he said:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . in principle, personal financial responsibility originating with the family and the targeting of welfare are key elements of our approach . . .

There is a direct contrast as between the Government, which in terms of Medicare sees a system in which public responsibility is taken to deliver universal and equitable benefits, and the Opposition's approach, which I was beginning to refer to.

Mr Speaker, I will return at the appropriate time later in the week to try to develop what apparently the Opposition is willing to have revealed, that is, the very stark contrast between what the Leader of the Opposition is prepared to say outside of this place but has not got the guts to debate within it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I wish to direct a question to you. In the light of the answer given by the Prime Minister to a question asked by the honourable member for Calwell concerning the honorary Order of Australia given to the President of Turkey, will you reconsider your reported decision to boycott the official dinner for the President of Turkey on Thursday night? Or do you not accept the arguments of the Prime Minister?

—I will be represented at that dinner by my deputy. I note in passing that in regard to the arrangements that have been made for the arrival of President Ozal at Canberra Airport, indeed the Leader of the Opposition will be represented at that arrival by his deputy as well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Staples The Hon P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.
—Does the Minister claim to have been misrepresented?
—I certainly do.
—The Minister may proceed.

—On 19 April the Brisbane Sun, the Sydney Telegraph Mirror and Haydn Sargent on Radio 4BC in Brisbane reported that I favoured paying drug addicts extra money for just turning up for work. The Brisbane Sun published an article by Paul Reynolds with reaction to the proposal by the Queensland Confederation of Industry. The newspaper also printed an editorial roundly slamming my purported comments as a `ludicrous idea'. The Telegraph Mirror attributed to me the statement:

SPEECH.PARA: Drug addicts who try to kick the habit should get paid extra for just turning up to work . . . bonuses for good work attendance are needed as an incentive for employees undergoing drug rehabilitation.
Mr Haydn Sargent said:

Amongst a lot of good suggestions that Mr Staples made for employers helping in the rehabilitation of addicts-whether they're alcohol or drugs-is the suggestion that they're paid extra money for turning up at work is just plain silly.
Mr Sargent went on to say:

That kind of attitude expressed by Mr Staples gives rise to the constant criticism that governments all too often have become quick to resort to unreasonable welfare mentality rather than trying to find solutions to inspire people to work.

In fairness to the Brisbane Sun, it at least ran a small correction on 22 April. But to my knowledge the Telegraph Mirror and Mr Sargent have not admitted their mistake. Needless to say, the suggestion in the reports that I advocate paying drug addicts for turning up to work is simply rubbish.

At a Drugs in the Workplace conference in Melbourne on 18 April I said that sick leave was legitimate for people undergoing drug and alcohol rehabilitation, a common practice in many developed countries. Moreover, I said that incentives for workers respecting good health practices, such as bonuses for high productivity and good attendance records negotiated between employers and employees, could be considered in a package approach. This is very different from what was reported in those papers. Sensationalist reporting, based on misinformation, causes unnecessary confrontation and is not conducive to developing national approaches to combat drug abuse in the workplace.
