DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Sharp) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The Government's failure to deliver the essential savings on our waterfront for Australian exporters to compete in international markets.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sharp Mr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a fairly commonplace event these days for those who live in the Australian community to witness the breaking of promises by this Labor Government here in Canberra. But yesterday we saw a breathtaking new high in the Government's approach to its credibility-in specific terms, the preparedness of one of the Ministers of the Government to make clear, definite and concise promises which he has, as of yesterday, clearly broken, with no remorse, no sense of guilt and no apology thrown in.

SPEECH.PARA: I speak in specific terms of the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support (Senator Collins), who just on 12 months ago, on 6 May last year, made a clear promise to resign if he was not able to achieve significant reform on the Australian waterfront. I want to quote from the comments of Senator Collins, to put in context the promise that he made just on 12 months ago yesterday. He said:
If there hasn't been the completion of the award restructuring process and if there hasn't been a number of these enterprise agreements put into place, after I've been in this job 12 months, I quit.
He then went on to say:
I won't need anyone to sack me, I will do it myself.

We cannot get any more definite commitment than the one we have just heard, which was made by the Minister for Shipping, Senator Collins, 12 months ago. If this were a man of honour, a man of decency and credibility, one would consider that, as of yesterday, the anniversary of the making of that promise, Senator Collins's resignation would have been offered to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). One would have considered, too, that the Prime Minister would have accepted it.

When we look at the last 12 months, we realise that there is strong justification for the Prime Minister to accept the resignation offer of the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support. Two specific promises were made by the Minister in that statement of 12 months ago. The first was the promise in relation to the completion of the award restructuring process. Twelve months later, has the award restructuring process been completed? The answer is no, it has not been completed. We are a long way from actually seeing anything happen as far as award restructuring is concerned. The second promise was that a number of enterprise agreements would be put into place. Have a number of these enterprise agreements been put into place on the waterfront? No, there has been only one-and one, incidentally, which comes from the Government's own stevedoring company, National Terminals (Australia) Ltd, and which in the last few days has been drawn into doubt because it appears that it will be renegotiated.

The Minister promised that there would be several enterprise agreements in place within 12 months. The fact is that there is only one. On both counts, the Minister, Senator Collins, has broken the promise, so one would think a resignation would have been in the offing as of yesterday. But, of course, there was not a resignation. A couple of weeks ago, in an interview on the Sunday program with Laurie Oakes, Senator Collins told us that he was not going to offer his resignation because, even though he said those things, he did not really mean to say them; what he really meant to say, he did not say; and, if he had said what he meant to say, it would have been different from what he had said. That all sounds kind of confusing. It is confusing, because the Minister is confusing. He is confusing the truth and he is confusing his credibility.

What would the objective judge say about the Minister, Senator Collins? He or she would have to say that, as a result of the Minister's promise made 12 months ago and his subsequent refusal to resign in keeping with that promise, Senator Collins has no credibility. Some would say that Senator Collins looks a bit of a fool. Some would say that Senator Collins is a buffoon. I think they are fair and sound comments to make about Senator Collins, because he did make that commitment, a commitment which he has not been prepared to live up to.

The Prime Minister, if he were a man of fairness and a man of honour, would have demanded that Senator Collins fulfil the commitment he made 12 months ago. But, of course, the Prime Minister did not demand that Senator Collins resign yesterday. Why? Because the poor old Prime Minister needs Senator Collins's support. Why? Because there is a leadership challenge on within the Australian Labor Party. He cannot afford to put offside his own mates within the Australian Labor Party, because he cannot afford to offend anybody at present.

For that reason, the Prime Minister did not demand the apology and indeed the resignation that should have come from Senator Collins. Of course, because of the Prime Minister's weak position within his own Party, he decided to try to boost his standing within the community and the Party over the past fortnight or so since the House last sat. What has he been doing? He has been up to his ears trying to do a good deal for the wharfies, to get the union movement back on side with him. As a result, the Prime Minister has entered into negotiations on behalf of the unions with the employers to deliver a wage increase way in excess of community expectations at this time, in order to give our wharfies a better deal than they already have.

The Prime Minister has been busy; he had a 19-hour marathon session with employers of waterfront labour and with the unions on Wednesday last week. That was an extraordinary thing for the Prime Minister to do; one does not often see that happening with a Prime Minister. Perhaps our Prime Minister has slipped back into the days when he was the President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions; indeed, perhaps he is trying to do some favour for his old mates.

Whatever the case, the Prime Minister tried to describe what he did last week as enterprise bargaining. On no objective judgment could anybody claim that last week's effort by the Prime Minister, the unions and the employers of waterfront labour could be termed as enterprise bargaining; a better description would be enterprise bullying. What possible enterprise bargaining could be considered to be fair and normal when the Prime Minister and the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support were engaged in it up to their ears? It certainly was not that.

One has to say that the Prime Minister was involved only because of his close and long association with his trade union mates. One has to realise that the waterfront is a sacred site to the labour movement of Australia. People within the Labor movement of Australia will go out of their way to do good things for their wharfie mates. Why on earth would they, the average Australian would ask, when these people are so well off in relation to the rest of the community? For example, would the Prime Minister have exerted the same sort of effort for our farmers? When the live sheep export industry was going down the plughole, did the Prime Minister try to do anything to fix that up? No, he did not. Did he try to do the same thing for our wheat industry when it was facing heavy subsidies from the United States Government? Did he go across to the United States leading a delegation with the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson)? No, he did not do that. He would not go out of his way for the wheatgrowers or the live sheep export industry because they are not Labor mates.

Over the past fortnight we have seen the true colour of this Labor Government coming forward. It is the true colour which will ensure that the wharfies will receive a total of 8.6 per cent wage increase over the next 15 months. In addition to that 8.6 per cent increase, it must be realised that the national wage increases between now and 15 months time will also be included. It is fair to say that this will probably bring the wage rise to 14 per cent or 14.5 per cent over the next few months. Where on earth will the 14 per cent or 14.5 per cent come from? It will not come from the pockets of the stevedores; they will only pass on that cost to the users of the waterfront.

At Question Time today we heard the Prime Minister say that he had involved everybody on the waterfront in the negotiations over the past fortnight, and how happy and delighted they were with the deal. However, the Prime Minister forgot to mention the one group that actually pays for it all-the users: the farmers, manufacturers, retailers and consumers who will pay for it.

TALK.START.PARA: —They're not important!

—No, they are not important. For goodness sake, they are not the Government's mates. Its mates are the wharfies so it will do a good deal for them. Honourable members can see a wage rise coming forward for the wharfies, which will be around $100 a week when it is finally completed; $100 a week is not bad. This wage rise comes in the midst of the worst recession we have had since the Second World War. One might say, `Thank goodness we have a recession'; had there not been a recession, what sort of a wage rise would these people have got from the Prime Minister? I suggest it would have been in the order of 30 per cent to 40 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: Who pays? The farmers pay 20 per cent of the cost of everything that goes on in the Australian waterfront. What is the average family farm worker earning in the current financial year? The answer is $100 a week. That is an interesting figure, because it precisely matches the size of the wage increase that the wharfies will get.

The wages that wharfies get are, of course, only a part of the package. Their package includes many allowances. The Prime Minister, having spent a fortnight negotiating the position for the wharfies, got a good deal for his mates. He did so at the expense of farmers, manufacturers, retailers and so forth. What is he doing? He is promoting their upper middle class lifestyle. That is all he is doing. Do honourable members know how much wharfies earn? Last year on average wharfies earned $824 a week for a 27-hour week. Last year the average wage earner earned $485 per week. Wharfies earned $339 a week more than the average wage earner-some 70 per cent more. So it is an upper middle class group that the Government has been supporting so strongly over the last fortnight.

These people are doing well at everybody else's expense. They have a job which one might say is very well paid. It is a job which one might say is not highly skilled. Even people on the other side of the House could perform the tasks of a waterside worker. Even the wages earned by people on the other side of the House could pale into insignificance when compared with the wages earned by people on the waterfront. When we talk about a wage of $825 a week we also have to remember that waterside workers who become foremen and supervisors can earn up to $100,000 a year.

All of this was designed to get waterfront reform back on the rails. What will be the position when the waterfront is back on the rails? Two months ago in this House we had a debate on this same subject. At the time, the Government had, of course, admitted that waterfront reform had fallen behind pace-that it was not proceeding with the speed that had been hoped for. The Government said that there were to be 500 redundancies last September. The result was zero redundancies. By March of this year there should have been 1,000 redundancies. We had all been told to expect 451 redundancies by the end of March, although the original expectation was 1,000. I am sorry to say that we have some bad news. The expected 451 redundancies did not actually happen. Instead of that, we ended up with redundancies of only 361. There has been a little bit of a shortfall.

If we balance that with the fact that the Government has enabled the waterfront to employ an extra 213 people, we suddenly realises that the net reduction in waterfront workers over the last year and a half of so-called Government reform amounts to 148 wharfies. That is all we have got out of all of the rhetoric and hoo-ha from that side of the House. This is hardly what we would call keeping waterfront reform on track. Yet, that is exactly what the Prime Minister told us he was doing.

In the meantime, a genuine government that is involved in genuine reform has been able to achieve significant things. The New South Wales Government has been reforming its Maritime Services Board-its port authority. Over the last 18 months, out of an initial work force of 2,920 people 1,322 have gone. Nearly half of the Maritime Services Board's work force has actually left over the last 18 months. That is what we call genuine reform-not the 148 out of a total of some 6,000 on the Australian waterfront that this Government has been able to achieve over the last 18 months. It simply does not stand up to the test.

If we test what this Government hopes to achieve over the few months that remain of the waterfront reform program, we will see that our reform programs under this Government pale into insignificance when compared with other programs around the world. We stand to achieve efficiency levels in Australia of only about half that of our trading competitors. The port of New Orleans in the United States of America can handle 37 containers per hour. The goal that Senator Collins has set for himself in Australia is 20 to 25 containers per hour.

There is no question that the goals that this Government has set for itself under its waterfront reform program are inadequate. The promises made by the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support have been proven to be unfulfilled and have been broken. As a result of that, there is a need for this Government not only to live up to the claims that it makes but also to undertake genuine reform for the benefit of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have just had a genuinely silly speech from a genuinely nice man.
—You've got to withdraw that.

—I withdraw `genuinely nice man', which is what the honourable member asked for. The Opposition has put a position on waterfront reform and I take it that this is what we are now to understand the Opposition to mean when it talks about enterprise bargaining. The position is this: if workers agree to substantial changes in work practices and productivity is substantially increased, not just on the waterfront but in any business, they will not be permitted to receive a wage rise. This is apparently the position now being put forward by the Opposition. We can interpret it in no other way. The extra six and a bit per cent relating to each of the tranches can only be achieved after there is delivery of changes in those areas. They are the only terms under which that can be achieved.

SPEECH.PARA: Under our formula for enterprise bargaining, no wage rises can take place unless they are preceded by genuine changes in work practices and staffing levels which improve the productivity of an organisation. That is the basis on which we operate. It does not matter how much one is paid. The simple fact of the matter is that a very substantial proportion of the work force on which there needs to be a concentration in the productivity area via the enterprise bargaining process happens to be among the most highly paid in our community. There is no question about that. Sometimes this is because the people involved are in a semi-monopoly situation in terms of the companies or authorities that employ them; sometimes it is because they have substantial skills which they have for sale. So if the position is put to them and the public generally that under enterprise bargaining we expect productivity changes for no achievement as far as they are concerned in respect of wages, there will be no achievement of enterprise agreements. That is all there is to it.

To this point the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) has paraded around this country saying that what he stands for is beneficial to the country, beneficial to management, owners and shareholders and beneficial to the work force. To this point, that is what he has said is the intention of Liberal Party policy on enterprise bargaining. But we now have the Opposition spokesman on shipping and waterfront matters saying effectively, in a question he asked the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and during debate here, that that is irrelevant.

As far as the Opposition is concerned, we will get enterprise agreements that improve productivity but absolutely none of the gains will be returned to the work force. That is just simply one of the many areas in which Opposition industrial policy is away with the fairies. It is away with the fairies in terms of commonsense as to how one approaches one's fellow Australian citizens; it is away with the fairies in terms of ever being able to achieve an outcome as far as productivity in this nation is concerned.

The objections that have been raised here about the waterfront reform process are as about as silly as we have heard from the Opposition on any matter that it has brought before this House. The first six or seven minutes of the speech of the honourable member of Gilmore (Mr Sharp) were devoted to a silly call for the resignation of the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support (Senator Collins). Anybody who has had anything to do with the employers, the shippers and the unions has nothing but praise for the way in which Bob Collins has handled that specific portfolio task.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about his promise?

—I am going to get on to that. We have been told that he should keep a promise. I will tell the House what his promise was. He said at the time that he would resign if there was not one agreement in place. He did not say that he was going to resign unless there had been the achievement of a total Government package. Of course, since he has been the Minister he has achieved those positions and there are some agreements already in place. Not all are going to be achieved, but some are already in place. I go to one of them-the one with National Terminals (Australia) Ltd (NTAL).

SPEECH.PARA: Again we get no analysis from the Opposition of what that agreement with NTAL involves. That agreement involves a 34 per cent reduction in the work force associated with the company-a 34 per cent reduction-in return for a 60 per cent improvement in productivity. So we have fewer people operating on the waterfront, a massive change in work practices associated with it and a 60 per cent improvement in productivity. That is an agreement gained in part through the activities of Senator Bob Collins as the relevant Minister.

The honourable member for Gilmore did nothing more than carp for seven minutes of his speech to make one passing political point about the matter and hope that nobody actually analyses what Senator Collins had to say. In the parliamentary process honourable members opposite, as an Opposition, oppose us in government, and we explain ourselves and oppose them. That is fair enough, and in that debating process there is the odd comment such as, `Ha, ha, ha'. But the fact of the matter is that the honourable member for Gilmore devoted almost half his speech to a trivial point-and, as it happens, erroneously as far as Senator Collins is concerned.

What else have we had from the Opposition on these waterfront reform proposals negotiated by the Prime Minister, among others, last week? We had from the honourable member for Bennelong-and God knows where we are going to get enterprise agreements or anything else out of the Liberal Party if it ever gets into office-this statement: `The process shouldn't have been taking place at all. It should have been purely a matter for the employers and employees'-not, I might say, the shippers. He did not have anything to say about the shippers. He said, `purely a matter for the employers and the employees'. The shippers have been added as an afterthought by the Opposition spokesman who has participated in the debate here today.

So the position of the honourable member for Bennelong is, `We will achieve enormous changes in industrial relations by doing nothing'. This is very convenient. That was the Liberal Party position when it was in office. It had attitudes; it was a Government with attitudes. Invariably on a wage case issue before the Australian Industrial Relations Commission when a general proposition was put forward on wages, the response that came forward from the then Liberal Government was, `It ought not happen. There ought to be no wage rises; there shouldn't be any increases. The work force ought to be de-unionised; they all ought to be sacked'. Of course, nothing occurred. It was just attitude.

What did occur were 18 per cent wage rises with no productivity gains, on the basis of mindless speeches about the resources boom being upon us. That is what happened. Mixed signals were being sent all the time and there was absolutely no government involvement. That is convenient; it means that attitudinally those in government can always be right even if governmentally they are always wrong. But at least honourable members opposite will be able to point back to their marvellous speeches during the period when they were in government about what they were attempting to achieve and say that somehow the situation created itself.

Of course, we all know that situations do create themselves. In recessions wages go down if left to themselves. In booms wages go through the roof and of themselves produce other recessions in pretty short order without any other factors impacting on the economy. That is basically where the Opposition leaves itself. In its industrial policies it would chalk up some runs on the board, provided the country was in recession or permanent recession. If it entered into a boom period without government jaw-boning through a process like the accord, the system would have the guts ripped out of it and there would be no real benefits in terms of the achievement of an improved industrial infrastructure in this country.

That is the position of the Opposition. It does not quite have a total hands-off position, because it recognises that simply declaring the waterside workers union no longer compulsory, that one is not obliged to be a member, or simply removing over 12 months the guarantees of employment or something like that are in themselves meaningless acts, unless they happen to be enforced on the waterfront, and that it would have to do something else. In the Opposition's heart of hearts, it knows that. It might work in some industries. If it goes down to a poor old bunch of shop assistants or if it goes out into the bush and tells workers that they cannot join the Australian Workers Union-I have worked on a couple of the farms that the honourable gentleman talked about-yes, it would work. Those workers will not join the unions. However, the workers on the waterfront will just have a huge laugh at the Opposition, and the waterfront is obviously much more critical to the future productivity of this country.

So the Opposition has a solution. It knows in its heart of hearts that its waterfront policy is unworkable. And its solution is to bring in the troops. Again this is just off the top of the Opposition's head. I wish that we on this side of the House could say that this was just a piece of alarmist baloney. I wish we could say that in this place. Unfortunately we cannot, because several Opposition spokesmen have said that as a fall-back the Opposition would have that in mind. The trouble is that the fall-back would be the policy and the only policy it could pursue. So rather than have the Prime Minister engaged in a genuine effort to get the employers together and to get some productivity in the place, the Opposition would discover that it had not achieved productivity and would put in the soldiers. Let me tell honourable members opposite: one has to be very careful when one puts in soldiers. Firstly, they do not like it.
Mr Broadbent interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, and I am going to tell the honourable member opposite about it. I have had personal experience in connection with it, so the honourable member opposite can learn from my experience. I will go into it for him. One has to be very careful because, in the first instance, the soldiers do not like it. Their view-the soldiers, sailors and airmen-is that their duty is to defend the people of this country. Unlike the Opposition, they do not find it in their hearts to regard the workers-who are their fathers, their cousins, their uncles, their mothers, their daughters and their sisters-as enemies. It is very, very difficult. They have an entitlement, even though they are under discipline, to be as assured as anyone else that what they are doing is well supported in the community.

SPEECH.PARA: When we put in the airmen, we did not train up airmen to fly Boeing 737s or Boeing 727s. We did not do that, even though we knew we confronted a long strike. In that confrontation we used the airmen to man their own equipment. Let me tell honourable members that one has to think these things through. In addition to that, we had the solid support of the trade union movement, so that aircraft were refuelled, the baggage was handled, the goods or whatever that were transported on the aircraft would be picked up and taken away from the airport to elsewhere. We did it on the basis of that support from the trade union movement.

The Opposition should try it on the waterfront and see what happens. Is it going to have the troops to bring the trains down to the waterfront? Is it going to have the troops to do the warehousing? Is it going to have the troops to make sure that the goods taken off the waterfront are not black-listed? Is it going to have the troops to bring the trucks into the waterfront and take them out? The Opposition does not have a defence policy which anticipates a defence force component of 500,000 men. It does not have the troops, therefore, to perform these tasks. It may have the troops to perform the tasks on the waterfront itself, to cross those picket lines, to enter into that period of great bitterness. It may have them. But they will be hating the Opposition every minute as they do that, and their discipline effectively will be subverted as they do it by the feelings that they have towards the Opposition, because the ordinary soldiers will be the ones unloading and the ordinary soldiers drift out of the Army into precisely these sorts of jobs in the transport industry. They do not go into the waterfront industry; but that may well happen under our reforms. They will have that opportunity open to them.

If the Opposition thinks that they will persist in its policies in that regard, it has another think coming. But that in the end is the Opposition's only policy on the waterfront. It abused the Prime Minister for genuine achievement in this area, and it has no policies itself on the waterfront. It had better think that through, because it is going to have to argue it. Simply putting in the troops is not of itself an answer. It can solve some problems, but it is not anything other than a double-edged sword and it is not necessarily the easiest thing to do. But that is the only policy that the Opposition has as far as waterfront reform is concerned.

In the case of the coalminers-and I will just conclude very briefly on that-again the rest of the union movement was supporting what was done by the Government at that time. But the troops did not like it, and all the things that I say apply to this situation applied to that situation as well. The fact is, we are getting waterfront reform. We will get European best practice through this process. We will get those productivity gains-we already have them-in the bag as far as a whole series of these agreements are concerned. They will be of enormous benefit to this country and we have got them the hard way and the only way. The only way these gains are going to be brought about is by solid hard work by governments, not by government with attitude and government with attitude based on the terrible inexperience in industrial matters which the Opposition shows in the sort of high school standard questioning that it delivers against the Prime Minister and other people in this place, somehow thinking that it is making points. It is not, and this is a ridiculous matter of public importance.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cobb Mr M.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have just heard a pathetic speech by the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley), who talks about when the Government brought in the Royal Australian Air Force to kill the pilots strike. It brought in foreign pilots from overseas, for heaven's sake.
—And they are still here.

—And they are still here. They are not even allowed to make announcements over the intercom on the plane because their foreign accents are embarrassing to the passengers. There is no greater indictment of this Government than its failure and inability to reform our waterfront. It is a blot on our national pride, and it is something which this Government should be ashamed of. This area symbolises what is wrong with this country today. The waterfront desperately needs reform. Regrettably, this is an area where the Government has failed abysmally.

SPEECH.PARA: It should be obvious to the Government that Australia is a trading nation. It lies in the Southern Hemisphere, distant from most of its trading partners. It is crucial to our well-being and to the well-being of this nation that we have an efficient waterfront if we are to compete with the rest of the world-a waterfront that is just not equal in productivity to the rest of the world, but a waterfront that is hopefully the best in the world, not the worst in the world.

We have been snowed, of course, by the previous speech, and other speeches and press releases of the Government, saying that it cannot be done, that we must go slowly, that only the Australian Labor Party (ALP) can deliver. If that is the case, how come other countries in short periods of time have pulled their waterfronts into line? We have seen it done in England under Margaret Thatcher, and we have seen it done recently under both Labour and National Party governments in New Zealand. Those countries now have ports comparable to Amsterdam and the Asian ports which achieved this years before. But Australia still lags behind.

One might ask: how can this Government stand by, knowing full well the rorts and featherbedding that goes on, the thuggery and coercion on the waterfront, and the criminal waste and Saddam Hussein-type practices that still exist? How can it stand by and still do so little?

TALK.START.PARA: —They have a go slow attitude.
—Kelty wasn't involved.

—I will tell honourable members why. It is for those reasons which the honourable members have just outlined. There is another reason too that is worth highlighting. I think it is the 60 : 40 rule, where 60 per cent of delegates to Labor Party conferences-where policy is determined-must come from trade union representatives. That is written into the Party's constitution. So we have this conflict of interest where what is best for the ALP is not necessarily best for Australia.
—Not 60 per cent.
—Yes, 60 per cent. One would think that the Government would be talking about getting rid of this totally, but what is it doing? Only yesterday on the front page of the Australian it was stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The ALP is moving towards cutting its traditional trade union domination, with growing party support for an end to the rule that union representatives must make up 60 per cent of delegates to party policymaking conferences.

A senior member of Labor's Right faction, in a paper submitted to the ALP National Secretary, Mr Bob Hogg, on Friday, proposes the party adopt a national principle allowing State branches to reduce union participation to 50 per cent.
Opposition members-Ha, ha!

TALK.START.PARA: —Laughable indeed. It goes on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: But Left sources confirmed the faction would strongly oppose any reduction in union involvement.
So there we are. We are condemned to this nonsense for another 100 years, no doubt, within the Labor Party.

TALK.START.PARA: —A puppet party.

—Indeed. It is not as if the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support (Senator Collins) himself does not know what is going on on the waterfront. He recognised it from day one when he got in, as we just heard from the honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Sharp). Let me refresh the memories of Government members-I think there are three in the chamber now. The headline in the Sunday Territorian of 6 May stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Collins threatens to quit.
And the article following says:

Territory Senator Bob Collins says he will resign as Shipping Minister within 12 months if he cannot achieve significant reform on Australia's troubled waterfront. `If there has not been a significant amount of improvement in the reform process I'll resign after one year in the job,' he said. `I'll quit-promise.'
Asked what he meant by `a significant amount of improvement', he said:
`If after 12 months the award restructuring process is not complete . . .
and these are his words:
. . . and we haven't wrapped up at least one major enterprise agreement, then I'll quit. I'm dead serious.'
He may be dead, but he certainly was not serious. In the Sun-Herald he says:

`If the award restructuring is not finished and at least one significant enterprise agreement negotiated within 12 months, then the Government's three-year productivity targets aren't going to be met'.
The Centralian Advocate of July last states:
Senator Collins had no hesitation saying that unless he can bring about substantial reform in the areas under his direct responsibility in 12 months he will quit.
`I won't need anyone to sack me. I will do it myself'.
The reporter said he so told them in his usual forthright way. I turn to the Age of May last year:
Senator Collins conceded that the reform process was going too slowly at present.

`If there hasn't been the completion of the award restructuring process and if there hasn't been a number of these enterprise agreements put in place, after I've been in this job 12 months, I quit,' he said.

He is still there, of course. I suppose the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) set an example for breaking promises. We have all heard: no child will live in poverty by 1990; there will be no capital gains tax; and all this sort of nonsense. So we perhaps cannot blame the Minister.

Let us look at some examples of what is going on on the waterfront. If one wants to ship cars from Melbourne to New Zealand, it is cheaper to ship them via Hong Kong or fly them from Melbourne to New Zealand than to send them on the trans-Tasman route. Even if one sends them that way, chances are they will have dents in the roofs from waterside workers walking around on top of them. It is absolutely outrageous.

The honourable member for Gilmore highlighted 27 hours work for $40,000 to $45,000 a year. But the Inter-State Commission found that many waterside workers are working only 20 hours a week. There are cases where there are two drivers employed to operate cranes that are designed for one operator only. There are things like nick-off days where they draw straws for having a day off on full pay and so on. These are absolutely outrageous practices that the Government knows full well about, that it has promised to resign on, but it is doing nothing about them. It ought to crawl away in shame at its performance in this area. This Government is unlikely to do anything about it because it cannot understand certain things about the waterfront, or it misrepresents certain things about what is happening there to the Australian people.

We had an outrageous answer by the Prime Minister to a question in Question Time today when he said that things have improved on the waterfront. He is comparing the outrageous practices on the waterfront today with the super-outrageous practices which existed on the waterfront before. Australia is a trading nation. We have to compare ourselves with the rest of the world-not by Labor Party standards.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a bit embarrassing.

—It is embarrassing indeed. We have had the example of New Zealand, which was 30 per cent ahead of us a year ago. But since we have had these wonderful improvements that the Minister and the Prime Minister spoke about, New Zealand today is 60 per cent ahead of us. That shows the nonsense of the Government's whole argument.

SPEECH.PARA: There is another area of misrepresentation. We had the spectacle of the Prime Minister flying back from the Northern Territory, unbuttoning his shirt, showing his hairy chest, leadership, et cetera-trying to keep the Treasurer (Mr Keating) on the front bench and not up at the dispatch box all the time-stitching up yet another deal. But what did the deal involve? More pay rises.

We have just heard from the honourable member for Gilmore that there is another $100 a week, which means the waterfront has the most highly paid group of blue collar workers in Australia. It is money guaranteed up front, yet we still have not seen the colour of any productivity improvements at all. As the honourable member for Gilmore said, this is not enterprise bargaining; this is enterprise bullying.

If Tina Turner was promoting this, she would be up there kicking her legs in the air and saying, `Simply the worst'. That is Australia's waterfront today. That is what we have had to put up with under this Government. The Government should abolish compulsory unionism; it should get rid of security of tenure; it should corporatise, if not privatise, the ports; it should allow full and free competition. This is supposed to be a democratic, free country. Until it does something about that, until we get proper things in process, we will continue to have this inefficient system operating in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The greatest compliment I can pay the honourable member for Parkes (Mr Cobb), who has just resumed his seat, is to say that it is a pity for the National Party that the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Anderson) did not participate in this debate. At least we would have had a much more discerning, sensible and relevant contribution.

SPEECH.PARA: The waterfront arrangements that we have heard about from the last three speakers were created by National Party Ministers. It is rather significant that this afternoon we have had two contributors from the National Party-the honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Sharp) and the honourable member for Parkes-pursuing virtually vintage Peter Nixon, the former National Party Minister for Transport and former member for Gippsland.

The history of the existing arrangements shows that they were all brought into being under National Party Ministers-the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair), the former member for Gippsland, and the former member for Gwydir. The former member for Gwydir was probably a more constructive Minister in his way than the present member for Gwydir is as a member. But it is interesting that this afternoon the two previous speakers from the National Party have yet again, after all these years, done their constituencies a great disservice. They have yet to understand what the waterfront is about; they have yet to understand the background to the practices and the operations that occur there; they have yet to develop sensible solutions; and they have yet to come forward with a program for the implementation of those solutions. Rather, they choose to blackguard people working on the waterfront, be they tallyclerks, wharf labourers or crane drivers-whatever role they are performing-for working in a system that former National Party Ministers created.

I have heard reference to idle time-27 hours a week, 20 hours a week. If honourable members opposite hunt around Australian ports they will find that, as a result of their legislation and arrangements, there are even less actual working times. They designed the system called idle time in which people were paid for being available for work. Whether or not work was done depended on what happened at the port and whether there were ships to be worked. That is their system and arrangements. They and their industry and terminal operators saw those operations and arrangements as appropriate to the circumstances at the time. It took this Government to recognise that those arrangements were not appropriate to today's circumstances and that they had to be changed. The National Party has been concealing its responsibility for the inefficiencies of the waterfront and trying to divert attention to other people and to this Government by a personal attack on good Australians carrying out the job under arrangements set for them.

The Opposition refers to Thatcher changes in the United Kingdom. Let us look at them. It is a nice throwaway line. The port that is generally referred to by the Opposition is Felixstowe. That port was never in the national dockside labour scheme. It developed as a privately owned container port, designated as the Felixstowe Dock and Railway Co. and owned by the P &O group since 1987. That port alone handled 1,278,000 twenty equivalent units (TEUs) in 1988. It is the sixteenth largest container port in the world. That terminal alone handles almost as many as all of the terminals within Australia. The Opposition compares that port with Australia where we have been trying to get like performances in productivity. This is the idiocy, the nonsense and the dishonesty of the National Party.

Let us look at the size of Australian ports and how many containers are handled by them. Felixstowe pays a bonus wage to its employees. It has always paid a higher wage than the national dockside labour scheme, so it has been outside comparison with the Australian scheme. It handled 1.3 million TEUs in 1988. In Australia in 1988-89, Melbourne handled 710,000 TEUs; Sydney, 631,000; Burnie, 85,000; Brisbane, 172,000; Fremantle, 132,000; and-a great performer!-Adelaide, 34,450. Does the Opposition seriously suggest that, with the spread of capital equipment across all of those ports and such small numbers being handled, we are going to get the same productivity and economies of scale and utilisation of equipment that are found in Felixstowe?

If we want to look somewhere else, let us look at Los Angeles. That port alone handled 1.7 million TEUs in one year. Singapore handled 3.5 million; Hong Kong, 2.3 million back in 1985; Yokohama, 1.3 million in 1985. Does the Opposition seriously suggest that we are going to achieve the same economies of scale and utilisation rates here in this spread of little ports as is being achieved in those very large single ports around the world? The Opposition knows it cannot. It is a totally dishonest argument and a grave disservice to the people it represents.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the turnaround times?
—Whatever measure that the Opposition wants to use. Analyse them one by one.
—Are you proud of what is happening now?

—I am recognising the realities and the need for improvement. We are undertaking that improvement. We are not presenting a dishonest case to the people we represent, as those opposite have been doing. They have been concealing the facts that the waterfront industry situation is theirs. They deregulated the waterfront in 1977 to create greater competition and efficiency. They lied to the people and failed the people. They failed their own export industry and importers.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us turn to what the waterfront is about. It is a reactor. It does not make anything. It does not build anything. It does not manufacture anything. It provides a service. People bring things to the waterfront by sea and take them away on land, and vice versa. The timetables are very much determined by those who use the waterfront, whether by sea or by land. It is not done by the waterfront; it reacts. What do we find? We have exporters turning up at the waterfront after the deadline for the ship has closed, wanting to get boxes or bags on the vessel. Why were they not there on time? Usually they have a minimum seven days notice, and often 10 days. Why did the cargoes not come in at an even pace over those seven or 10 days? Explain that to the exporters. Explain to them why 90 per cent of the trucks that go onto the waterfront are empty and come out full or go in full and come out empty. Why are exporters not getting a decent deal on transport service rates to and from the waterfront?

Why is it that when goods come onto the waterfront they sit there waiting to be taken away? The first three days on the waterfront is free when goods come off the ship. Fifteen per cent go out on the first day, 20 per cent the second day, and there is a hell of a rush on the third day. Why? When that rush comes it generates a peak. It generates congestion. Who gets the blame? The wharfie. The exporters say, `Everybody is tucked in behind the big shed-blame them. We did not get our goods to the wharf on time. We did not check with our agents to see whether we could get a better rate by having the goods there a few days earlier. As importers we did not check whether we could get a dedicated time for our ship's arrival so that we could get an even spread of ships arriving at the terminal, thus reducing the peaks and the congestion. None of those things have been done'.

Those opposite are just so dishonest. I say to the honourable member for Gilmore: `You are an intelligent man; you have ability. For God's sake, if you want to make a contribution to improving transport efficiency in this country, forget the personal trivia you went on with before, forget the misrepresentation, and concentrate on the real issues of educating exporters and importers'. Those opposite are living in Rip Van Winkle land. They have some childlike and ignorant belief that, once a box arrives on the wharf, somehow-miraculously-it will get to them. Somebody will care for it-maybe God, maybe heaven, who knows? Once their box is picked from the factory, miraculously it will get to its destination. They do not check the best rate.

So much needs to be done by exporters and waterfront users themselves. The waterfront has problems. Those problems are being addressed expeditiously by this Government. Waterfront users have a greater potential for improvement and efficiency but they are not addressing it. If there is one area alone in which the Opposition, when in government, excelled in port productivity it was the growth of bottom of the harbour tax rorts. That is the only area of port productivity that those opposite did any good in.
