PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Beazley, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
Introduction

The Telecommunications Bill 1991 is the first in a package that I am introducing today affecting the telecommunications industry. Before addressing the detail of the legislation it is useful to put these reforms in context. The package gives effect to the reform package which the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) announced to this House on 8 November last year. These telecommunications reforms are a central plank of the Hawke Government's fourth term commitment to micro- economic reform. In introducing network competition into this industry, we will not just be improving the efficiency of a major domestic industry; we will also be aiming to lift dramatically the performance of a key infrastructure industry.

All three of the current carriers-Telecom Australia, OTC Ltd and Aussat Pty Ltd-have a good technical record but have not been as responsive to customers, as innovative, or as export-oriented as they might have been. The carriers themselves recognise that they can do much better in terms of quality of service, productivity and price of services.

As long as the present carriers have a monopoly on the public switched trunk network, there is only modest pressure on them to minimise costs and to develop new products and markets. Telecom's and OTC's profitability has been largely based on historical accounting conventions and regulated monopoly pricing. Competition across the network will force the merged entity to become more responsive to customers' needs, to reduce costs and to find better ways of providing existing services.

These reforms, though, go beyond the scope of structural reform, important though that is. The reason for the Government's focus on this industry is that we realise the critical long term importance for Australia of getting the regulatory framework for this industry right. First, telecommunications now provides a vital part of the infrastructure for all business operations, be they domestic or international. Having access to internationally competitive telecommunications services is therefore essential if our firms are to be able to meet their opposition in the marketplace. Second, with the globalisation of the world economy, and the explosion in information technology, it has become increasingly obvious that telecommunications will be one of the key global industries of the next century in its own right.

New telecommunications services are revolutionising the way people do business. Mobile communications are growing at a phenomenal rate as are the range of value-added telecommunications services. The introduction of intelligent network services is ushering in a whole new range of sophisticated services for consumers. The future for telecommunications companies lies in integrating information technologies and telecommunications networks to connect people and information around the world. Remaining a simple provider of a telephone network is no longer an option for telecommunications companies that wish to survive, let alone prosper. As a result, governments worldwide are giving reform of the telecommunications sector a high priority. In turn, the deregulation of telecommunications markets in Western countries is advancing the trend towards globalisation of the industry.

The opportunities in this industry are enormous. The Asia-Pacific region is now experiencing a staggering increase in demand for telecommunications. Some estimates of this growth range as high as $130 billion in the next five years. Half of the world market in fibre optic cables, worth about $13 billion during the 1990s, will be laid in North and South Asia.

Australia has an excellent opportunity to exploit the anticipated growth in the region. We have the skills to design, plan, source, construct, operate and maintain telephone networks. Both Telecom and OTC have been successful in winning lucrative export contracts. It is important that we now build on this early success.

The next century's telecommunications will not only be global and dynamic; they will also be very competitive. Many of the world's major economies, including those of Japan and the United States of America, have already broken up their telecommunications monopolies and introduced competition. The Government has carefully observed the experience in those countries and is convinced that its reform package does the job better.

While the Government's strategy for the industry, then, aims at producing important efficiency gains for Australia in the short term, the `main game' is positioning Australia's telecommunications industry to be globally competitive in the next century. Certainly, there will be immediate short term benefits for the economy as a whole and for consumers from these reforms. However their real impact will be felt in a decade or so.
The Government's strategy for achieving this has two basic, closely related features-
* to introduce genuine and sustainable network competition for the benefit of the wider Australian economy; and.
* to create a world class telecommunications company that has the ability and ethos to compete vigorously in what will be a key industry in a very competitive global environment.

A third important element of the Government's strategy that has yet to be finalised is the industry development arrangements that are to apply to the carriers. I am not in a position to give the precise details of these arrangements yet, as their final resolution is linked to the sale of Aussat.

One of the key selection criteria for the Aussat sale is that the bidders submit network development proposals that demonstrate how they propose to assist the development of Australian industry. There are two reasons for the importance which the Government places on these industry development proposals.

First, one of the main reasons for fundamentally restructuring the industry now is that we intend Australia to become a significant international telecommunications centre. To exploit fully the potential embodied in the other elements of the Government's reforms, it is essential that the carriers be able to turn to a dynamic local industry, with a research and development ethos that looks beyond Australia's boundaries, for necessary support. A local industry that is innovative, forward-looking and has a commitment to excellence will also be necessary if we are to take full advantage of the opportunities that telecommunications will present in the next century.

Secondly, we recognise that Telecom's policies to date have contributed in no small measure to the development of a significant electronics industry in Australia and a research and development base. It is important that we build on this. For these reasons, the Government will be examining the bidders' industry plans on this matter closely, with a view to formulating an appropriate industry development plan for inclusion in carriers' licence conditions.

In developing its framework for reform, the Government has remained mindful of the social importance of telecommunications to Australian society. The Prime Minister has already guaranteed that no ordinary consumer of the telephone system will be disadvantaged as a result of the introduction of competition. This assurance can be given for two main reasons.

First, the Government will preserve the merged Telecom-OTC in full public ownership. This enables the Government, in its capacity as shareholder as well as regulator, to ensure that the dominant network provider will continue to meet the Government's social objectives.

Second, the price cap arrangements for Telecom-OTC in the Australian and Overseas Telecommunications Corporation Bill (AOTC Bill) 1991, in combination with the new entity's universal service obligation in the Telecommunications Bill, will ensure that the price benefits from competition will be distributed among consumers in an equitable way.

In fact, as I mentioned earlier, competition is likely to produce significant gains for all consumers. The overwhelming evidence from Western nations that have introduced network competition is that the real price of telecommunications services to business and household consumers has fallen and the quality of service has improved.

The package of Bills that the Government is introducing today is designed to maximise the benefits for Australia from its telecommunications industry. It will create a robust, globally competitive industry which is capable of seeing Australia into the next century. At the same time it will deliver improved services at lower prices to both the wider economy and ordinary householders.

The Telecommunications Bill 1991 replaces the Telecommunications Act 1989, which is repealed by the Telecommunications (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Bill 1991. As such, the new Telecommunications Bill will provide the general regulatory framework for the provision of telecommunications facilities and services in Australia. Certain specific regulatory matters relating to pricing arrangements that will apply only to the merged Telecom-OTC are dealt with under the AOTC Bill.

During the process of developing the Bill, an extensive process of public consultation has been undertaken. This has involved the circulation of an exposure draft of the legislation for public comment and consultation with key affected community groups. The Bill gives effect to the Government's November 1990 decisions in the context of a process which has taken into account legitimate concerns of the main groups with an interest in these matters.

I might say at this stage that I very much thank the honourable member for Chifley (Mr Price), who has entered the chamber. The honourable member was chairman of our working group and also chairman of my ministerial advisory committee. I thank the members of that group and the advisory committee, which was very broadly based, for the advice which they have given us on these matters. Of course, the Bill has been available more generally than to just those groups, and a great number of people have had an opportunity to have a chop at it and make suggestions.

I indicated at the time that the Government viewed the exposure drafts without any sort of extremity of personal defensiveness, and we have made substantial adjustments on the basis of what both of those groups and some of the users have referred to, such as the private network operators-like Australian Associated Press-which would be bidders for the second carrier. All sorts of people have had an influence on our processes. Above all, I thank those sections of the Department that have worked on this. They have done an extraordinary job as this is an extraordinarily difficult Bill.
General Principles
In policy terms, this Bill essentially does eight things:
1. it provides a framework for fostering genuine and sustainable network competition;
2. it provides a framework for fostering competition among all service providers, whether carriers or not, consistent with fostering sustainable network competition;

3. it ensures that certain specific social objectives in telecommunications-in particular delivery of the universal service obligation and continued access by residential consumers to the option of untimed local calls-will continue to be met, but on a more secure legislative basis, and in a more efficient and transparent manner;
4. it provides for a licensing scheme for telecommunications carriers;
5. it allows, with minimum attendant bureaucracy, for greater public input into Austel processes, commensurate with Austel's enhanced regulatory role and powers;

6. it gives the carriers, on an equal footing, certain exclusive rights and powers. These include rights to install certain types of telecommunications facilities; and certain powers in relation to land and immunity from laws;
7. it provides an effective and appropriate enforcement regime; and

8. it re-enacts, with some additions and modifications, parts 5 to 8 of the 1989 Act relating to technical regulation, Austel investigations and Austel's constitution. These provisions have generally worked well.
My following comments address the key features of the Bill against this framework.
Network Competition
The central feature of the Bill is the framework it provides for the introduction of genuine and sustainable network competition in the shortest time possible. It does this in three ways:
(i) Licensing

In contrast with the 1989 Act, the Bill allows for network competition by giving the Minister the power to license Australian trading corporations as general carriers. A general carrier will have complete freedom to use whatever technology that carrier chooses to deliver the full range of telecommunications services-other than public mobile services, unless it also holds a public mobile licence. The general carriers, which are recognised in the objects of the Bill to be the primary providers of Australia's telecommunications networks and the primary providers of Australia's telecommunications services, will also have certain exclusive rights and powers. I shall discuss these rights and powers later. The Bill provides a similar licensing regime for public mobile carriers with respect to the primary supply of public mobile telecommunications services.

The Bill gives the Minister a wide discretion as to the grant of licences. As announced by the Prime Minister, the Government has taken the view that the goal of genuine and sustainable network competition is best served through licensing a single network competitor to the merged Telecom OTC prior to full competition in 1997. The chief reason for this is that the Government has taken the view that the creation of one strong competitor is the best way of achieving genuine and sustainable network competition quickly in a market the size of Australia's. The aim is to ensure that by 1997 there is a significant, recognised network competitor to Telecom-OTC. Accordingly, on commencement of the Bill, the Government will be licensing only one competitor to Telecom-OTC.

The Bill therefore anticipates, but does not attempt to prescribe, the post-1997 environment. As already announced, this will be the subject of a review by the Government prior to 30 June 1997. In accordance with the recommendations in Austel's report on public mobile telecommunications services, the Government intends to issue only three public mobile carrier licences before 1995.
(ii) Access and interconnection

The second main feature of the Bill which is intended to promote network competition is the inter-carrier access arrangements in part 8. Overseas experience, particularly in the United States and the United Kingdom, has shown that the most important element in introducing genuine and sustainable network competition in the long run where there is an established telecommunications monopoly is to have appropriate interconnection and access arrangements between the carriers. It is widely acknowledged internationally that the arrangements proposed in the Government's decisions of November 1990 will be the most rational, pro-competitive and equitable interconnection arrangements that have been introduced anywhere in the world. The framework provided by part 8 enables those decisions to be implemented while allowing flexibility for dealing with changing market circumstances.

The short term aim of the arrangements is to assist the second carrier in overcoming the formidable advantages associated with Telecom-OTC's control over the customer base, infrastructure and access to information so that the second carrier will be able to compete from as level a playing field as possible. The longer term aim is to create the basis for an open network framework for the provision of telecommunications services.

Part 8 creates two broad categories of access rights. The first is the basic right of any carrier to interconnect its network to that of any other carrier, and to have that other carrier carry and complete calls on its behalf. This right is fully mutual between the carriers and also applies between the general and public mobile carriers. The second, or supplementary, class of rights covers matters relating to supplementary services affecting a carrier's control over the customer base. This is capable of being made carrier specific and in practice will apply only to the provision of supplementary services by Telecom-OTC while it remains the dominant carrier.

The part also allows for disallowable ministerial determinations on special pricing arrangements that are to apply between the carriers. This power will be used to set out the details that implement the general principle that the second carrier should have access to Telecom-OTC's facilities and supplementary services at directly attributable incremental cost following Austel's report to the Government on this issue in June.

These rights will be given practical effect by giving a carrier the right to ask Austel to arbitrate on a dispute that it has with another carrier concerning access and interconnection matters. The Bill provides for extensive procedures governing the way in which such arbitrations are to be conducted, although the general principle is that they are to be conducted in a way that is fair, just, informal, economical and quick. An arbitration will generally be conducted in private. However there is provision for Austel to conduct a public inquiry on a particular issue where Austel considers that this will have a significant and direct impact on consumers, and that the inquiry will not significantly delay the arbitration.

Carriers will, in effect, be required to register all access agreements with Austel. These agreements will be public, to the extent that normal commercial confidentiality principles permit. So as to ensure that all agreements actually promote the long term interests of consumers of telecommunications services, Austel will have the ability to refuse to register an access agreement where in Austel's opinion it does not further the objects of part 8.
(iii) New Austel functions

The third way in which network competition will be enhanced is by giving Austel a charter with a number of pro-competitive functions. The most important of these new functions is given in clause 37 which charges Austel with the function of promoting competition within the regulatory framework established by the Act. In relation to network competition, Austel has the role of promoting competition between the carriers; of protecting carriers from the misuse of market power by other carriers; and of arbitrating disputes between the carriers. Austel is, therefore, being given a clear mandate to create the conditions necessary for genuine and sustainable network competition between the carriers and is being authorised to take appropriate action to ensure that this occurs.

Austel is also being given a number of other new powers and functions which are related to the promotion of competition. The most important of these is Austel's powers in relation to accounting and charging procedures in division 5 of part 5. This requires Austel to draw up a chart of accounts and a cost allocation manual. The primary function of these documents will be to ensure full accounting separation of those areas of a carrier's activities that do not face strong competition. Austel will be able to decide on the extent to which a carrier should be made subject to the accounting separation regime. This is because it is likely that for the first few years of its operations the second network carrier will face strong competition from Telecom-OTC in all of its main business activities. There may, however, be reason to apply a degree of accounting separation to the second carrier when the third mobile operator commences operations in 1993.

Clause 39 of the Bill gives Austel the function of managing numbering. Austel will be required to establish a numbering plan for telecommunications services provided across carrier networks, consulting, where appropriate, with the Standards Association of Australia which also has a role in relation to certain services. In establishing the plan, Austel is required to have regard to its other relevant functions which would include promoting competition and protecting consumers.

A further Austel function given by clauses 40 and 399 will be that of reporting annually to the Minister on the operation of competitive safeguards and carrier performance. As the Minister is required to table the report in Parliament this will ensure that the public is aware of how the competitive safeguards regime is working out in practice. It also ensures that Austel maintains an appropriate level of interest in competition and carrier performance. The fact that this reporting obligation, which also has a consumer protection dimension which I will discuss later, has the status of an Austel function, indicates the importance which is placed on it.
Service Provider Competition

While the main long term goal of the new regulatory framework lies in fostering network competition, the Government has also moved to foster competition from other service providers, in a manner consistent with that primary goal. The chief reasons for this are to encourage innovation and diversity in the provision of telecommunications services and to give the fullest possible degree of flexibility to consumers in the way in which they use telecommunications services derived from carriers. The Bill has a number of features for achieving this end.
(i) Resale

One of the key differences between this Bill and the 1989 Act, both in policy and conceptual terms, has flowed from the Government's decision to remove all restrictions on resale of domestic and international telecommunications capacity currently contained in the Telecommunications Act 1989.

Under the 1989 Act, only the carriers are permitted to provide so-called reserved services. Even where a person obtains a basic service from a carrier, that person cannot use the basic service to supply another service unless that service can be classified as a value added service.

The Government's resale decision was intended to remove that artificial distinction, and allows for much more efficient use of capacity within private networks. This is a very significant liberalisation of existing arrangements and the approach of the Bill to resale is among the most liberal, if not the most liberal, in the world.

The decision to allow resale is given effect by ensuring that the Bill does not apply any restrictions on the supply of services other than those contained in an Austel class licence issued under part 10 of the Bill. These restrictions are primarily intended to deal with:
(a) technical and operational matters, so as to ensure the technical integrity and efficiency of public telecommunications networks is maintained and relevant international standards are met;

(b) the provision of international services, to prevent the misuse of market power by foreign carriers through resale; and to ensure that the agreements that carriers enter into with international cabling consortia cannot be used to achieve effective bypass of the carriers; and

(c) services provided over radiocommunications facilities that are connected to a carrier's network and that have been privately installed. The reason for this restriction is that the Bill, again in contrast to existing arrangements, allows complete freedom for anyone to install radiocommunications facilities and otherwise use radiocommunications services. In the absence of a safety net there is a danger that such facilities might be used to erode significantly the practical value of the carriers' reserved rights.
(ii) Unbundling of basic carriage services

The second main feature of the Bill designed to promote competition from service providers is the approach in division 2 of part 9 towards the controlled unbundling of basic carriage services. BCS is one of the central concepts in the Bill, so I will take some time to explain its functions.

The decision to allow full resale has essentially been implemented by framing the carriers' reservations-apart from public mobile services and satellite services-in facilities terms, and imposing no restrictions on the persons who may provide services over those facilities. This fulfils the twin objectives of giving the carriers' licences practical value, while allowing resale as long as the carriers are allowed genuine control over their facilities and are able to exploit the economies of scale and scope inherent in them, at least to provide basic connectivity and carriage services. Clause 237 underlines the carriers' prerogatives in this regard by giving them the ability to refuse to supply particular BCSs that are not included in the carrier's BCS tariff.

The BCS concept is essentially a functional description, from the point of view of the service as delivered to the consumer, of basic connectivity and carriage services, on which all commercial telecommunications services are necessarily built. The Bill calls all services that are not BCSs, higher level services (HLS). The conceptual distinction in the Bill, and the basic reasons for it, reflect the thinking proposed by Austel in its report to me on resale of 14 December 1990.

This ability of a carrier to refuse to supply BCSs, while necessary to maintain the practical value of the carrier's rights and thereby to promote network competition, nevertheless has the potential to have significant anticompetitive consequences in markets for other telecommunications services. To address this, the Bill has a procedure under which Austel, on its own initiative or on application, can direct a dominant carrier to supply a particular BCS. This unbundling regime has two main purposes.

First, it will prevent a dominant carrier that is supplying a BCS from precipitately withdrawing that service where this will have significant consequences for existing users of that service. Second, it will allow for a structured process for unbundling of BCSs. Unbundling in this context means requiring a carrier to make available lower level BCSs that are necessary to provide other telecommunications services. This process will promote competition by allowing service providers to use these building blocks to construct other telecommunications services from an equal base.

It is, however, important that such unbundling of BCSs actually benefits the long term interests of consumers by taking proper account of what is technically practicable, and of the need to promote genuine and sustainable network competition between the carriers by ensuring that their rights have practical value. Once a service has been unbundled in this way, a directed carrier will have to supply that service on reasonable terms, and will be required to supply the service to itself on the same terms as to all other service providers. This requirement applies automatically-but in a more limited way-to any BCSs that a carrier itself is using to supply an HLS.
(iii) Safeguards for service providers

The third main way in which the Bill fosters service competition from service providers is by giving them, along with other consumers of telecommunications services, a number of targeted safeguards against particular abuses of market power by carriers. The first safeguard is that a carrier that is in a position to dominate a market for a telecommunications service will not be able to discriminate between customers in that market unless that discrimination can be justified on a cost basis. Furthermore, carriers in general will not be permitted to discriminate against a person for the reason that the person is or wants to be a service provider.

The second safeguard is that carriers will be required to tariff their BCSs, and will have incentives to tariff their HLSs. (Extension of time granted) This will make it easier for consumers to obtain information about competing carrier services and in combination with the discrimination provisions, will provide incentives for a dominant carrier to keep its charges down. A carrier that is in a position to dominate a market for a BCS will be required to charge strictly in accordance with its tariff. A non-dominant carrier will be able to charge below its tariff but not above it. The existing carriers will have six months in which to tariff all their existing services following commencement of the Act.
The third safeguard is that the carriers are under an obligation to connect a service provider unless another carrier is supplying the connection service.
Social Objectives

While the main thrust of the Bill is directed towards introducing a more competitive framework for supplying telecommunications services as the best means of meeting consumers' interests in the long term, the reforms also aim to improve the regulatory arrangements for delivering certain key objectives.
(i) The Universal Service Obligation
The most important of these is Telecom's universal service obligation (USO). In my statement of November 1990 I gave the commitment, on behalf of the Government, that:
* community service obligations (CSOs) would be maintained, in particular to rural and regional areas, to pensioners and to people with disabilities;
* Telecom-OTC would be required to continue to provide and maintain its basic telephone services to residential and business customers throughout Australia; and

* the management and funding of community service obligations would be considered by an interdepartmental committee chaired by my Department, and that the IDC, in preparing its report, would have regard to the notation to the Australian Labor Party policy that the cost for the competitor to interconnect into Telecom-OTC's network should underpin Telecom-OTC's community service obligations on a pro rata basis.

After full consideration of the IDC's report, the Government decided that the most appropriate and least administratively complex way of giving effect to its aims in the continued funding and delivery of universal telephone service would be:
* to obligate Telecom-OTC to continue to provide a standard telephone service between places in Australia, including pay phones; and

* to require the second carrier to pay Telecom-OTC a fee which covers an equitable share of Telecom-OTC's costs of fulfilling its universal service obligation with a payment to be in direct proportion to minutes of interconnect time between each carrier's trunk international network and all local access networks.

Part 13 of the Bill gives effect to these decisions. This empowers the Minister to declare a carrier to be the universal service carrier for Australia. Telecom-OTC will be designated as this carrier. Clause 292 makes it a `prescribed carrier obligation' of the universal service carrier's licence to fulfil the USO. The USO has two strands:
* the obligation to supply the standard telephone service to people in Australia; and

* to supply pay phones in a way that ensures that they are reasonably accessible to all people in Australia on an equitable basis. This can be backed up by a ministerial determination that pay phones must be installed in specified places.

This has the effect of placing the USO on a more secure legislative basis than under current arrangements, where their management and delivery are largely at Telecom's discretion. This is because any person may complain to Austel about a possible breach of this licence condition. If Austel finds that the carrier has unreasonably failed to fulfil its USO, Austel must direct the carrier to fulfil it.

The net costs incurred in fulfilling the universal service obligation are to be calculated by participating carriers using a long term avoidability methodology. These are the costs that will be used by Austel, along with the number of minutes of interconnect time, to determine the pro rata contribution of all participating carriers in the levy. For practical purposes, interconnect time is to be measured as the number of minutes of timed traffic interconnected by a carrier.

The Government decided in December 1989 that an avoidability methodology should be used in future to determine the costs incurred by Telecom in delivering its universal service obligation. Accordingly, this Bill enshrines in legislation the requirement that a universal service carrier-in this case, Telecom-OTC-calculate its net costs using a long term avoidable cost approach. This will require Telecom-OTC, in calculating its USO costs in a particular area, only to take into account the justifiable net costs it thinks it would not have incurred had the services not been provided to that area.

The arrangements, as proposed, give Austel the responsibility for auditing the net costs and timed traffic figures provided by the carriers. However, with the Government's dual aim in mind of, on the one hand, delivering the universal service obligation to the highest standard and at the least cost possible and, on the other, of making the arrangements as open and transparent as possible, the Bill also requires Austel to make available to the public, and to participating carriers, information about the basis and methods of assessment in as much detail as it thinks appropriate, bearing in mind the need to protect a carrier's commercial or other interests.
(ii) Untimed local calls
Clauses 72 and 73 make it a licence condition of all general carriers that they offer residential customers continued access to untimed local calls as a payment option.
(iii) Quality of Service

Austel is to be given the new consumer protection function of developing indicative quality of service, or performance standards relating to the standard telephone service; services ancillary to the standard telephone services, such as directory assistance; and any other services Austel considers appropriate. While these standards will not be binding on a carrier-unless they were included in licence conditions-Austel will gather data and will use these standards as a key test of carrier performance for the purposes of its annual report to the Minister and to Parliament on carrier performance.
Licensing

One of the important features of the new Bill is that it establishes a licensing regime for carriers with broad discretions for the Minister to impose and vary licence conditions. However, it is important to note that a number of key licence conditions, in particular those relating to the USO and untimed local calls, have been included in the Bill and therefore will not be capable of change, except by an Act of Parliament.
Other matters likely to be dealt with in licence conditions are listed in subclause 63(4). They include:
* the term of a licence;
* industry development;
* foreign ownership or control;
* supplementary access rights-for interconnection purposes;
* consumer inquiry and complaints procedures-such as a requirement that a carrier develop a code of practice for handling such inquiries and complaints;
* compliance with technical standards;
* law enforcement issues; and
* geographical limitations on a licensee's scope of action.

It is also intended that there will be licence obligations on Aussat relating to remote commercial television services, the Australian Broadcasting Corporation's homestead and community broadcasting satellite service, and defence and aviation requirements.

A number of issues on this list, which is not exhaustive, are clearly going to require further detailed work. Others will be issues to be negotiated during the sale process for Aussat and will be the subject of a commercial contract.

The Government recognises that there will be many occasions where a public process would be desirable to assist in clarifying the issues involved with important licence conditions. Clause 69 effectively encourages a Minister to request Austel to conduct a public inquiry before the Minister varies an important licence condition.

The Government also recognises that carriers have a legitimate interest in regulatory stability in order that they can make sensible investment decisions. To this end, clause 68 requires a Minister to consult with a carrier before varying a licence condition. Clause 70 allows a Minister to enter into an agreement with the carrier about the way in which the Minister will exercise a particular licensing power. At the end of the day, though, it is not appropriate to unduly fetter the Minister's ability to impose or vary licence conditions as there may be important issues of public policy at stake.
Public Processes
In general the Bill adopts a more open approach to policy formulation than the 1989 Act. The following measures have been adopted, in addition to those in the 1989 Act, to achieve this:

(a) A new part 14 of the Bill has been added to give Austel a simple and straightforward public inquiry process. This is largely intended to codify Austel's existing practices, although some new features of the Bill-for example, unbundling of BCSs-will depend on a public inquiry.

(b) Austel will be required to keep a simple and publicly accessible register of complaints and investigations under part 15 of the Act. This will also assist Austel in meeting its annual reporting obligations.
(c) Austel will be required to keep a register of access agreements between the carriers.

(d) Carriers will be required to keep a publicly available schedule of BCS tariffs and to file these with Austel. They will have substantial incentives to include their standard terms and conditions in these tariffs.
Carriers' Exclusive Rights, Powers and Immunities
Under the Bill the carriers' exclusive rights are essentially based on a facilities reservation only, rather than a services and facilities reservation as in the 1989 Act.

The general carriers will have the exclusive right to install line links between distinct places. A line link essentially is any combination of connected wires or cables that is used or intended for use in carrying electromagnetic energy. A distinct place will be:
* any freehold or leasehold title; or

* any combination of adjoining freehold or leasehold titles that are occupied or principally used by the same person; or that are the subject of a ministerial determination, which is subject to certain limitations.

Division 2 of part 2 makes it clear that the network termination point, or network boundary, for a line link in a distinct place will be the main distribution frame or telephone socket as appropriate. The regulations will allow this to be changed both to take account of changing technology and to give effect to the Government's decision that from 1 July 1993 the network boundary will be the property boundary.

The general carriers will also have the exclusive right to be the primary suppliers of services that use satellite facilities. I say `primary supplier' because, of course, resale of such services will be permitted. Public mobile carriers will have exclusive rights to supply public mobile telecommunications services. The formulation of the reservations based on these concepts remedies a range of problems under the existing Act and allows for an appropriate level of flexibility.
The exceptions to the carriers' reservations remain broadly as they are under the 1989 Act with the following exceptions:
(a) the defence forces and the Civil Aviation Authority have been given special purpose exceptions to the carriers' reservations;
(b) a person who has an exception to a carrier's reservation will now be able to supply a service to a carrier or dispose of his or her facilities to a carrier;

(c) the exception granted to broadcasters has been widened to allow broadcasters to supply programs to each other by means of their own exempted line links and to use those line links in relation to the supply of ancillary communications services;

(d) the Government's international private satellite earth station policy has been formalised as an exception to the carriers' satellite reservation. Any person will be able to obtain an international satellite service from any satellite operator, whether or not a carrier. For the purposes of resale, these services will be treated in a manner that is directly analogous to other interconnected radcom services-that is, they will be subject to use restrictions under Austel's services class licence;

(e) Austel will be able to issue authorisations under ministerial direction, which is subject to certain constraints, for persons other than carriers to install exempted classes of line links or use satellite services.

The existing land access powers of Telecom under part 8 of the Australian Telecommunications Corporation Act 1989 will be extended to the general carriers, with compensation agreed or assessed with a right of appeal to a State or Federal court. This is considered essential to carrier activities and to allow the second carrier to roll out its network. Telecom's pre-existing immunity from suit is removed. Any exclusion or limitation of tort liability becomes a matter of normal contractual principles and negotiation. Austel is empowered to determine appropriate ceilings in respect of tort liability.

Telecom's exemption from State and Territory laws has been replaced by a more focused and balanced regime. Essentially, the regulations will be able to specify that certain network related activities are exempt from State and Territory laws, and a carrier will be able to engage in those activities, despite any State or Territory law. This will be balanced by a national code of practice for the carriers, to be discussed with the States and Territories, which will impose parallel obligations on the carriers to the extent that this is warranted. However, a carrier will not be subject to any State or Territory laws that discriminate against the carriers.
Enforcement

The Bill contains new enforcement mechanisms that reflect the changed nature of the regulatory environment. Essentially, the chief sanction against a carrier is based on Austel's ability to direct a carrier. The sanction for a carrier failing to comply with an Austel direction is enforced by Austel having the ability to take the carrier to court for a civil pecuniary penalty of up to $5m, an injunction or a declaration.

Austel enforces licence conditions in a similar way-first, by investigating to satisfy itself that a breach has occurred, then issuing a direction to the carrier to rectify the breach. It is only if the carrier does not rectify the breach that Austel can go to court. The Minister also has the power to enforce licence conditions by taking a carrier directly to court-the same penalties apply-without the need for an investigation. However, this is intended to be a reserve power, and it is not envisaged that the Minister would normally enforce licence conditions.

Austel has also been given certain powers of entry and seizure in relation to its technical regulation functions. The reason for this is that Austel's practical ability to enforce its technical regulation powers are, under the 1989 Act, very limited. These powers are necessary to give meaning to Austel's function in this area.
Re-enactment of Existing Parts

Essentially, parts 5 to 8 of the 1989 Act relating to technical regulation, Austel investigations, Austel's constitution, and miscellaneous matters have been re-enacted. The following changes are worth noting, however.

With technical regulation, Austel has been given the power, at ministerial direction, to formulate network standards. It is a condition of a carrier's licence that the carrier comply with any such standards.

Austel has also been given the power, at its own initiative, on application or on ministerial direction, to exempt certain types of equipment and customer cabling from the scope of technical regulation requirements where such equipment does not have the ability to affect the integrity or efficiency of a carrier's network.

When the Bill comes into force I intend to issue a direction to Austel under relevant provisions to exempt computing equipment and equipment in broadcasters' studios that are beyond an appropriate line isolating device.

In relation to Austel's constitution, there are some minor changes relating to Austel membership and Austel finances. In relation to membership, the changes are intended to clarify the status of associate members. The new provisions relating to Austel finances are standard provisions relating to the financial arrangements for statutory authorities.
Other Issues

There are two other features of the Bill that deserve comment.The first relates to the Minister's general powers of direction to Austel under clauses 49 and 50 of the Bill. These powers of direction re-enact sections 28 and 29 of the 1989 Act essentially without change. These powers of direction were somewhat controversial at the time of passage of the 1989 Act, however their use has attracted no criticism subsequently. Section 28 has been used to give effect to the industry development arrangements for customer equipment. Section 29 has been used to direct Austel to undertake a number of studies and reports. These provisions play an important function in ensuring that Austel remains accountable and takes account of the full range of policy perspectives.

Another feature worthy of note is the international code of practice in division 4 of part 5. This is intended to give the Government flexibility in dealing with possible misuses of market power by foreign carriers that become possible with the advent of full resale. It is the Government's intention, however, to impose minimal restrictions on those carriers and trades where reciprocal rights of resale are permitted.
Financial Impact

It is estimated that the measures in this Bill which give Austel new functions will require additional expenditure on Austel of $4.6m in the 1991-92 financial year and $3.8m in the following financial year.

It is expected, however, that the increase in expenditure on Austel will be more than offset by the additional revenue raised from the carrier licence fees imposed by the Telecommunications (Carrier Licence Fees) Bill 1991, and the fees imposed under the Telecommunications (Application Fees) Bill 1991 and the Telecommunications (Numbering Fees) Bill 1991.

The measures in the Bill which introduce competition are expected to have a major financial impact on Australia's telecommunications industry, with new players entering the market and greater efficiencies in the provision of services. The increased efficiency in the telecommunications industry and the new services likely to be offered by the players in the industry as a result of this Bill are designed to enhance the long term competitiveness of the entire Australian economy.

In terms of financial impact on the ordinary customer, no householder or ordinary subscriber in rural areas will be disadvantaged by the reforms. All residential consumers who currently have access to untimed local calls will continue to have that access.
I commend the Bill to the House and I present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.

This is a companion piece of legislation to the Telecommunications Bill 1991. It provides for the setting of fees for a range of applications made to the Australian Telecommunications Authority, Austel, and updates previous legislation to this effect.

Fees will continue to be payable in relation to the categories of applications for which fees have been payable up to now, and will include applications relating to customer equipment permits, cabling licences and test house accreditation. Fees will also apply to the same types of applications relating to eligible services under the Telecommunications Act 1991 as applied to applications relating to value added and private network services under the Telecommunications Act 1989.

Financial Impact
This Bill will allow Austel to recover its costs in processing these applications. I commend the Bill to the House and I present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.

This is a companion piece of legislation to the Telecommunications Bill 1991 and provides for the payment of fees to the Commonwealth for the allocation of numbers for public telecommunications services. The allocation of numbers will be the responsibility of the Australian Telecommunications Authority, Austel, under division 2 of part 11 of the Telecommunications Act 1991.

The Bill provides for different levels of fees to be charged for ordinary and `special' numbers. The fees for numbers will be fixed by, or determined under, regulation. In the case of special numbers, the regulations will apply to provide for a premium, a tender process or a public auction for fixing the fee.
Financial Impact

It is expected that this Bill will generate significant Commonwealth revenue, particularly in the sale of special numbers. This revenue will contribute towards offsetting Commonwealth expenditure on Austel.

This is a companion piece of legislation to the Telecommunications Bill 1991, and provides that the holders of general telecommunications licences or public mobile licences must pay a fee to the Commonwealth for the licence.

The amounts of the fees, or the formula by which the fees are determined, are to be set by regulation. It is intended that the amount or the formula determined by the regulations should represent a reasonable estimate of the administrative costs borne by Austel in directly regulating the activities of the carriers. Fees prescribed for the holders of telecommunications licences may differ from those provided for the holders of public mobile licences.

There is an upper limit on the total of the fees that may become payable under this legislation in any one financial year. This limit is the amount of Austel's appropriation from the Consolidated Revenue Fund for the previous financial year.
Financial Impact

The purpose of the carrier licence fees is to recover regulatory administration costs associated with Austel's work on carrier regulation. It would therefore be inappropriate for the total of the licence fees raised from the carriers to exceed Austel's total cost.

This is a companion piece of legislation to the Telecommunications Bill 1991, and imposes a levy in connection with ensuring the future delivery of the universal service obligation in Australia as defined in the Telecommunications Bill 1991.

The Bill allows for a carrier to be declared to be a participating carrier for a particular financial year and for a carrier to be liable to pay an amount equal to the carrier's levy debit balance. Details of the assessment, collection and distribution of the universal service levy are contained in part 13 of the Telecom- munications Bill 1991, as is the formula to be used by Austel to calculate levy credits and debits. Briefly, the formula allows levy credits and debits to be calculated based on the net costs incurred by carriers in delivering the universal service obligation, and apportioning liability for those costs to each carrier according to minutes of interconnect time. A levy is payable, therefore, only where a carrier's liability outweighs its net costs incurred.

In combination with the Telecommunications Bill 1991, this Bill will enable effect to be given to the Government's commitment to the future funding and delivery of the universal service obligation, and to its decision that the second telecommunications carrier should contribute on a pro rata basis to the costs of providing universal service.
Financial Impact

The relative contributions of participating carriers will depend on the carriers identifying loss-making areas of their operations where they have a universal service obligation, the extent of those losses and the amount of interconnect time between the carriers' trunk and international networks and all local access networks. Accordingly, it is impossible to quantify what amounts will be payable under the levy. It can be expected, however, that as the second general carrier's business grows, its contribution to cover the net cost of loss-making services will increase.
I commend the Bill to the House and I present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN AND OVERSEAS TELECOMMUNICATIONS CORPORATION BILL 1991

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Beazley, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The primary purpose of this Bill is to permit the amalgamation of the Australian Telecommunications Corporation (Telecom) and OTC Limited (OTC). The new corporate entity will be named the Australian and Overseas Telecommunications Corporation. The merger was one of the central elements of the parliamentary statement of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) of 8 November 1990 on transport and telecommunications reform. Further details were spelled out in my own announcement of the same date. This Bill requires that the new company remain in full public ownership.

It has been a central tenet throughout the Government's reform processes that a strong public sector presence in Australian telecommunications be maintained. The decision to retain the merged company in public ownership will enable the Government to meet the guarantee that no householder or ordinary subscriber in rural areas will be disadvantaged by the introduction of competition.

It is only through public ownership that the Government can ensure that the requirement that a standard telephone service be available to all residential and business customers throughout Australia is met. Public ownership allows direct control over this universal service obligation to the clear benefit of the people of Australia. If the Government were to privatise our national carrier, we would have to forgo the right as the Government to require that carrier to continue to meet such important social goals.

Retention of the new company in full public ownership will also mean that Australian taxpayers will continue to receive dividends in their capacity as shareholders. This means that future generations of Australians will continue to benefit from the rapid growth in telecommunications which this package of reforms will engender.

The major focus of this package is introducing competition, not privatisation for its own sake. The experience of other countries that have simultaneously attempted to privatise telecommunications companies and to introduce competition has been that competition has always been compromised. This package reflects our view that the fundamental issue is to get the regulatory framework right.
The Government's decision to merge Telecom and OTC followed consideration last year of the review of the ownership and structural arrangements among the government owned telecommunications carriers.

The Government intends that the merger of Telecom and OTC not represent a mere amalgamation of the two carriers. It is far more than that. The Government is seeking to bring these two carriers together to create a new entity with a streamlined organisational structure, which is capable of being not only an efficient national carrier but a major player in the telecommunications trade in this region.

This company must operate in a vigorous new competitive environment. It must therefore develop a genuinely competitive ethos and an overriding commitment to meeting the needs of Australian users. To do this, it is essential that the board and management of the new company pursue the achievement of standards of technical quality, service and price which are not only better than those achieved by Telecom and OTC individually but are equal to the best in the world.

It is expected that significant synergies will be realised by removing the current distinction between domestic and international telecommunication services. A united entity, exploiting the existing abilities and expertise of Telecom and OTC, will be able to provide customers with a comprehensive, globally interconnected service. It will also provide the foundation for an increased export focus within the Australian telecommunications industry by building on the successes so far of Telecom Australia International and OTC International.

The first stage in the merging of Telecom and OTC commenced with the appointment in December 1990 of an `interim board' comprising representatives of both the Telecom and OTC boards. The interim board's primary task is to advise the Government on the corporate and management structure which will best facilitate the merger of the two organisations and to prepare Telecom and OTC to face a competitive environment.

The interim board is progressively refining its position on a proposed structure for the new company. The board aims to ensure that the new structure will provide focus, accountability and authority so as to achieve strategic business objectives. As well, the structure of the new company will promote transparency of revenues, costs and assets to support accountability. A further aim will be to ensure that the new company's performance in regard to prices, costs, productivity and quality of service is comparable with the best in the world.

The new entity will be established, as a company with share capital, under normal corporations law processes. Consequently, the fiduciary responsibilities of the directors of the company will be the same as those applying to directors of private sector companies.

The operation of this Bill is directed at vesting in the new company all the rights, property, staff and liabilities of Telecom and OTC. It is the intention of the relevant provisions of the Bill that the new company be recognised as the legal successor of Telecom and OTC. In effect, the new company `stands in the shoes' of Telecom and OTC in respect of all their contractual arrangements. Provision is expressly made to ensure preservation of the rights, accrued entitlements and continuity of service of all Telecom and OTC staff transferred to the new company.

It is a deliberate policy decision of the Government that the merger provisions of the Bill will not commence until a day to be fixed by proclamation rather than commencing automatically after 6 months from the passage of the Bill. This is so that proclamation can be made to coincide with the certification by Austel that appropriate interconnection and equal access arrangements between the networks of Telecom and OTC and the second carrier have been settled. This approach recognises that the terms and conditions of interconnection are fundamental to the successful launch of the second carrier. In short, there is a powerful incentive on Telecom and OTC to move quickly on interconnection as they will be required to continue to operate as separate entities until the Austel certification is issued.

I would like to emphasise that this merger is not simply about subsuming one government owned organisation into another. The merger is concerned with the creation of a new organisation that will be much more than a simple `adding together' of OTC and Telecom. I have previously stated that the Government is interested in achieving the creation of a dynamic, customer driven, commercial entity. I reiterate that our goal is exactly that, and I am confident that it will be realised.

The Bill I am about to introduce empowers the Minister for Transport and Communications to give directions to the new company in relation to its operations when it is in the public interest to do so. This emphasises the Government's commitment to providing the Australian consumer with the most efficient and responsive telecommunications carrier possible.

Nevertheless, this provision should be viewed as primarily providing the Minister with a reserve power. Indeed the whole thrust of our competitive reforms will ensure that the board, management and staff of the new company will have every incentive to ensure that the new company performs efficiently and is responsive to customer requirements. If the new company is not responsive to the community's expectations it will inevitably see its market share and market power diminish.

The Bill also empowers the Minister to regulate charges levied by Telecom or OTC-or by the new company after the merger-for a telecommunications service or facility. This provision continues existing arrangements. At present, Telecom and OTC are subject to price cap arrangements which work to keep average price increases to consumers well below the inflation rate and thereby encourage Telecom and OTC to actively pursue improvements in their productivity. In the case of Telecom, control is also exercised through the notification and disallowance powers of the Minister in relation to a number of reserved services.

Both the price cap and notification and disallowance arrangements will continue until 1 July 1992, when the number of services regulated by notification and disallowance of charges will be reduced with greater emphasis on the price cap mechanism. The price control mechanisms are included in this Bill rather than in the Telecommunications Bill as they apply only to Telecom and OTC and, following the merger, the new company. This reflects the fact that as long as Telecom and OTC retain substantial market share, it is necessary and appropriate to be able to influence their pricing practices. It can be expected that as the market presence and power of the second and subsequent network providers grow, the need for these provisions will diminish. Ultimately they will be repealed.

In opening the telecommunications sector to more competition, the Government has been conscious of the need to create, as far as possible, a level playing field between the two general carriers. Accordingly, the Government gave careful consideration to which laws and policies should or should not apply to the new company. Because it is being established as a company under the corporations law, the new company will be automatically subject to certain laws which Telecom, as a statutory authority, was not.

At the same time, some exemptions from Commonwealth, State and Territory laws are carried over in this Bill and further exemptions may be accorded by regulation. Such exemptions will be kept to a minimum and will only be provided in cases where the cost to the new company of complying with the particular legislation would be particularly onerous and would result in substantial flow-on to customers; where the introduction of effective competition would be hampered; or where an exemption is essential in order to satisfy other government policy objectives.

A provision in the Bill also requires that the new company submit its annual report and financial statements to the Minister for Transport and Communications. It is my expectation that the directors of the company will include in those financial statements a full consolidation of the accounts of all subsidiaries and all joint ventures, including where the company only has a minority shareholding, of the new company. I consider it entirely appropriate that a Commonwealth owned company should conform with the highest accounting standards possible. In any event, when the Parliament passes amendments to the corporations law covering consolidation of subsidiaries, the new company will be obliged to compile financial statements in this form.

As regards financial impact, direct Commonwealth outlays will be minimal, being essentially limited to the costs of establishing and registering the new company. As regards additional revenue to the Commonwealth, a fee will be paid to the Government as a result of the merger of Telecom and OTC. The level of that fee will be set by the Government following consideration of advice from the interim board on the likely financial results of the merger. The Bill provides for certain exemptions from Commonwealth, State and Territory taxes with regard to the succession process, recognising there has been no change in beneficial ownership of the carriers.
I commend this Bill to the House and I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.

DEBATE.TITLE: APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 4) 1990-91[COGNATE BILLS:APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 5) 1990-91APPROPRIATION (PARLIAMENTARY DEPARTMENTS) BILL (No. 2) 1990-91]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 18 April on motion by Mr Willis:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the debate is resumed on this Bill, I remind the House that it has been agreed that a general debate be allowed covering this Bill and the Appropriation Bill (No. 5) 1990-91 and the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2) 1990-91.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crosio The Hon J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In continuation of my support for the Appropriation Bill (No. 5) in particular, I wish to proceed in expressing to the House the importance of Federal funding for flood mitigation works in western Sydney's flood prone areas, particularly in regard to house raising schemes. Before my speech was interrupted by the adjournment debate during the previous sitting, I mentioned a house raising subsidisation scheme which is administered by the New South Wales Rural Assistance Board. Under this scheme, loans are available to house owners in flood prone areas of up to 90 per cent of the cost of raising or relocating homes above flood level, subject to a ceiling amount of $10,000.

SPEECH.PARA: However, according to the Review of Floodplain Management Practice in NSW, a discussion paper dated May 1989, the scheme was generally seen as restrictive and unfair. I quote from that paper:

Most occupants of flood liable homes feel that it is not their fault that they live in such a dwelling. The residents were generally not parties to the original building approvals, and often were not aware that the site was flood liable at the time of purchase.
The paper concluded that:

More direct encouragement to people to help themselves, by raising the flood liable parts of their homes, and review of the existing house raising scheme in this light is deemed worthy of consideration.

Many residents who need financial assistance to raise their home above the one in 100 year flood level are pensioners or low income families who cannot afford to repay even the Rural Assistance Board's loan of $10,000. Moreover, conditions which apply to a loan application impose an extra financial burden on an applicant who invariably must arrange additional finance to cover the total cost of the house raising.

Fairfield City Council wrote to the New South Wales Premier, Nick Greiner, on 19 October 1988 requesting that the Rural Assistance Board loan be increased to $20,000 and that the `means testing restrictions' be removed. This was refused. What I suggest now and have suggested in the past is that indexed grants of $20,000 be made available to those people who own homes in the flood affected areas and who can ill afford to have their houses raised or relocated. There are 380 houses in the Lower Prospect Creek area which require funding for house raising. The estimated total cost to raise these houses is $4.3m.

Fairfield City Council allocated $600,000 in this financial year's budget to contribute towards house raising under the 2:2:1 funding arrangement between the Federal, State and local governments. The former Minister, Senator Peter Cook, advised Fairfield Council of the Commonwealth's agreement to fund house raising in this manner. However, until as recently as 23 April, the State Government of New South Wales had not agreed to the arrangement. Now, with the State election called, the New South Wales Liberal coalition Government has finally decided to come to the party and has provided Fairfield Council with ministerial approval for house raising to be eligible for flood mitigation funding-subject to formal approval from the State Minister for Public Works, I might add.

Unfortunately, however, the New South Wales State Government's 16 month delay in deciding on this matter has meant that administrative arrangements for house raising projects must be set back further and must now come under the 1991-92 financial year flood mitigation program. Under the Fairfield City Council's Lower Prospect Creek Floodplain Management Strategy, it was proposed that a reasonable approach to the house raising issue would be for a subsidy in the range of $3,000 to $20,000 to be offered to property owners to raise their houses from the available flood mitigation funds. The level of subsidy would be proportional to the expected damage which would be sustained by the unraised house over its remaining lifetime. In some locations, additional structural works comprising deflector banks and road raising are recommended to facilitate access and emergency evacuation from the raised houses.

The flood mitigation strategy recommended that the house raising proposal be implemented as soon as practicable, so that the wishes of those residents who were on waiting lists for the schemes could be met. The action of subsidising house raising would mean that people could remain in their homes; the Government would be seen to be solving these problems quickly; councils would continue to receive rates from the property; communities would continue to prosper; and money allocated in this way would achieve more value for the dollar spent.

However, there are a number of practical details which have to be resolved before this house raising scheme can be implemented. These include, just to give a few, that a subsidy must be payable only on the condition that houses are raised above the one in one hundred flood level plus freeboard; that any additional costs to enlarge or upgrade the house would be the responsibility of the owner; and that the owner may, in some cases, be allowed to demolish and rebuild above flood level, rather than raise an existing building.

The idea of subsidising house raising has been welcomed by many flood-affected residents in my electorate as well as lobby groups such as the South West Region Flood Action Group. In a recent press release issued by Fairfield City Council, the mayor claimed that New South Wales councils were:
. . . missing out badly on flood mitigation funding from Canberra . . .
and that:
Federal funding had failed to keep pace with State Government allocations, falling short by $8 million in 1990/91.
The press release also stated:
State and Local Government funds, unmatched by Federal funding, (in the 2:2:1 program) ultimately costs ratepayers an extra $133,000 for every $1 million spent on flood mitigation.
According to that press release the executive of the flood mitigation authorities of New South Wales wants:
. . . Canberra to provide $10 million in its next budget for urgent flood mitigation in NSW for the 2:2:1 (program). This will give a real boost to the Councils in reducing annual flood damage costs.

There are 35 local government areas within New South Wales, with a combined population of nearly 2 million persons, which have urgent flood mitigation backlogs totalling $275m. Financial assistance is needed from both State and Federal governments to subsidise flood plain management studies and capital works in these areas which require more funding than the councils alone can provide.

Although modern flood plain strategies and future planning are being adopted by councils, the flooding problem in existing residential areas will not be overcome without more financial assistance from State and Federal governments to allow the implementation of substantial flood mitigation works. Major river flooding in New South Wales directly affects about 45,000 urban properties. (Quorum formed)

In the time that I have left I would suggest that the proposal suggested that the Commonwealth and State governments should each pay an annual contribution of $7.2m and the affected councils should pay an annual contribution of $3.6m. Needless to say, this proposal was never heeded.

The issue of Federal funding of flood mitigation works in western Sydney will not disappear in the near future and the problem of flooding will not be solved overnight. However, significant progress can be made towards preventing further flooding disasters and hardship in western Sydney if action is taken by Federal, State and local governments now. It is for this reason that I commend the Appropriation Bills to this House and hope that a decision to increase funding for flood mitigation works in New South Wales, and especially in western Sydney, will soon be made.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beale Mr J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a pleasure to speak before such a receptive audience on Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 1990-91, Appropriation Bill (No. 5) 1990-91 and Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2) 1990-91. It is nice to see the Australian Labor Party members come to hear a decent speech, instead of that political rubbish we just heard from the honourable member for Prospect (Mrs Crosio).
—Don't you like the truth?
—It must be election time. I remind the House that Nick was Bob's good friend until the last couple of weeks.
—Order! The honourable member for Bruce will refer to the Prime Minister by his proper title.
—I was talking about Bob Brown.
—Could you refer to him by his proper title too?

—I wish to spend my time today in discussing Appropriation Bill (No. 5) in talking about communications and, specifically in Appropriation Bill (No. 5), the fifth item of additional appropriations which is the $25m agreed value for the purchase of Telecom's equity in Aussat. The Government purchased Telecom's 25 per cent equity so that it can sell Aussat together with the second network carrier licence.

SPEECH.PARA: We have just heard the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Beazley) introduce a series of Bills that will give effect to the Government's decision to partially deregulate the telecommunications market and partially effect a form of privatisation. The coalition will respond to those Bills in due course.

We do know now what the Government will do. The Government will sell, or attempt to sell, Aussat and in doing so will attempt to create a form of competition. That sold Aussat will compete with the merged Telecom-OTC. The Government intends to maintain the duopoly that would then exist until 1997 at least and it has stated that it will keep Telecom in Government hands.

On the other hand the coalition policy on telecommunications is starkly different and quite clear. Our first priority in telecommunications is to achieve full and effective competition, and that means not a duopoly but the ability of anybody to be able to enter what we hope will be a contestable market. Within that framework of full and effective competition, we will proceed with the privatisation of Telecom.

The timing, pace and conditions of the privatisation of Telecom will be determined having regard to all the relevant circumstances and the capital market's ability to provide the funds required for the privatisation of Telecom. That privatisation of Telecom would be managed so as to ensure that Australians retain majority ownership and control of strategic telecommunication assets. In the pri- vatisation process employees of Telecom will be given preference in acquiring shares.

The community service obligations in telecommunications will be paid for by direct and specific appropriation made in the Budget. The community service obligations will ensure the provision of comprehensive, reasonably priced telecommunications services to rural, regional and remote areas. Competitors in telecommunications will be required to obtain licences from the Australian telecommunications authority, Austel. These licences will entitle the licensees to compete in the entire field of, or specific areas of, telecommunications. Licences will be issued against criteria established, including the competition and services proposed by the applicant, and the merits of the application.

A specific matter that will be taken into account in the awarding of these licences will be the degree of Australian ownership of the applicant. The coalition parties will treat the telecommunications industry as an industry of strategic national importance for the purpose of foreign investment guidelines and each licence application will be subject to a case-by-case examination. The coalition parties commit themselves to the independence of the regulatory body, Austel, which will have a very significant role in enabling full and effective competition to take place.

Austel, therefore, will have, firstly, adequate powers and resources to ensure that competitors to Telecom will be able to connect to the Telecom network on non-discriminatory terms and fair prices and, secondly, a charter to encourage competition. Austel will also retain its essential function of determining technical standards.

Our emphasis, so far as the telecommunications industry in the future is concerned, is on full and effective competition right across the board. We want to see anybody who is prepared to offer telecommunications services to the Australian public have the ability to do so. We want to see a properly contestable market with anybody who wants to compete in that market having access to it. Full competition is a prerequisite to privatisation. The coalition parties will proceed to privatisation of Telecom only after they are satisfied that full and effective competition is either in place or can take place; in other words, that there is a properly contestable market.

The privatisation process is misunderstood by the Government. The Government regards privatisation as essentially a revenue raising exercise. But privatisation is not only about raising revenue and providing an appropriate return to the taxpayers of the funds that they have invested in Government business enterprises; it involves greater competition, greater efficiency and benefits to consumers. By benefits to consumers, we mean lower prices and better services.

In the Victorian public transport system-a government enterprise which operates as a monopoly-we have a wonderful example of the way in which we should be using the market to open up and to provide better services to consumers. In that transport system there is a lack of competition, shocking delivery of services, and an immense cost to the Victorian public and, in a sense, to the Australian taxpayer in the form of a loss of $1.2 billion last year. That is an extra tax of $1,100 for the average four-person family. The Commonwealth Government now has an opportunity to lead the way in privatisation, but already it has made an extraordinary mess of trying to part-privatise the airlines-all this before the process has even begun.

Although the part-privatisation of the Commonwealth Bank appears to be proceeding smoothly, it offers an opportunity for a successful transfer of all the ownership of the bank at a time when the Government has squibbed that issue by offering only a portion of the bank to what will be an eager public wishing to invest in it. The next coalition Government will embark on an orderly program of returning property and enterprise to the people. We will encourage the States to follow suit for the sake of efficiency, lower prices and better services to consumers.
