We emphasise the consumer benefits; we emphasise the beneficial effect of competition; we emphasise the effect that more efficiency will have; and we emphasise that lower prices and better services will almost certainly follow the opening up of markets to competition and the transfer of ownership of government business enterprises to the private sector.

We should make mention of the aspect of funding. It is now clear that governments are trying to do more than they can or should do. Government resources are limited and should be employed in providing social services to the community, to look to establishing a safety net for those people who cannot look after themselves, and to providing those services in our just and compassionate society. All of these government business enterprises will need additional funding in due course; any successful business requires additional funding. The fact that both Qantas Airways Ltd and Australian Airlines now have such an appalling ratio of debt to equity, quite out of step with their private sector competitors here and with what is happening in the industry in other parts of the world, is an indicator that the Government is either unwilling or unable to provide the necessary funds to bring those debt equity ratios into balance. Any successful business requires additional funding. By transferring these government business enterprises from the public sector to the private sector we obviate the need for the taxpayer to provide those additional funds.

A further aspect of the privatisation program is the fact that we want to encourage employees in those organisations to participate in their ownership. The Government lectured us in Question Time today about relations between employer and employee and our approach to this. On the contrary, our approach to industrial relations, with its emphasis on enterprise bargaining, that is, entering into relationships between employer and employee at an enterprise level, will make it easier for communication to take place between employer and employee and almost inevitably will improve the relationship between them. If we go further-as we propose to do-in the privatisation of government business enterprises by requiring or asking employees to participate in the ownership of the enterprise, we will further improve the relationship between employer and employee.

Another benefit we see from privatisation is that we can encourage a more widespread ownership of the assets of our country in the hands of its citizens. There have been some articles recently in the Australian Financial Review that suggest that, with the part-privatisation of the Commonwealth Bank, there could be 300,000 to 400,000 new shareholders in the bank. That compares with 187,000 shareholders, I think it is, in our largest listed public corporation, the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd. So we want to see greater employee participation and a wider spread of shareholding of these enterprises in the hands of all our citizens when they are transferred to the private sector.

A further benefit from the transfer of these government business enterprises to the private sector is that we will have leaner government and less need for people to be involved in overseeing these enterprises. Leaner government will mean a more competitive, more effective and better managed government sector. Finally, in terms of benefits, capital markets will become more responsive as these large enterprises are floated or sold into the private sector because capital markets respond very actively to new issues, and particularly to issues of many of these corporations which, as we know, are great Australian enterprises.

If I summarise briefly a recent paper by Des Moore of the Institute of Public Affairs on the six points that have led to the worldwide privatisation movement, it will further encapsulate what we believe are the benefits that will arise from the privatisation process. They are, firstly, the recognition that there can be government failure as well as market failure; secondly, the deterioration in economic performance in those countries that accompanied the expansion of government over the last generation; thirdly, the apparent failure of government intervention to overcome social problems such as poverty; fourthly, the poor performance of government trading enterprises; fifthly, the development of public choice theory, suggesting that there is an in-built tendency for government and bureaucrats to act in ways contrary to the best interests of the community as a whole; and, sixthly, the realisation that powerful interest groups, whether business or union, can capture government and government enterprises and persuade them to protect their positions, again contrary to the interest of the community as a whole. The privatisation movement has developed as a counter to this capture that has taken place in the public sector and of government business enterprises

We plan to privatise the following government business enterprises: Aussat Pty Ltd, Australian Airlines, the Australian Industry Development Corporation and the Australian National Line. We plan to complete the process of privatising the Commonwealth Bank, the airport terminals, Medibank Private, the Pipeline Authority, Qantas Airways Ltd, the Commonwealth Funds Management Ltd, the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories and the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation. In due course we will develop and expand the appropriate mechanisms that will apply to the privatisation of those government business enterprises and the appropriate method of marketing to ensure that their transfer is a success and that the taxpayer is appropriately rewarded in terms of the return of the proceeds from the sale.

Finally, an essential part of the privatisation process is the contracting out of services to Australian business enterprises and to small and even one-person contractors of those functions now performed by the bureaucracy. This process of contracting out will encourage competition, provide more flexibility and give greater service to the consumers of those services. Amongst the targets for contracting out are things such as cleaning; security functions; computer services; fire protection; laundries; stores management; training; property management, construction, maintenance, valuation and mapping; waste collection; and laboratory analysis. All these functions are presently delivered by government but could equally be contracted out to the private sector, thus introducing competition and providing better services to those consumers to whom those services are directed.

I would be happy to encourage tenders for the supply of food and drink in Parliament House, for example. Our highly skilled staff in the dining room would be able to earn more if their efforts could be rewarded by a more efficient system. Workers will soon come to learn that flexibility and better service mean higher incomes. For example, in the United States of America highly successful contracting-out programs have been conducted in such areas as prisoner rehabilitation. The Salvation Army has a wonderful record in this respect. It has saved the United States taxpayer large sums of previously wasted expenditure. The coalition parties look forward to budgets which incorporate coherent and widespread programs of privatisation and contracting out, thus giving to the Australian people lower prices and better services. I believe that that view is shared by the Australian public.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hulls Mr R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to the Appropriation Bills, I take the opportunity to congratulate the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission on its relentless efforts to acknowledge and implement Australia's international human rights obligations. Over the last 12 months-my first year in parliament-I have been convinced more than ever that it is absolutely essential that this Parliament address itself seriously to human rights and that raising the profile and effectiveness of the Commission is the best way we can do this. It is true that Australia has a solid international reputation on human rights issues, and deservedly so. In January this year we began a three-year term as a member of the United Nations Commission on Human Rights. This will further raise our profile internationally. I hope it will also help focus our attention on human rights abuses in our own backyard.

SPEECH.PARA: The Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission has been turning the spotlight on human rights abuses in Australia. Disturbing reports have been tabled in this House on behalf of Mr Brian Burdekin, the Human Rights Commissioner, on the social and material needs of Queensland-New South Wales border towns and on homeless youth. Just last month the Race Discrimination Commissioner, Irene Moss, tabled a damning report on racist violence in Australia.

If we are to maintain our international reputation into the twenty-first century, we have to consolidate what we have already achieved. We have to raise the status of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission. As a Queenslander, I am particularly concerned about community awareness of human rights in my State. The objectives of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission are as follows: first, to increase the understanding, acceptance and observance of human rights and equal opportunity in Australia; and, secondly, to promote a fairer society by protecting basic human rights and ensuring that Australia complies with its human rights obligations under international law.

It is fair to say that it makes it extremely difficult for the Commission to fulfil its charter in Queensland, where there is only one office in Brisbane to serve the entire State, especially when nearly half a million Queenslanders live above the line across from Townsville to Mount Isa. For this reason alone there is an urgent need for an office of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission to be established somewhere in north Queensland. Obviously, this will involve an increase in funding for the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission. I will certainly be lobbying my colleagues in the Government, particularly northern Queensland members-the honourable member for Leichhardt (Mr Gayler) and the honourable member for Herbert (Mr Lindsay)-to make provision for this in the forthcoming Budget. However, apart from demographics, there is a compelling argument for an expansion of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission's presence in Queensland, particularly on the basis of need.

My electorate of Kennedy is in Queensland. It extends from the Northern Territory border across to the Atherton Tablelands and south to Blackall. It takes up about 45 per cent of the Queensland landmass. Because of the size of the electorate I am entitled to two offices. I have one in my home city of Mount Isa and one in Mareeba, which is about an hour's drive inland from Cairns.

As all honourable members in this House would know, a wide range of people with a wide range of problems venture through the doors of electorate offices. Because of the breadth of my electorate I also receive an incredible amount of mail from constituents. What has concerned me over the last 12 months is the number of constituents who have sought my advice and assistance on matters that have involved serious breaches of human rights. I have been approached about blatantly racist treatment of Aboriginal constituents, about more subtle racism against Filipino women, about sex discrimination in employment, about child abuse and indeed about shameful treatment of elderly people.

I am not in a position now to say whether the incidence of human rights abuses in my electorate is any higher than anywhere else. However, I can say that Queensland as a whole fares a lot worse than other States in relation to human rights abuses. It is fair to say that Queensland has suffered 32 years of right wing fundamentalism under the National Party Government-a government that had 32 years to introduce anti-discrimination legislation but did not. As I understand it, Tasmania is the only other State that has failed to do so.

Under the National Party, Queensland did not have a State-funded office dedicated to women's issues, prompting the Commonwealth to set up an outpost of the Federal Office of the Status of Women in Brisbane some time ago. The Bjelke-Petersen Government was openly hostile to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people, as indicated by the Koowarta case in which the Queensland Government refused to sell land to an Aboriginal community group.

Queensland was one of three States surveyed in a study undertaken by the National Inquiry into Racist Violence, which quite disturbingly found that police systematically beat young Aboriginal detainees. A survey of some 200 Aboriginal youths found that between 82 per cent and 94 per cent had been assaulted by police.

Nor is the Queensland record on sex discrimination anything to cheer about. In a paper given at a seminar held by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs on sex discrimination legislation, Marg O'Donnell, Director of the Queensland community justice program, past Director of the Queensland Office of the Status of Women and conciliator with the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission, presented the Committee with these disturbing statistics concerning Queensland's record on sex discrimination: Queensland has the highest unemployment rate for women of any State in Australia; in Queensland women have the lowest rate of pay relative to men; and Queensland has the highest percentage of sexual assaults against women of any State in Australia. Those are disturbing statistics indeed.

In the same paper, Marg O'Donnell told the Committee that because the Commonwealth Sex Discrimination Act specifically did not apply to employment in that State, many Queenslanders, especially in remote areas, believed that it did not apply in Queensland at all. The Queensland Attorney-General, Dean Wells, summed up the mood in Queensland under the previous National Party Government when he described the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission as `courageously implementing the Federal legislation in Queensland'.

In view of the above, I guess it is not surprising that so many apparent human rights abuses have come through my offices, and I am very pleased to see that in March this year the Queensland State Cabinet approved the preparation of legislation which will outlaw discrimination on grounds of race, religion, sex, age and disability. In fact, the Queensland Government recently announced plans to negotiate with the Commonwealth to enable complementary administration of the State's proposed anti-discrimination laws with Federal laws.

I guess this now gives us the perfect opportunity to redress the 32 years of neglect by the National Party and make a concerted State and Federal attack on all forms of discrimination. As I said, for human rights abuses to be seriously challenged in Queensland, and indeed Australia-wide, the Commission must have a higher profile. One way to achieve this in Queensland is to open an office in the northern part of the State.

However, it is fair to say that we must go further than this. We can have an office in every city and town, providing information on human rights and successfully conciliating instances of human rights abuses, but unless the Commission actually has the power to enforce its determinations in those critical situations where conciliation fails, those offices are indeed mere facades. The Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission must be given more teeth. The fact is that, when it comes to sexism, racism, ageism or any other form of discrimination, we have to change people's ideas. It is not sufficient to rely on the view of ourselves as a nation of battlers where everyone gets a fair go. Just because we see ourselves as an egalitarian society does not make us one. Similarly, to legislate to the effect that people should not discriminate on the basis of sex, marital status, age or race does not mean that such discrimination will cease.

It is not so long ago that Australia unquestioningly maintained a White Australia immigration policy. No doubt, this official racism was reflected in individual prejudices that in some cases still linger today. Some form of compulsion to rethink fundamentally racist views is necessary so that people can see that change can occur and anarchy will not reign. The same can be said in relation to sexism and other forms of discrimination.

There is a fundamental problem in regard to the power of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission: the determinations of the Commission are not enforceable by that Commission. As well as its own Act, the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission administers the Sex Discrimination Act 1984, the Racial Discrimination Act 1975, as well as the Privacy Act 1988. The emphasis in the legislation is on the settlement of complaints by `conciliation'. When the conciliation process fails to achieve results, the Commission has wide powers to conduct its own inquiries and either dismiss the complaint or find the complaint substantiated and make certain determinations.

I appreciate the merits of conciliation. According to the Commission, by far the majority of complaints are successfully dealt with by conciliation. In fact, in 1988-89, 97 per cent of the complaints brought under the Sex Discrimination Act were either successfully conciliated or not proceeded with. However, it is an unfortunate fact that the cases which attract publicity are those which cannot be conciliated and which go to a formal hearing. The outcome of these cases is therefore vitally important in terms of the public perception of the effectiveness of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission.

The consequences of the current legislative arrangements have been amply illustrated in the case of one Lynette Aldridge who made a complaint to the Commission under the Sex Discrimination Act. I will outline briefly the path of Lynette Aldridge's complaint, as I believe it actually tells its own story.

Lynette left her job in a bakery in January 1986, and in March 1986 she made a complaint under the Sex Discrimination Act against her employer, one Grant Booth. After all attempts at conciliation failed, the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission held a formal hearing on 5 November 1986 and found that Lynette's complaint was substantiated and that the incidents complained of were unlawful under the Sex Discrimination Act. The next day the Commission awarded her $7,000 damages for humiliation and injury.

Mr Booth actually refused to pay the money. Because of the constitutional constraints, the Commission could not make him pay. Under the Constitution, judicial powers cannot be conferred on administrative bodies, so section 81 (1) of the Sex Discrimination Act and section 25z of the Racial Discrimination Act specifically state that the Commission's determinations are not binding on the parties. For the order to be enforced the matter had to be referred to the Federal Court.

Lynette successfully applied for legal aid and an application to appeal was filed with the court on 9 March 1987. Constitutional questions arose in relation to the status of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission and other matters which resulted in the then Attorney-General and the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission intervening in the proceedings. After numerous Federal Court appearances, during which it was decided that the Court was required to rehear all the evidence, the matter eventually went to trial in August 1987 and was heard over seven days between August and October 1987.

This meant that Lynette had to go through the whole humiliating episode again in a formal court, dominated by men, in which the experience she complained of was peripheral to the heady questions of constitutional law being debated. Much to her relief, some seven months later, in March 1988, the Federal Court found in her favour and imposed an identical order to that of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission.

It would be comforting to end the story there. However, Mr Booth has again refused to pay up on the basis that he could not afford to, even if he wanted to do so. So, after an oral examination, Lynette's application for legal aid to enforce the Federal Court's decision has now been refused. To my mind, this whole process is an abuse of human rights. Lynette has absolutely no reason to believe she had any rights at all, certainly none that this Parliament is serious about enforcing.

The Aldridge and Booth case is of particular concern to me in light of a recent Commission hearing in my electorate in Mareeba. A complaint was made by a number of my constituents, who are Aboriginal, who had been refused service in two Mareeba hotels. In December 1990 the Commission found that the hotels concerned had unlawfully discriminated against Aborigines under the Racial Discrimination Act.

I do not want to say much more than that here, as I understand that the publicans concerned have refused to pay the compensation ordered by the Commission. This leaves the complainants in the same position as Lynette, where they will have to apply for legal aid to have the matter reheard in the Federal Court. I believe this situation is totally unsatisfactory. The Government is well aware of the problem. In a submission to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, the Attorney-General's Department states that it is arguable that the fact that the Commission's determinations are not binding undermines the effectiveness of the Commission's role in eradicating sex and race discrimination.

The submission made the very disturbing comment that in recent cases respondents have exercised the option of withholding their evidence but assessing the complainant's case in the hearing before the Commission, ignoring the Commission's determination and then developing or patching up their own case in the Federal Court. The submission makes the obvious point that, as more and more respondents learn that the Commission's decisions are indecisive, there is a risk that they will use their financial superiority over the complainants to force repetition of proceedings in the Federal Court.

So the question has to be asked: what do we do? I believe that there are a number of short term measures that can be implemented almost immediately. Firstly, the need for complete rehearings in the Federal Court can be limited. The submission of the Attorney-General's Department to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs stated that the Government is giving consideration to a means whereby some of the more onerous effects of the need for complete rehearings in the Federal Court can be alleviated. Secondly, the need for the complainant to take action on his or her own behalf to have a determination of the Commission enforced in the Federal Court can be shifted to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission by providing the Commission with sufficient resources to run its own appeals.

In conjunction with these initiatives, I believe we need to look at the wider question of the status of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission in the context of constitutional reform. A guarantee of basic human rights was identified by the Constitutional Centenary Conference held in Sydney earlier this year as one of the 12 key issues to be pursued in the constitutional reform debate.

The question of how human rights are to be guaranteed must be addressed in this context. Bodies such as the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission must be given clear and appropriate powers, and our courts must be given clear and appropriate direction. These issues have to be addressed in the context of constitutional reform. I, like you, Mr Deputy Speaker, cherish my freedom of speech and my freedom from discrimination. But I wonder whether Lynette Aldridge or my Aboriginal constituents in Mareeba would say the same thing. As an Anglo-Saxon, tertiary educated male, my world experience does not include the discrimination experienced by a single mother harassed at work or an Aboriginal person desperate for a job or who just wants to have a drink in a hotel.

It is fair to say that we live in rapidly changing times-times in which the global demand for human rights is gathering momentum. If Australia is to keep up with the rest of the world we must be seen to be doing more than simply sermonising. We have to establish an office of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission in north Queensland to meet the desperate needs of nearly half a million Australians who are entitled to reasonable access to the Commission. We have to urgently address the problems facing complainants seeking enforcement of Commission determinations. The current situation is totally unsatisfactory.

As I said earlier, I believe we have to act now. As things stand, my constituents in Mareeba face a similar soul destroying experience, as did Lynette Aldridge. The Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission must be given the support it needs to fulfil its charter so that we can maintain our international reputation on human rights issues. As the Human Rights Commissioner, Brian Burdekin, said in the Commission's annual report for 1989-90:
There is no doubt that the existing structure-
of the Commission-

can be improved upon. What is essential, however, is a better understanding in the general community and at the political level of the need for human rights machinery, given the limitations of our court system to provide affordable and effective remedies for many of our most disadvantaged Australians.
As I said, we must act now to ensure that there is an office of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission opened in north Queensland as soon as possible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aldred Mr K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In rising to speak on the Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 1990-91 and cognate Bills in the context of Australia's present national circumstances, I am reminded of the words of the famed British Foreign Secretary Edward Grey who, on the eve of the First World War, on 3 August 1914, said:

SPEECH.PARA: The lamps are going out all over Europe; we shall not see them lit again in our lifetime.

Today, on 7 May 1991, the lamps are going out all over Australia. They are going out because of the most disastrous combination of adverse forces throughout the 1980s which have made that decade the most dissipated and forgettable in our 200-year history-a decade dominated by the incompetence of Federal and State Labor governments, widespread official corruption, the repulsive excesses of corporate entrepreneurs and the arrogance of militant unions, which have given us the politics of expediency and the economics of greed.

The resultant net foreign debt of over $130 billion, crippling interest rates, endless mergers, takeovers and then crashes and mindless industrial disruption have all but destroyed our once great farming, mining and manufacturing industries. Not that any of this has apparently worried members of Australia's various Labor governments. Even the more responsible and rational Labor members have gone along with the policy direction of the 1980s-if one can dignify it with that term-and, in Parliament and in Caucus, faithfully followed W.S. Gilbert's dictum in HMS Pinafore:
I always voted at my party's call, and I never thought of thinking for myself at all.

If individual Labor members had thought for themselves, they would have realised that one cannot build a great nation and an enduring economy on the financial services sector, tourism, casinos and taking in each other's washing. However, the Australian Labor Party does not have the dubious status of being solely responsible for the near ruination of this country. The corporate fringe dwellers, the entrepreneurs such as Bond, Skase, Herscu, Spalvins and others, with empires built on the sands of debt and not on the rock of real wealth creation, must be held just as accountable. Taking full advantage of Labor's excessive and incompetently implemented financial deregulation, the subsequent absence of proper prudential controls and spurred on by the yuppie element in the financial institutions, the corporate entrepreneurs engaged in the most extensive exercises of economic destruction, not production, and disgraced the hitherto good name of Australian business.

To Labor's incompetence and entrepreneurial rapaciousness must be added the blind arrogance of the militant unions. Not only have they, with a Luddite passion, undermined or blocked sensible reforms to work practices and the operation of the labour market, but on occasions also placed the livelihood of entire industries at risk by the most idiotic and incomprehensible industrial action. Not so long ago in my own State of Victoria we had a classic illustration of this form of industrial action when the tomato growing industry was put at risk by an absolutely pointless dispute at the Heinz factory.

As a result of the now totally discredited roulette economics of the 1980s, Australia faces the coming decade with a massive foreign debt, an impotent economy and drastically weakened public institutions. The terrifying consequence of this awful combination is a massive erosion of our national sovereignty. In the immortal words of the Scottish poet, Robert Burns, we are losing `the glorious privilege of being independent'. All those responsible for this betrayal of Australia's freedom to act in our best interests will stand condemned in the eyes of the electorate and the generations to come.

However, not content with playing its part in destroying our economic independence, the Hawke Labor Government now proposes to further undermine our national sovereignty by taking away even the capacity to properly defend ourselves. There can be no doubt that the steady sapping of our defence capability has been sensed for some time, especially by the handful of us in this House-and, believe me, it is only a handful-who take any serious interest in defence. Despite Government protestations about increasing Australia's defence self-reliance and posturing about new capital equipment programs, there has been growing evidence of a developing crisis in our defence forces.

Throughout the 1980s we have witnessed such disturbing events as the early decimation of the Army Reserve by the quite stupid tax on Reserve pay; the rising resignation rate amongst experienced officers and non-commissioned officers in all three regular services; the growing parlous manpower, equipment and stores situation within the infantry battalions of the Regular Army; the severe restrictions on both Royal Australian Air Force flying time and Royal Australian Navy (RAN) steaming time; the scouring of the Army for sufficient boots for the force that went to Fiji; and the ransacking of naval stores to provide adequate supplies for the RAN task force that went to the Gulf.

Most recently, we have seen the abolition of the Army's 3rd Division headquarters in Melbourne and the accompanying unit abolitions and amalgamations of the Army Reserve, which are impacting most heavily upon Victoria. The implications of all this are most disquieting because it is 3rd Division headquarters that was instrumental in the development of the Vital Asset Protection (VAP) doctrine for such assets in northern and western Australia. It is the headquarters that has the greatest experience in the operation of that doctrine.

Those people who are indifferent or even hostile to Australia's defence requirements give two totally predictable responses to this gravely deteriorating state of affairs. The first of these predictable responses is that Australia faces no imminent threat of mainland invasion or other significant defence contingency. Clearly, though, there are many disturbing scenarios, short of invasion, that can suddenly arise, as the Falklands War, Fiji, the Gulf and our near involvement in Bougainville all patently demonstrate.

A second response is that our allies, most especially the United States, will look to Australia's safety in any foreseeable emergency. Leaving aside the obvious fact that we are ostensibly a nation in our own right and not a tributary vassal in an American empire and that we require the respect of our allies and not their contempt, it also has to be said that there are numerous localised or even regional defence contingencies where United States protection or support could not be taken for granted.

Of course, we could resort to that fine European tradition of centuries past, also practised in the Roman empire in its final years, of ensuring Australia's national defence by hiring mercenaries. Knowing the predilection of the Hawke Labor Government, they would, of course, have to be Japanese mercenaries, possibly retained as part of an overall package deal on the multifunction polis or the very fast train. Levity aside, when the House hears what I am about to say about the further destruction that the Federal Labor Government intends shortly to wreak upon the Australian defence forces, my colleagues in this place and the Australian people will realise that hiring foreign mercenaries may ultimately be the only defence option that this country has left.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —In essence, the crunch point in the run-down of defence has come. This Government's years of starving the Australian defence forces of essential resources, of disinterest in defence, of poor political leadership in military affairs and of continuing confusion over strategic aims have made this terrible day inevitable. What is more, the Hawke Government cannot plead ignorance of its imminent arrival. No less a figure than the nation's most senior serving soldier, General Peter Gration, Chief of the Defence Force, told the Parliament prior to Christmas that it was coming. In evidence before the defence sub-committee of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade on 17 December 1990, on page 1262 of the transcript, General Gration is reported as saying:

SPEECH.PARA: As the Committee knows, since the 1987 White Paper actual defence funds have fallen well short of the anticipated 3 per cent per annum real growth that we foresaw in 1987. As a matter of historical fact, we have had more like zero per cent real growth and we have had zero growth this year. We have, therefore, been trying to implement this total force under conditions in which we were contracting both the size of the Defence Force and our investment plans. In this climate, difficult judgments were necessary and the Reserves, as part of the total force, had to take their share of the hurt. The hurt was apportioned not on the basis of whether particular units were regular or reserves but on the priority of their contribution to the defence of Australia.
This was the background to the reductions in the Reserve in Victoria in the context of the 1990-91 Budget.

At this juncture I must interpose my own observation. Notwithstanding General Gration's distinguished record, I must take issue with him on his last remarks. The Army Reserve in Victoria was undoubtedly singled out for peculiarly brutal treatment. Major-General Mike Jeffrey and others saw to that, as I have pointed out earlier in this House. Nevertheless, I continue with General Gration's testimony on page 1267 of the transcript of evidence of 17 December last, where his expose develops as follows:

I will just pick up a couple of things there. I think you have to be very careful in distinguishing between percentage of gross domestic product and percentage growth. You used both figures there. The figure that I was talking about was predicted annual real growth. At the time of the 1987 White Paper the Government guidance was to plan on plus 3 per cent per annum real growth. There was a separate figure given of keeping defence outlays between a range of figures of gross domestic product, but I was talking of percentage growth and I think you were as well. Without making any comments on whether it is good or bad, the simple historical fact is that since 1987 we have had about zero per cent real growth this year. If you do the arithmetic, the difference over the first five years of the program between the program of plus 3 per cent and a program of about zero is indeed the figure you mentioned-$1.7 billion. It depends on the assumptions you make on inflation, but it is of that order.

Therein lies the crux of the crisis now upon us. The Hawke Government supposedly laid out finite financial parameters for recent, present and future defence spending levels. On that basis, certain major capital equipment projects were entered into or planned and it was expected that a particular force in being could also be effectively maintained. That those financial parameters for defence spending were laid out as stated by General Gration in his evidence is utterly beyond dispute.

The commitment to 3.1 per cent real growth over the five-year defence program is clearly set out on pages 161 and 163 of the Dibb report on Australia's Defence Capabilities of March 1986. Likewise, the additional capital equipment acquisitions that flow from these financial arrangements are laid out on pages 164 to 166 of the Dibb report. These cover every conceivable item, from the light patrol frigates to the over-the-horizon radar. Confirmation of the framework for the five-year defence program is then given on pages 102 and 103 of the subsequent 1987 Defence White Paper. Furthermore, later on at paragraph 9.15 of the White Paper, the Hawke Government makes a commitment to an overall allocation of resources to defence, generally within the order of 2.6 per cent to 3 per cent of gross domestic product (GDP).

The simple fact is that resource allocation has not in recent years been of this order of magnitude and is currently around 2.3 per cent of GDP. In fact, the highest level defence spending has been at as a proportion of GDP in the last decade was 2.7 per cent in 1982-83, the last year of the Fraser Liberal Government, and 2.7 per cent again in 1985-86 under the present Government. Of special interest in the present perilous circumstances is paragraph 8.4 on page 103 of the 1987 White Paper. Prophetically, it reads as follows:

The FYDP must take account of changes in the level of Government's financial guidance to defence and differences between this guidance and actual budget allocations. This Government recognises that considerable waste and inefficiency in defence planning is inevitable when unrealistic guidance is given as a planning basis for defence spending. The Government is committed to more realistic financial guidance, for defence planning, although some adjustments will still need to be made when settling annual budgets.

The Hawke Government, having reneged on its own unequivocal commitments, is now crucified by its own words. What did it expect was going to happen in the 1990s? Had Hawke Labor Ministers expected the coalition to win the Federal election of March 1990 and then, as we moved into this decade, the coalition was to be blamed for the enveloping shambles in defence? Whatever the motivation, as General Gration succinctly pointed out, the reality is that Australia is now faced with a $1.7 billion defence bungle.

In essence, by reneging on its White Paper financial commitments and simultaneously proclaiming a doctrine of self-reliance and expanded defence capital projects, the Hawke Government has propelled the Australian Defence Force into acute crisis. The Federal Labor Government, in the foremost area of its responsibilities to the Australian people-national defence-follows its State counterparts in Western Australia, South Australia and Victoria into a growing Labor litany of political incompetence and financial mismanagement. This disastrous destruction of Australia's defence is now to be dressed up as structural reform by the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) in a statement presently scheduled for 6 June.

It is predicted that the current force structure review will recommend the reduction of the Regular Army by at least 6,000 personnel and Royal Australian Air Force regular manning by well over 4,000. There will be major reductions of both Regular Army and Reserve manpower in all Army commands, especially the training and logistic commands, with a no more than three or four regular battalion structure a likely result. Overall it is expected that the 69,000 strong regular force will be reduced by a hefty 12,000 personnel.

A so-called ready reserve force is proposed to be raised, initially with a brigade of 3,000 personnel, or possibly more, over the period 1992 to 1995, with considerable confusion existing as to how this will be practically achieved. I will return to this strange proposal later.

Generally in respect of the Army Reserve, it is expected that Reserve command and staff colleges and officer cadet training units will be restricted to the east coast, the university regiments will be downgraded, one infantry battalion in Queensland and another in New South Wales will be abolished, and supporting arms and services will be reduced. Across the Army at large various schools and training centres are facing closure while all military district headquarters around Australia will be dis-established. Not since the 1930s have the Australian Army and the Air Force faced such debilitating cuts to their operational capabilities and logistic infrastructure. Only the Navy's recent Gulf involvement and the need to man the new submarines, frigates and aircraft, for which commitments have been made have saved the RAN from a similar fate.

The so-called ready reserve referred to earlier is certainly no answer to these appalling inadequacies. According to an Army signal of 22 February in my possession ready reserves are seen to have the potential to provide a third option for manning appropriate parts of the Australian Defence Force. In fact, the ready reserves are neither fish nor fowl and if implemented will detract from both the existing regular and reserve forces. This is especially so given that the ready reserves are expected to have regular officers but draw on the general resources of the reserves.

The same signal states that ready Reserves would `undergo full time service for about a year' and then give `six weeks without evening and weekend training and three weeks with some weekend and evening training'. Given the known reluctance of many employers to release employees for Reserve training, especially in the present economic climate, their enthusiasm for a heavier and more jumbled release arrangement is highly questionable.

Finally, the Hawke Government apparently aims particularly at attracting ex-Regulars and potentially unemployed school leavers to the ready Reserves. However, the record over many years shows that very few ex-regulars move into the Reserves as they are too busily establishing themselves in their new civilian careers. Moreover, as far as the attitude of school leavers to the ready Reserves is concerned, the Government's own ANOP Research Services Pty Ltd survey found that the major reservation many young people had with the concept was concern at the prospect of having to fight.

It has to be said that the ready Reserve concept does not sound as though it will be all that ready. Nor will this nation be ready for any form of defence contingency unless this accelerating destruction of our Defence Force is halted and reversed forthwith. Not only will Australia lack the balanced and adequate capability to project military power that the Gulf crisis amply demonstrated we still need, but we will become incapable of defending even the mainland. Future generations will curse those responsible for this betrayal of our fundamental ability to sustain our sovereignty as a nation. I seek leave to table the Army signal which I have quoted from during my speech and which the Minister already has in his possession.
Leave granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fitzgibbon Mr E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: -It is unfortunate that in his speech the honourable member for Deakin (Mr Aldred) has been diverted into attacking this Government's defence expenditure. It is equally unfortunate that the honourable member does not have a better understanding of what he is talking about. The weight of expenditure and the capacity of a fighting force are not always commensurate. Many multimillionaires without expertise have failed dismally, so money is not of crucial importance. Nor is the numerical strength of the force indicative of its fighting power. Saddam Hussein had one million troops, but caved in like a pricked balloon. It is how people use their money and how they use their men that really counts. This country has a better trained fighting force than at any moment in its history.
—What's left of it.

—The honourable member should not take my word for it; he can ask any general. He can ask General Gration, General Grey or any of the other generals or experts in dealing with matters of Australian defence capacities.
—They have all been gagged.
—It is most unfortunate that the honourable member did not take the time to attend last week the El Alamein exercise, where we saw the true firepower of our Army and the Royal Australian Air Force.
—I was in Puckapunyal the week before.

—The point that the honourable member should realise is that the Australian defence forces have more sophisticated weapons than they have ever had at any time in their history. He had better believe it. We are doing a great job in defence. If the honourable member tries to attack us and denigrate us on that score, he will fail lamentably.

SPEECH.PARA: Appropriation Bill (No. 4) and related Bills seek additional provisions to meet payments for additional services. Expenditures covered include such things as the Gulf war and emergency aid for victims of that ghastly but necessary conflict.

I am pleased to see that the appropriations include an amount of $12.9m for trade training, of which $10m is for additional pre-vocational course places at technical and further education (TAFE) colleges and $1.8m for out of trade training centres. In my electorate of Hunter, in addition to three TAFE colleges at Maitland, Cessnock and Singleton, we have the Hunter Valley Training Co. Pty Ltd, which operates out of Maitland and spreads throughout New South Wales, training young apprentices and hiring them out where their services are required.

As at 31 March this year, the Hunter Valley Training Co. had 905 apprentices on its books and trainees under the Australian traineeship scheme had completed their training. Last year, the Federal Government funded the Hunter Valley Training Co. with some $1.3m for group schemes plus craft and off-the-job training. Funding in the 1990-91 financial year so far is $182,500 for apprentices and $15,000 for Australian traineeship scheme participants. Additionally, nearly $776,000 has been allocated for off-the-job training. At a time when job losses are being experienced, we must not lose sight of the fact that we need a skilled work force. We cannot let our skilled people fall by the wayside. That would be to Australia's detriment when recovery commences. Despite the prophets of doom opposite, recovery will commence sooner than they would like.

I am pleased that it has been the Hawke Government that has introduced a national training scheme. Last November, after more than three years of working towards more consistency in training, the State Ministers accepted the Federal Government's suggestions to develop a national core curriculum for training across the nation and to establish a national framework for national consistency in the recognition of skills and accreditation of training courses, and agreed to review TAFE to ensure it operates in a commercial way and is responsive to industry needs. These decisions will open up the training system to enable it to better meet the nation's needs for new skills. One might ask, when there are so many jobs being lost, why this training is so important. As I said earlier, Australia cannot afford to lose its skilled work force. It will be that skilled work force that will be in such demand and will help turn Australia's economic situation around.

Another major initiative of the Hawke Labor Government to increase Australia's capacity to compete in the world with a more highly skilled work force is the training guarantee, which came into effect on 1 July 1990. The training guarantee requires businesses with a payroll of more than $200,000 a year to spend one per cent each year on approved training. That amount would rise to 1 1/2 per cent next year, but I believe everyone will recognise that training of the work force is an investment to which all businesses and enterprises should contribute a fair share. The net result of training is increased productivity; and the Government, unions and business recognise the benefits to be gained from an increase in productivity across all sectors.

An additional $28.7m is required in Appropriation Bill (No.4) for Austudy. This sum is needed to cover the increased number of students in the latter half of 1990 and the increased number of students furthering their education in the first half of this year.

One of the greatest achievements of the Hawke Labor Government is the number of young people staying on to year 12 to complete their secondary education. The Budget projected that there would be 338,000 secondary students, but this has risen to 353,000 students. The Budget projected that there would be 407,000 students in higher education, but this figure has risen to 422,000 students. As well, covered under other assistance programs there are 44,000 Abstudy students, 9,000 migrant students, 2,000 veterans' dependants and 13,600 isolated children receiving assistance. I wonder whether such worthy schemes would continue if those opposite were given the opportunity to hand more money to the wealthiest members of our society.

The Hawke Government certainly can be proud of its record in education. As a direct result of Labor Government policy, the year 12 school retention rate has risen from a low 32 per cent in 1982 to 64 per cent in 1990. This means-and it has often been quoted-that about two out of every three students go on to complete year 12 these days, whereas under government by those opposite only one student in every three went on to complete secondary school education.

By 1992 Federal funding for schools will increase by almost $500m in real terms under the Hawke Labor Government. I am sure parents and students out in the community appreciate that fact. More than $2 billion a year is now spent on government and non-government schools, including special needs based programs for disadvantaged schools, disabled students, and hostel accommodation for isolated students. In higher education the Government will soon spend almost $4 billion a year on our nation's universities, and all this funding is being spent wisely.

It is worth noting that this represents an increase of 25 per cent in funding for higher education since 1988, the year preceding the major expansion announced in the Government's White Paper, which is an increase of 42 per cent since 1983. We are spending 42 per cent more on higher education than the conservatives were prepared to spend. They preferred, and this is their judgment, to give pensions to millionaires. Between 1988 and 1993 about 70,000 additional student places will be created for Australian students, which is the equivalent of creating seven new universities. Yes, the Opposition is rightly shamed by the magnitude of this Government's achievements.

I remind honourable members on the other side that the Australian taxpayers fund our universities and therefore universities should be accountable for their activities to the taxpayers. The Government has ensured that institutional autonomy and academic freedom are protected. Funding of universities has been enhanced through annual funding negotiations between the Commonwealth and individual institutions on broad teaching and research profiles, thereby achieving a more equitable distribution of funds. Research is of vital importance and it is worth noting that funds for research purposes will be 156 per cent higher in real terms in 1993 than they were in 1989, and 247 per cent higher than was the case under the coalition government in 1983. The Opposition knows the need for funding for research, but never provided more than a pittance when it occupied the treasury bench.

The May 1989 science and technology statement committed the Government to providing increased funds for research infrastructure and postgraduate research awards. Further funds for postgraduate research awards were provided in the 1990-91 Budget. These statements should quell any doubts that research is being downgraded under the new arrangements; the evidence gives the lie to that fear. This Government recognises the value of research and is committed to funding research in our universities.

I came across some other interesting statistics which indicated that the number of arts students increased by 33 per cent, from only 83,000 in 1980 to 110,000 in 1990, with the most rapid growth being in the bachelor and higher degree levels. I could say a great deal more about education, but I am afraid my time is slipping by rather quickly.

I will not go into greater detail about the report brought down by the Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training other than to say that I am delighted the Committee has decided to look on the current parental income formula used to assess eligibility for the Austudy allowances. There is no question that that matter needs to be re-examined.

I am afraid I cannot say much more about such matters; however, I want to speak on matters other than education. I note that in Appropriation Bill (No. 5) $75m is required for natural disaster relief. This amount will bring the Commonwealth allocation to $155m this financial year. Earlier this year widespread flooding occurred particularly in New South Wales and Queensland. Only two weeks ago I attended a meeting of delegates from the flood stricken areas of New South Wales, and it struck me how wildly unpredictable our weather is. There we were in the midst of a drought talking about flood mitigation works, but I agree with the delegation that now is the time to talk about flood mitigation works to prevent disasters such as those which occurred at Nyngan, Dubbo and other parts of New South Wales and north Queensland.

I am pleased to see that the figure for New South Wales includes $28m for restoration works in Newcastle following the devastating earthquake of December 1989. Members unfamiliar with the Newcastle area will be delighted to learn that people there have worked courageously and successfully to restore their city's pride and beauty. It is also pleasing to note that this Government has made considerable expenditure outlays towards road works severely damaged by floods, and to help farmers and small business people who are receiving assistance for the restoration of damaged working assets.

Appropriation Bill (No. 5) also includes an amount of $14m for a higher level of assistance for pharmacy restructuring. I am glad that fight has been resolved and that everything seems to be working fairly harmoniously within the pharmacy industry.

Recently I had the pleasure of accompanying the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys) on a visit to my electorate. The purpose of the Minister's visit was to present plaques to the Returned Services League (RSL) sub-branches in Maitland, Cessnock and Singleton. At each venue the Minister was welcomed by considerable numbers of ex-service men and women. The Minister explained the concept behind the move to make the repatriation general hospitals State based. Although there is some dissension among the RSL movement, Sir William Keys and the overwhelming majority of RSL personnel in my electorate have supported the concept. I think the leaders of the RSL movement need to come out to country areas and see what the membership thinks. After the Minister had explained the situation fully to the people whom he addressed, there was general support for what he was proposing.

Other matters regarding the Veterans' Affairs portfolio were addressed by the Minister. I am pleased to say that most of the veterans and returned service personnel in my electorate are most satisfied with the way in which the Minister is trying to benefit them.

I am delighted that the Singleton army base in my electorate has been so well treated. I am very pleased about the close liaison and friendship that I have developed with so many defence personnel in the Hunter Valley. Mr Deputy Speaker, the time available to me has gone too quickly.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Costello Mr P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 1990-91, the Appropriation Bill (No. 5) 1990-91 and the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2) 1990-91 appropriate additional money to meet expenditures additional to those made under Appropriation Bills Nos 1, 2 and 3 and the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill which were brought down as part of the Budget.

SPEECH.PARA: The Budget was brought down on 21 August last year and in the short time that has elapsed Australia has gone into deepening economic crisis. That deepening economic crisis has meant that most of the fundamental economic assumptions underlying the Budget and the Budget strategy have changed significantly. Yet, the Government seems paralysed, unable to come to grips with the changing, deteriorating state of the Australian economy and unable to show any leadership to the Australian people who are suffering so badly at the current time.

We have in rural Australia a crisis as severe as we have ever seen-a collapse in prices in wheat; a collapse in prices in wool. This feeds into country service centres where people who service rural producers are no longer able to make good incomes. We are seeing a basic wind-down in rural infrastructure. The mood in rural Australia at the moment is one of desperation. And rural Australia looks to this Parliament, it looks to this Government and it finds no answers.

We see this crisis in rates of bankruptcy. When the most recent bankruptcy statistics were released-those that went to March 1991-we found that the increase in bankruptcies to March 1991 on March 1990 throughout Australia as a whole was 52 per cent. That increase of 52 per cent of the March 1991 quarter over the March 1990 quarter did not come off a low base. It came off a base that was already up to record highs. Yet, there has been a wave of bankruptcy which has gone through the Australian community.-Bankruptcy is the very last step taken by a person who is in desperate financial circumstances. It is a step that people take when they cannot pay the money that they owe to creditors. Significantly, they put most of their personal assets on the line.

I have been pressing the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) to provide figures in relation to company liquidations. He is unable to do so. But if we were able to look at company liquidations, we would see a similar story. Company liquidations are a measure of the financial crisis that is confronting small and medium sized business in Australia at this very time. The ANZ Bank's annual report shows that a large provision had been made for bad debts. The chairman who brought down that report made it clear that many of those bad debts were in the small and medium sized sector of the Australian economy. Yes, we have heard about the major corporate collapses-the collapses of the big corporate conglomerates. But as was pointed out in that report, a surge of liquidation has gone through small and medium sized business in Australia.

Indeed, in that respect, the chairman of the ANZ Bank referred to a shopping precinct in my electorate, namely High Street, Armadale, once the premier speciality shop area in the city of Melbourne and now devastated because of harsh financial times and depressed consumer sentiment. It is suffering the double whammy of not only the Federal Labor Government but also the disgraced and discredited Victorian Labor Government. If one were to walk up that shopping centre at the moment one would see empty shops, not because the proprietors in those shopping centres have behaved irrationally or intemperately but because they were victims of a deliberate government strategy to wind up interest rates and depress consumer demand.

The Treasurer (Mr Keating) has sent surging through the Australian economy, as a result of his interest policy, a wave of bankruptcy, a wave of forced business sales and a wave of company liquidation in what rates as one of the worst recessions that Australia has ever had. This Government has hung out to dry the small and medium sized business sector in Australia.

Of course, in its defence the Government says that as a result of this high interest rate policy, as a result of this determination to dampen consumer demand, we are starting to see some good effects-a wind back in the rate of inflation, a wind back in the balance of payments. The balance of payments figure that came out this week showed a loss of only $1.2 billion. A great improvement! For that month we showed a loss of only $1.2 billion. It is a mark of how bad things are in Australia when we now welcome a loss for one month of $1.2 billion as a great result which is consistent with the Treasurer's policy.

Even though that result showed that there was now a surplus in merchandise trade, what is driving the current account into deficit month on month, year on year, is the accumulating foreign debt that we owe. And month on month, year on year, Australia must service that debt. Even if Australia breaks even on its monthly trading account, the money it sends out to service past debts drives that current account into deficit and that deficit on the current account drives that debt higher.

In 1983 net foreign debt stood at about $23 billion or 13.7 per cent of gross domestic product. By 1990 it had risen to $126 billion or about 34.3 per cent of GDP-about a threefold increase in the percentage of GDP over the term of the Hawke Labor Governments. As a result of that, each month Australia has to service past debts, which takes away from its current trading position.

This country is in a debt trap. The situation is akin to a householder who, unable to pay the interest component on his mortgage, adds the interest to capital. The capital continues to rise, the cost of servicing continues to rise and month after month the debt increases as past servicing costs are not met and future servicing costs are increased. A householder in a debt trap eventually loses the house. A nation in a debt trap eventually loses control of its own domestic economic policy. This is the crisis that will confront Australia unless strong and decisive measures are taken to reverse it.

It is particularly regrettable that we are now seeing the effects of the Government's economic policy flow on into the labour market-an unemployment rate of 9 per cent which will probably shortly go to 10 per cent; and youth unemployment at record levels. The official rate of youth unemployment-that is, people under 20 years of age looking for full time work in Australia-is around 25 per cent. That means that one in four young Australians is unable to get a job. But if we extract figures out and produce a real rate, that is, adding back job losers who did not become listed as unemployed and who otherwise disappear from labour force estimates, we find it is as high as 35 per cent and in the city of Melbourne it is 45 per cent. In other words, nearly one in two young people under 20 is unable to get full time employment. These figures are of crisis proportions.
When the Treasurer introduced his Budget Bills, the Appropriation Bills Nos 1, 2 and 3, on 21 August 1990, he had this to say:
Australia has negotiated a difficult transition over the past 12 months-from an economy where spending and growth were overblown to an economy with lower activity and fewer imports.
Tonight I am able to report-
said the Treasurer-
that we are emerging from this phase in fundamentally better shape having succeeded in this transition.
Some transition; some success! He went on to say, on 21 August 1990:
Economic policy has worked and is working.
The faith the Australian people exhibited in the Government at the election is now being repaid as the economy adjusts to a sustainable rate of growth without a catastrophic collapse.
Of course we have no real growth in Australia at the moment; we do have a collapse. Then the Treasurer boasted:
This year inflation will fall further, the current account deficit will markedly improve and employment will pick up.

On 21 August 1990, `employment will pick up'. Look at the unemployment rates in the meantime. We are nearly eight months into this financial year, and employment is not picking up. The Treasurer boasted:
. . . in short, the kind of outcome the Government was seeking, delivered without the misery and despair of high unemployment and a savage recession.
This was delivered with the misery and the despair of high unemployment and a savage recession.

The Treasurer stands condemned by his own words and the people of Australia want to know how did he get it so wrong; how did the Treasurer, with all of the vast resources that he had in the Treasury Department and all of his wisdom, stand up on 21 August 1990 and get it so wrong? How is it that Australians have had to pay for the errors that the Treasurer has forced upon them with his economic policy?

In Australia we have had a serious level of corporate collapse. Some of that corporate collapse has involved straight-out, old-fashioned fraud, and whilst that was going on, this Government was turning a blind eye. When I hear in this Parliament of the 15 June 1987 fundraising lunch with Premier Burke, Mr Roberts of Multiplex, Laurie Connell, Alan Bond and Mr Dempster, I do not think that Mr Burke was at that fundraising lunch lecturing on the need for high corporate standards in Australia. He was not there on 15 June telling those people that what we needed to avoid in the Australian economy was warehousing, exorbitant management fees, high debt in companies and explosive gearing. He was there courting those people, giving an imprimatur to those kinds of activities and a kind of activity that has been very destructive in the Australian economy.

Of course we see a level of financial collapse which is very disastrous throughout much of southern Australia. Not only do we have the Western Australian Royal Commission into Commercial Activities of Government and Other Matters looking into corporations that were involved in questionable deals, but also in South Australia we have an investigation into how the State Bank in that State there managed to lose-what was it-$700m or $800m. In Victoria we have a royal commission trying to look at how the State Bank of Victoria was wiped out by the operations of the Tricontinental corporation, which was a merchant banking arm government owned through the State Bank. And, of course, in Victoria it was not just Tricontinental; there was also the OST Friendly Society that went down and the Pyramid Building Society, which figured in a level of financial collapse that we probably have not seen since the 1890s.

One of the things I regret is that the term `entrepreneur' now has nasty connotations in Australia because it came to be applied to those people who, during the bull run on the stock market in the 1980s, geared companies with gay abandon for shareholders and creditors. As a result, the word `entrepreneur' is tarnished. But what we need in Australia is more entrepreneurs, honest entrepreneurs-people who are prepared to take their savings and invest them in a business, create a job, sell a product and get this economy moving again. Until we have an environment in which people feel that they can go out and look after themselves and create a job for somebody else, we are not going to do anything to get this economy moving.

What do we do with people who want to go out and look after themselves and create a job and create a product? We charge them rates; we levy charges; we impose sales tax on their products. They pay workers compensation premiums. If they get big, they pay payroll tax. They take income tax out of their employees' wages for the Australian Taxation Office. They pay fringe benefits tax to the Taxation Office if their employees have fringe benefits. If they make any money, they pay income tax. If they sell off their business, they have their capital gains taxed. If they have employees, they take 3 per cent out of their wages for superannuation, and now another one per cent will be taken out for a training levy. I often wonder how it is that we have people in Australia who are brave enough to go out and create jobs.

This Government seems to think that employers are just the goose that will continue to lay the golden egg, that it can just keep piling obligation after obligation onto the employment relationship for whatever goals it happens to have at this particular time, and that somehow these businesses will just continue to function and continue to provide jobs and maybe make a profit at the end of the day. The Government cannot do it. It cannot ask people to assume all of those social obligations, to assume all of those economic penalties, to look after themselves, and at the same time to make a profit and create employment. What we need to do in this Parliament is rediscover the real entrepreneur; we need to rediscover where wealth is created in the community; we need to think a little bit more about creating wealth before we think about spending it.

I heard the previous speaker, the honourable member for Hunter (Mr Fitzgibbon), say how the Government had spent this and the Government had spent that and that it was great that this Government had spent so much money. This was not the Government's money. The Government did not manufacture it; it did not earn it. What the Government did was tax people who were out there making it and earning it. If there is nobody out there making it and earning it, the Government is not going to be taxing it; and if it is not taxing it, it is not going to be spending it.

There ought to be a general reassessment on the Government side of the House as to where the wealth, the jobs, the profits, the investments, the products and the recovery are going to come from in Australia over the next 12 months. This is a Government marked by absolute complacency, a Government that is complacent in all of its dealings, a Government that has lost sight and really lost hope-lost hope about doing anything in relation to getting that productive environment in Australia going.

I listened to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) this afternoon talking about how it was necessary if waterside workers were going to accept detrimental changes in their conditions that they be rewarded for doing so. Nobody could dispute the proposition that employees ought to be rewarded for work. I think what the Government has forgotten is that it is not the waterside workers, with whom it seems to be obsessed at the moment; it is the wage and salary earners right throughout Australia who need some kind of incentive to produce more and to work harder.

There is no way in Australia at the moment that, if one is covered by an award, works hard and works more productively, one will get a pay increase. The way one gets a pay increase under an award is that Bill Kelty sits in the Cabinet room with Paul Keating and they work out an accord mark 6, 7, 8, 9, 9B, 9C, 9D or whatever it is going to be. Then one might get a pay increase. But one does not get a pay increase aside from that if one happens to be working well or more productively down in the enterprise.

What we have to get down in the enterprise is some kind of reward for effort. Personally, I am and always have been a great believer in employee share ownership plans, plans by which employees have a direct stake in the enterprise so that they know that their efforts, if they produce profitability, will come back to them in increased remuneration.

That would be one of the ways in which you could get some incentive for wage and salary earners back at the enterprise level. But the deal that this Government has in mind, negotiating macro wages policy with Bill Kelty in the Cabinet room-whether it is sanctioned by the Australian Industrial Relations Commission or not-is never going to produce that kind of enterprise, incentive or reward for the wage and salary earners of Australia. We have to direct our thinking to the wage and salary earners of Australia, to the entrepreneurs, to the small and the medium business sector.

We have to give those people an incentive to lead Australia back into recovery. One of the best things that this Parliament could do for a recovery in Australia is to vote out the Government. This Government is tired and complacent with a leadership that is defeated and divided as it looks to the next election, wondering whether it will go with Keating or with Hawke, with both of them, or with neither. This Government is paralysed by ongoing scandal. It is a Government which has lost the capacity to have strong and decisive leadership. This Government wasted time and in time it will be wasted. The people of Australia are looking for leadership. Unless they are given that leadership, and given it shortly, Australia will be very much the poorer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Mr L.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will refrain at this stage from responding to some of the comments from the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Costello)--
—Restrain yourself.

—It takes a bit of restraint, because they certainly do encourage one to explain a few of the facts of life to them. Honourable members opposite speak about leadership, yet they see their own leader on that side of the House, when he tries to get something through his own committee room--
—He can't.

—That is right. He gets rolled on a number of issues. I would like to speak on a number of aspects in relation to Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 1990-91, Appropriation Bill (No. 5) 1990-91, and Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2) 1990-91 which are before the House. It gives me great pleasure to have the opportunity to speak in support of Appropriation Bills (No. 4) and (No. 5) with the common theme that they encompass, that of ongoing dedication to the initiatives which matter most to Australian families. These are the people issues.

SPEECH.PARA: The people of Australia today need to be assured that the Government is giving more than just tacit support to the reforms and measures they read about in the daily paper. They need to know that the much needed restructuring of the country's pharmacies, for instance, is going to ensure that they have access to the medication that their families need when they need it. In these Bills, $14m is provided for a higher level of assistance for pharmacy restructuring. The assurance of access to needed medication was ratified on 6 December 1990 in an historic agreement between the Government and the Pharmacy Guild of Australia on a revised remuneration package and a restructuring of the retail pharmacy industry. This agreement saw the establishment of the Pharmacy Restructuring Authority to oversee the smooth reorganisation of pharmacy outlets and to ensure that ready access to needed medication was maintained.

Under that restructuring, costs are to be shared between the Government and approved pharmacists. With the agreement ending differences between the Government and pharmacists, there came to the pharmaceutical supply area a new era of stability and cooperation, to the significant benefit of consumers, which is of course very important.

Users of pharmaceuticals also benefited through revised remuneration arrangements: a reduction in the mark-up of drugs from 25 per cent to 10 per cent; reductions in the average cost margin, that is, the mark-up plus the fee, from $4.63 to $4.25; fees to be frozen for 18 months, after which time the fee would be indexed every six months by movements in award wages and the consumer price index, and a commitment by the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal to review remuneration by 1995.

In regard to any closures, I believe it needs to be emphasised that all closures or amalgamations of pharmacies are purely voluntary and that assistance is available to those eligible pharmacists who apply to the Authority. Eligibility is to be determined by the restructuring authority with the bottom line requirement being that no pharmacy that is deemed to be an essential pharmacy will be allowed to close to the detriment of people residing in remote areas.

I cannot stress this point strongly enough in light of the shameful scaremongering by some members of the Opposition which only serves to undermine the constructive reform measures that have been achieved to date. One only needs to look at the figures which document the success of these reforms to see how far off the mark the claims by these members of the Opposition really are.

Up to the end of March, 456 applications had been received for financial assistance towards the cancellation of approvals to supply benefits where pharmacists had chosen to close. There were 97 applications for the amalgamation of two or more pharmacies. This response from the retail pharmacy industry confirms the original judgment of the Guild and the Government in relation to the number of pharmacies operating at a less than efficient level.

Quite contrary to the claims of some members of the Opposition, the Government is genuinely concerned for those people living in remote areas with regard to their access to medical supplies. The payment of an essential pharmacy allowance has been specifically designed to achieve this. To the end of March, 226 pharmacies had also lodged applications for the essential pharmacy allowance.

Aside from those in need of medication, there is the other side of pharmacy closures-that of the staff currently employed in pharmacies earmarked for closure or amalgamation. Therefore provision is specifically made in the agreement with the pharmacists for packages to be made available to affected staff. In fact, the payment of financial assistance to a pharmacist who chooses to close or amalgamate is conditional upon the pharmacist agreeing to provide redundancy packages to affected staff.

One final point I wish to raise regarding the baseless claims of these uninformed members of the Opposition is that the Government has no control over pharmacy trading in isolated areas. It cannot compel people to trade and it cannot prevent the unassisted closure of essential pharmacies. The Government can work with pharmacists in a constructive way to ensure a guaranteed supply of pharmaceuticals to all Australians. The information I have provided shows that the Government is doing just that.
