Parents need to know, when it comes to their children wanting to further their practical skills to enhance career prospects, that they will not be limited by a shortage of places. Through this legislation a further $12.9m is proposed for trade training, of which $10m is for additional prevocational course places at technical and further education (TAFE) colleges, and $1.8m for out-of-trade training centres.

Reflecting the Government's desire to have a well-skilled work force in a wide range of areas, it is proposed that this money be spent in a broad range of practical skills areas. One measure, that of assistance for employers to retain apprentices who are vulnerable to dismissal, is scheduled to commence in 1991-92 at an expected cost of $1.6m. Our proud commitment to practical skills training continues. There is an additional $0.6m in 1990-91 and $1.2m in 1991-92 to assist unemployed apprentices and trainees complete their theoretical training in TAFE. There is an additional $1.8m in 1990-91 and $7.2m in 1991-92 to assist unemployed apprentices complete both theoretical and practical aspects of their training at non-TAFE centres. There is an additional $0.5m in 1990-91 and $1.65m in 1991-92 to encourage employers to engage unemployed apprentices and trainees. There is an additional $10m in 1990-91 and $40m in 1991-92 for the provision of prevocational training places in TAFE.

The Government's emphasis on skills-based training to ensure Australia has the best prepared work force for our future is something which is bringing success across the country. I pay particular tribute here to the work of the practical skills outlets in my electorate of Oxley. Great success has been achieved in practical courses conducted jointly between the Ipswich TAFE and the local Skillshare funded unit, YUPI, which stands for young unemployed people of Ipswich. It is pronounced differently by different people.

Some of these courses include a successful catering outlet, which they have actually called Tuckerbox, and a fibreglassing course which produces canoes which are, in turn, hired out at Lake Wivenhoe, which is a large dam north of Ipswich. Money is raised from the courses they run from these ventures on Lake Wivenhoe. It is a very successful venture indeed, and it certainly gives the young people a lot to do. As well they learn a lot of new skills. Reflecting this success was the recent announcement at YUPI's annual general meeting that in its first three years of operation the unit's annual turnover has more than quadrupled to over $1m.

In another part of my electorate of Oxley, recently I presented certificates to graduates of a storeman's course conducted through a Goodna unit funded via Skillshare. Importantly, the job placement rate on completion of courses is in the range of 80 to 90 per cent in most instances, which is a testament to the fact that the Government's push for practical skills training is the necessary ingredient for preparing Australia for long term stability in the work force.

With such success, it is surprising then that recent comments by Senator Michael Baume appear to go quite against this thrust. As our youth leave school and are deciding their career paths, it is stable and relevant practical training that will best prepare them for the years ahead. I find the honourable senator's suggestion that the best way to achieve this is to reduce wages for young workers so that more people can be employed a rather draconian step that takes working conditions back to the coalmining days of over 100 years ago-and we heard plenty over the last weekend, which was our traditional Labor Day Celebration, of what the trade union movement has done over the last 100 years. For a start, if there are more workers, the amount of time that can be spent on each one is less and the standard of tuition suffers.

This is aside from the issue of wages and conditions people should have to work under. That this issue has been raised in the centenary year of the Australian Labor Party is very timely, for at a time when we are reflecting on the achievements that have been won by the union movement in Australia in the last 100 years it is repressive to suggest that those basic rights be taken away and sweatshop conditions be put in their place, as suggested by the industrial relations proposal of the Opposition.

Turning to another phase of continuing education, reflecting the Government's desire to increase accessibility to Austudy for those students wishing to further their education, the legislation before us seeks to provide an additional $28.7m for Austudy, reflecting increased numbers of recipients in the latter half of 1990 together with an anticipated increase in the first half of 1991. The Austudy program has been very successful since its commencement in 1987. It is expected that over 350,000 students and their families will receive assistance in 1990-91. This represents a 9.5 per cent increase over the previous year, with the money provided for Austudy in this Bill catering for this higher than expected increase in the number of students receiving assistance.

The increase in the number of beneficiaries has been caused by a number of factors, including higher than expected enrolments in the tertiary education sector; higher retention rates for years 11 and 12; improved marketing and information materials leading to increasing numbers of eligible secondary students applying under the scheme; increased program recognition-a recent survey by the Australian Nationwide Opinion Polls Pty Ltd found that Austudy has the highest level of recognition amongst 15-to 24-year-olds of all government programs directed at youth.

Whilst speaking on Austudy, I would like to add my support to some comments mentioned earlier by honourable members in relation to the recent report on Austudy by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training, because it is an outstanding report and a credit to those members on the Committee, and certainly the honourable member for Chifley (Mr Price), who chaired the Committee. These achievements in education in a practical and tuition sense clearly show which side of politics has the people side of decisions in mind when planning an education framework.

Earlier today, the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Beazley) introduced some Bills in the House, and I now turn to that question. To prepare Australia for the overhaul of our telecommunications framework and to ensure that the subscribers to telephone services are provided with the smoothest possible transition to the new system, there is provision in this legislation for $25m for the Government to purchase Telecom's equity in Aussat Pty Ltd. While the parts of this Bill that relate to the Government's decision to purchase Telecom's 25 per cent shareholding in Aussat following the decision to sell Aussat together with the second network carrier licence are essentially mechanical ones, there is behind this a genuine concern that consumers of telecommunications services be given enhanced services with the greatest expediency and efficiency. One only needs to look at the standard adopted by the Australian Labor Party in relation to tele- communications at the special national conference last year.

Encompassing those principles, this Government is committed to providing universal access to telecommunications services across Australia. The Government considers that, further to this, services should be provided efficiently and at the lowest possible cost to consumers with quality of service and in a manner consistent with the early introduction of new technologies. Telecommunications is very much a people issue. Elderly people who live on their own rely on telephones for conversation, keeping in contact with their friends and relatives, or simply for peace of mind to know that it is there in times of need. Similarly, telecommunications allow people who are isolated to obtain information. It gives them an avenue for social interaction; it keeps them in touch.

In my electorate of Oxley, there are people who are less than 150 kilometres from the State capital of Brisbane; yet had they not ready access to a telephone, they may as well be 1,050 kilometres away. These people are sometimes the last surviving descendants of a family who settled in the area more than 100 years ago and it becomes an issue of family pride for them to remain in their homes.

Earlier this year, there was the same dependence on efficient telecommunications services when flash flooding in the south-east corner of Queensland meant that people living in the Brisbane Valley area and surrounds were temporarily cut off from Ipswich, the nearest large city. I am grateful that these residents were subject to flooding only for a matter of days and not weeks, as was the case with some of the more severe flooding that occurred in other parts of Queensland and New South Wales. In any case, for these people the provision of basic telecommunications services is not a luxury but a necessity. I am pleased to speak on legislation which relates to part of the restructuring which will ultimately see a much improved telecommunications network in Australia with ensured access to the services people need.

The Government is extremely mindful of the lessons learned from overseas experience in telecommunications reform and has specifically ensured that consumers will not be disadvantaged through the guarantee of community service obligations, particularly to rural and regional areas and, of course, to pensioners.

Another facet of the telecommunications restructuring that will bolster the provision of services for all Australians and prevent a deterioration in access to telecommunications services is the Government's intention to maintain Telecom in full public ownership. In addition, should it become necessary to sell either in part or in full, or merge any other facilities to develop an effective competitive framework, the Government will do so. It is the Government's view that the maximum possible Australian involvement in the telecommunications industry should be strived for so as to further develop the industry locally.

To this end the Government is pleased with the positive views of overseas interests and will seek firm commercial proposals by bidders for Australian ownership arrangements and levels, and will subsequently negotiate appropriate binding commitments with the selected licensees. This will allow the Government's firm commitment to ultimate majority ownership within five years to be achieved on a commercially realistic basis. On interconnect arrangements between Telecom-OTC and the second carrier, Austel will be asked to determine initial prices by mid-June 1991, prior to bidders submitting proposals. This allows bidders to develop more realistic business plans and submit firm bids. Austel is also examining technical arrangements for customers to choose equally between the two carriers and will advise further on revised regulatory provisions.

So as not to inhibit Telecom in the new environment, the Government will be removing from Telecom any government imposed constraints which may limit its ability to respond effectively to competition and which do not serve the broader national interest. With regard to the second new carrier, the Government announced recently that detailed proposals from interested parties were being sought to establish a second telecommunications carrier based on the purchase of Aussat. Again, the people side of telecommunications reform is reflected in the Gov- ernment's continued consideration of appropriate commercial arrangements to ensure maximum benefit for service users. Bidders will be asked to show how their proposals will lead to development opportunities for Australian industry, particularly in areas such as export, research and development for Australian manufacture.

Consumers of telecommunications services are to be further protected through the encouragement of future competition. This is exemplified in the Government's requirement that, where the second carrier's licence will require it to continue providing existing Aussat services such as remote area broadcasting, defence, Civil Aviation Authority and pay television, this will be on a commercial basis with charges reflecting the full cost of service provision. The second carrier will also be required to honour Aussat's contractual obligations to provide these services, with charges being subject to Austel arbitration where necessary.

The Government is also concerned for Australia's former service men and women and their families, as is reflected in the $41.3m set aside for the increased demand and fee increases for non-departmental hospital care for veterans, together with the increased costs in veterans' medical services. This money will specifically be spent on payments for veterans' medical services, reflecting the Government's recognition of an increase in demand for services, and $14.5m in payments is for patients in non-departmental institutions due mainly to increased demand and increased charges in public and private hospitals. These are the people who have given so much in their time of service and stood alone, along with many of their mates who gave the ultimate sacrifice.

The ones who did not return were recently remembered at the Anzac Day services across Australia. I place on record once again my thanks for the efforts made by our defence service men and women in the years gone by and, of course, by our existing Defence Force as well. As was reflected in our recent involvement in the hostilities in the Middle East, the Australian defence forces are a strong unit of which we can all be proud. It is only fitting, therefore, that for their contribution to Australia they be cared for adequately at their time of need. Through the provisions of moneys such as those proposed in this Bill this is being achieved. This commitment builds on many of the initiatives for veterans put in place by this Government since coming to office in 1983. A whole range of these issues have been covered previously.

The areas I have covered tonight are but some of those for which funding is provided in these Appropriation Bills. We see that common caring for the people implicated by decisions is at the heart of all the Government's initiatives. In today's complex society, it is so often the figures that take prominence in decisions. Yet it is the view of the Government that people are the most important part of decisions. Whether it be ensuring the supply of pharmaceuticals, providing a stable education environment to provide for a solid future, making sure new technologies are adapted with minimum disruption to users or caring for those citizens in need, this Government is intent on making the people the first priority when making decisions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 1990-91, the Appropriation Bill (No. 5) 1990-91 and the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2) 1990-91 cover substantial amounts of money in various areas. The speeches made on these matters are, by convention, quite wide ranging. Nevertheless, I note that there are specifically allowances and allocations made for grants to the States. Tonight I will direct many of my remarks to the administration of certain State governments.

SPEECH.PARA: Before starting it is worthwhile saying a few words about the honourable member for Oxley (Mr Les Scott). He wanted to rake up one of the old Australian Labor Party hardy annuals about sweatshops. If ever one wants to put an indictment on the Australian people who vote, start telling them that they have a chance of being returned to sweatshops. That says that they do not have one ounce of intelligence between them. I do not have much to say for the voters of the electorate of Oxley, because somehow or other they managed to elect the member for bogong moths. Nevertheless, I guess some of them there know what is going on. If they had a little more intelligence they would have elected someone a bit smarter, and there would be no way in the world they would accept a sweatshop environment. By international standards, we have a highly educated community. They will not buy it, and they do not have to.

The coalition parties are talking about giving those people a fair go. Is it not funny that the best paid manual workers in Australia are in places that do not have trade union representation? There used to be a time when trade union leaders were trade union leaders. They came up from the shop floor. Today they have all come straight from university. They have never done a day's work in their life. We have a line-up of them on the other side; I have called on them before. The honourable member for Oxley might not like this but I ask him whether he has ever done any manual work for a living.

TALK.START.PARA: —My word I have.

—He is one of the few. Nearly every honourable member opposite with a trade union background has never got one bit of grease under his fingernails. The reality is that they are trade union bureaucrats. Most of them are much more interested in their jobs than in the welfare of the people they are supposed to represent. The other night Bill Kelty told the collective trade unionists, `If we let the Industrial Relations Commission get away with this, we will lose all our power'. He used the word `power', and that is their problem.

SPEECH.PARA: Lincoln Electrics has been operating successfully in Australia for 70 years. It is a successful competitor on Middle East markets and in other parts of the world. What do we find here? There are no trade unions, but a business deal where the workers get 25 per cent of the pre-tax profits. They do not need Bill Kelty to hold their hand when they deal with the boss for the simple reason that they know about the 25 per cent. They do not have to change the 25 per cent in the Industrial Relations Commission every year. The harder they work, the more they improve the profits, the more money they get. They do not want the second cousin, first removed, of the honourable member for Oxley as a safety officer with a featherbedded job. They do not want him because they are not prepared to share the cake with him. They are prepared to share it only with productive workers.

For a long time, until Mr Goss got into power in Queensland, the workers at Power Brewing had a pretty good deal too. They were earning an extra $60 or $70 a week over and above the award. But that did not suit the mob opposite; it did not suit Mr Goss, who of course has 60 per cent of his preselection judged by trade unionists. We know that that is the way the Labor Party is structured. Not one of those opposite would be here without having suckholed up to the trade union movement. It has them where it wants them, but that is the problem of those opposite. Those opposite are so busy looking after the bureaucracy and the power of the trade union movement that they forget about the little people.

The first group of people that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) looked after were some of the elite of the industrial relations system-the wharfies. He got an increase for the best paid but he does not really know how to get something for the least paid. If anybody wants to be a wharfie and benefit in that wonderful pay scale, he can try but he will not get in. The unemployed cannot take their turn and get a little bit; it is a totally closed shop, a privileged elite. That is what the honourable member for Oxley is arguing for. And he talks about sweatshops. He would not know what one was. There is no need for them.

Our policy says, `Let people get some spending power back. Let them get it through productivity agreements and bonuses'. That is what we are talking about. The best thing that the honourable member can do for his wife and all the other women that go shopping in his electorate is get down the price of the goods that they buy at the supermarkets. Ninety per cent are manufactured by Australian workers. Every time those opposite jack up their wages without appropriate productivity improvements, the only beneficiary is the tax man, who gets his. All that those opposite want to do is boost wages to boost government tax revenue but they leave Mrs Brown with less buying power at the supermarket every time they do it.

Those opposite talk about sweat shops and this and that. The only people who have a genuine concern for individual Australian workers are the people on this side of the House. We want them to have more money. We know the only way they will get it is through productivity-not by borrowing $100 billion from the rest of the world to create another 1.5 million jobs, which are now all disappearing because those opposite cannot afford to borrow any more money. This Government has never created a real job.

As I said in my opening remarks, I want to talk about State finances. This legislation sends more money to the States. Two States in particular, Victoria and Western Australia, have thrown away billions on bad and corrupt business deals. We have been hearing about it with the WA Inc. royal commission.

I take honourable members back to some remarks I made in this Parliament some time ago. It became quite traumatic for me. Having criticised one of the WA Inc. players, Robert Holmes a Court, who was the first to get his very sophisticated, highfalutin snout in the trough, I saw one of the creeps of the Western Australian Labor Party, Norm Marlborough, attack my son and put his job opportunity and future at risk. He made scandalous remarks about my son being caught stealing software. When I asked this blockhead Marlborough, who has been a trade unionist and has followed that path into the Western Australian State Parliament, on radio what software was, he could not tell me. Under parliamentary privilege he was prepared to accuse someone of stealing something, but he did not know what it was. Of course, he was fed that information by the Holmes a Court family. An announcement was made on about page 10 of the West Australian the other day. Those opposite do not want too much said about it. The State Government Insurance Commission has now lost every cent of value of $150m worth of Bell bonds that it purchased in that outrageous deal it did to save the Holmes a Court family fortune.

Every penny has now gone. The bonds are worthless, as they were on the day they were purchased. But here was the State Government Insurance Commission, with $64m worth of assets, sitting down with the Labor Party's biggest WA Inc. donor, Robert Holmes a Court, finding $800m to buy the assets that he had to sell because he was flat broke. He had ramped up the value of everything until the share market crashed, he had no cash flow and he needed money desperately.

Because the chairman at the time- Wyvern, or Ollie, Rees-has lied continually to the Australian public and lied two days before the Auditor-General over there eventually came out with the actual documentation to prove his lies, we do not know how much the State Government Insurance Commission has lost on its other deals, namely, the $250m worth of BHP shares and the property it purchased. However, we know the loss on the Bell bonds must be about $230m, if we apply 15 per cent compound interest for the three-year period that they have gradually gone from their purchase price to nothing.

I have to say in this Parliament again that that very wealthy lady and widow of the late Robert Holmes a Court, Mrs Janet Holmes a Court, can still give the money back. She is out there swanning around as one of the richest women in Australia, getting her name in magazines and the paper every day, and it is to their shame that they give her the credibility that they do. Every penny that she has she owes to the Western Australian taxpayers, to people whose kids cannot get proper places in schools and to elderly people who cannot get proper treatment in hospitals because the Western Australian Government has not got any money.

It is noticeable that today one can drive around Perth and find that at nearly every second set of traffic lights one stops at some of the lights are not burning. The Government has not got enough money to keep up those safety features in Western Australia. That is because billions have been sucked out of the system by the WA Inc. players, with the concurrence of successive Labor Premiers, including the present one. It is an outrageous situation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I notice you are saying this under privilege.

—I am amazed that the Minister wants to interject and defend these people, because to date he has been reasonably credible: he is one of the few. Today we saw the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) get into the act and basically admit, although he wanted to put a different interpretation on the story, that in fact he tipped off Brian Burke that he had better resign before he had to go.

SPEECH.PARA: The facts of life are that this fellow Marlborough, who had a go at my kid, jumped up the other day and complained in the Parliament that some of the evidence given against David Parker, another one of the WA Inc. players and one time Labor Deputy Premier, should have been given in camera. He said, `Isn't it dreadful to have these people using the privilege of the Royal Commission to say scurrilous things about poor old David?'. David is the bloke who gave evidence that he used to keep $25,000 in cash in his drawer. One might wonder how dumb they think royal commissioners are.

However, the reality is that Marlborough suddenly had a change of heart, but methinks he protests too much. Every time one gets a bit close to some of the players, it is old Norm who gets up and starts to go crook and use scurrilous attacks on one's kids. I know a bit about him, too. He was in the trade union movement in the Pilbara. Every employer there has marked up his file `never to be re-employed'. I will tell honourable members the reason why. When there was industrial trouble and someone wanted to fix it in a hurry, he would go and see Norm and sling him a few dollars. It did not cost very much; he was such a meagre and horrible person. One could buy him off. I wonder whether he should be called before the Royal Commission, because one wonders what backhanders he has been taking. If he has not, it appears that he is the only one.
Mr Bilney interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member should not get into this, otherwise I will blame him as well. Does he want to defend these people? Those opposite have been carting money over here in chaff bags to help their election campaigns. I do not know, but I assume the honourable member did not get any. He is one of the few that did not. When we look at the list we see all the money that was dragged out of people. I say `dragged out of people'. The rule was very clear under Brian Burke in Western Australia: if one did business with government, one had better sling to the Labor Party. I have got letters on file. Consultants who had been dealing with government departments for years wrote to me during that time complaining that they had been given that sort of treatment: donate or else.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, there is an involvement for this Federal Government, because a substantial amount of its 1987 election campaign was funded from the Burke grants. The Prime Minister has stood up in this place and has said, `I sat down with four of the biggest scallywags in Western Australia'. I know them all; they are good blokes. I drink with them and I would trust their word ahead of the Prime Minister's. However, the Prime Minister sat down with them for lunch. It was a good team. There were two reformed drunks, both of whom are punters. For the information of the House, Brian Burke made his living, before entering parliament, selling tips at the races. That is his background-when he was sober enough to work it out. All of a sudden this person sits down with the Prime Minister and four entrepreneurs and they wanted to know about gold tax. And the Prime Minister tells us that they never raised the subject.

Let me tell this Parliament something: those four businessmen are also known to have a bet. When they have a bet, they bet with the bookies. I will tell honourable members why they bet with the bookies: they want to see the price; they want to know what value they are getting for their money. The Prime Minister comes into this place and says, `I never raised the subject of the gold tax; trust me on that'. Those blokes would not have let him out of the room with a million bucks if they thought they had not got a promise. In fact, it was not a million; it was $950,000, because one present, John Roberts, said, `I shouldn't have to donate the full quarter of a million. I haven't got any gold interests'. And they did not talk about gold, they did not talk about money! They would not have talked about anything else. It is a scandal and it is a shame, because the big losers are those people I started talking about-the little people.

A thousand million dollars have been lost in Western Australia, and possibly it will be more by the time we get to the end of it. We have situations where thousands and hundreds of thousands of dollars were being accounted for on the back of an envelope, but the envelope has now been conveniently lost, and memories seem to improve one day and disappear the next. That is just a simple fact.

Let me also refer to the infamous fishing trip. I do not know why the Prime Minister feels it is necessary to distance himself from Laurie Connell, but any suggestion that a Prime Minister goes out on a fishing boat, miles from shore, and does not know who is going to be on the boat is ridiculous. He would want to know for social reasons; he would want to know for security reasons.

The other day I asked the Prime Minister whether he had contacted Laurie Connell before that particular trip and I mentioned Wardleys Bank in Perth. While Laurie Connell was there on about 17 June-I cannot remember the date exactly, but it is diarised-at a special meeting, during that meeting he was called out, against his instructions, to take a phone call. I know that Connell was being urged to attend that fishing trip, either by the Prime Minister or the Premier of Western Australia on the Prime Minister's instructions.

It is time the Prime Minister came clean on these issues. They are not fundamental to the case; they just demonstrate his total lack of credibility on this issue. It is all right for the Leader of the House to get up today and try to throw some mud at Nick Greiner and others. There is a simple difference: when Nick Greiner was first asked whether he received corporate funding he answered, `Absolutely'. There was no beating about the bush, as the Prime Minister and others have done. He admitted it. Furthermore, I can bet that the money that was donated, whether at his request or someone else's, went into a bank account, not a manila envelope. This is the outrageous situation that we have here.

I repeat, because my time is running out, that the thing I am most concerned about is getting Mrs Janet Holmes a Court to give back the money that her husband robbed from the people of Western Australia, because he was the biggest donor to the Australian Labor Party and he could get the deal of a lifetime with valueless bonds and other items that were severely overvalued. I noted the other day that Mrs Holmes a Court is using some of those ill-gotten gains to buy Bell Freightlines.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you go outside the Parliament and say that?
—If the Minister wants to defend WA Inc., I ask him to put his name to it. I will be pleased to hear him.
—Go outside the Parliament and say it.

—Why do not some honourable members opposite do that? Do not worry about that. What I am saying is true. I am calling on the people of the north-west, whose schools are half closed down. Does the Minister deny that Robert Holmes a Court got $800m from the State Government Insurance Commission? If he does, he cannot read. He has been slinging to honourable members opposite, and that is on the record too. Did the Minister read the Sun today? It does not need to be said outside the Parliament.
—You're gutless, Wilson.
—I have not said a thing. The Minister is a dope. We have been through him before. I have stood on the same platform as him on the identity card issue, and I did him like a dinner.
—Who won the seat?
—Order! I ask the Minister to remain silent.

—He lost it. The Government did not even know how to write the law. The Minister is such an idiot. Where has he been? He is the invisible man. Anyway, Bell Freightlines is about to be bought by Mrs Holmes a Court. If people in the north-west who are battling for their schools and hospitals use that freight line, they want their heads read. They have to start to protest in Western Australia. Our newspapers have to start writing some editorials asking for the money back. We have people with $800m-people whom this Minister apparently supports. He is quite happy to see the people of Western Australia lose $1,000m because an entrepreneur got $800m.
