SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Mr H.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The debate on Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 1990-91 and cognate Bills is a similar debate to the one five years ago during which I made my maiden speech.
—It was a good speech, too.

—I thank the Minister for Arts, Tourism and Territories. There are some things which do not change in regard to the way this House conducts its business. Often those matters are best ignored, but later on I will pick up on some of the points that the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) made early in his speech.

SPEECH.PARA: In my speech back in 1986 I touched on six themes, which I want to revisit in my speech tonight. One of my colleagues to whom I indicated my intention earlier today said that I was taking very much of a risk and that it was, perhaps, not appropriate to go back to one's initial comments and to reflect on the movement that had taken place on those things which one had aspired to achieve.

The six themes on which I spoke in my first speech in this place were: firstly, local government; secondly, the importance of child-care; thirdly, the special needs of migrants and ethnic communities in general; fourthly, occupational health and safety; fifthly, peace and disarmament; and, sixthly, the adoption by this Government of a social justice strategy.

I would like to take some time to reflect briefly on each of those themes. As one of the many members who have previously played an active role in local government before coming to this place, I have long held the view that local government ought to be recognised as a partner in the implementation and planning of a wide range of services. Thus I welcomed the presence of local government at the Special Premiers Conference last year as a recognition of the role of local government in this partnership.

Over the past three years the Office of Local Government and the Australian Local Government Association have been working together to identify how better to integrate local government in Commonwealth program planning. In 1989 the Government initiated annual consultations between the Commonwealth and local government to provide an intergovernment forum in which issues of mutual concern could be discussed.

This is a promising beginning, but there is a need for far greater effort to reform bureaucratic duplication and inefficiency due to the overlap of the three spheres of government. Partly, this is being addressed by the present discussions about Commonwealth-State relationships, which local government has been asked to participate in as a result of the Special Premiers Conference.

I am pleased that last week the Government rejected the recent Commonwealth Grants Commission proposal for the distribution of local government funding among the States. This would have had catastrophic effects, especially on local government in Victoria and New South Wales. I think that in fairness to the Commission I should say that in its report it recognised the shortcomings of the methodology that it used. It will now be for government to address some of the perceived inequities that led to the Commission's being asked to investigate the matters before it.

There is a need for redistribution of resources to areas of greatest need to enable councillors to provide increased support services. This simply cannot be done by a rejigging of the figures for funds distributed among the States, but it must take into account the overall possibilities and capabilities of local government throughout Australia.

The evolution of a more comprehensive role for local government, in partnership with both State and Federal governments, requires reform of local government practice. Tonight I will touch on two such areas. Firstly, local government should continue to think very seriously about the benefits of boundary restructuring. At the time of my first speech in this forum in 1986, in Victoria there was a rather emotive debate about local government boundary restructuring. That is a debate which has been shelved over the last five years. There is perhaps a need for local government to realise the benefits of rectifying the imbalances caused by the present boundaries, especially in Victoria, and to take an active role in suggesting ways in which those processes can be improved.

The second area I would like to flag is my belief in the need for the introduction of freedom of information legislation to cover local government as an aid to opening up government practices at the local level. Often when one is involved in parliamentary committee inquiries, one comes across a number of local discussions about items of interest. For instance, in the inquiry into coastal management and land degradation we came across some such discussions. Often there was a perception that the processes of local government were not as open as they could be. I stress that these are perceptions and often they are incorrect. However, sometimes they have a basis. A form of freedom of information legislation for local government would ensure that the concerns of local communities would be eased.

Another area I would like to refer to is child-care. The Government has consistently recognised the need for affordable child-care. The number of child-care places has nearly tripled from 46,000 in 1983 to 125,000 in 1991. In the electorate of Scullin we have moved from one publicly funded child-care centre to five-plus one that will be built at Mill Park in the future. Industry has also been encouraged to become involved in assisting with the provision of child-care centres. It is interesting to note the release of a report showing that there is a change in attitude by industry to employer sponsored child-care. Now 45 per cent of private sector companies support it. That type of support in principle is to be encouraged and turned into practical projects on the ground. I know that the successful project that was put in place by the Ford Motor Co. of Australia Ltd in Broadmeadows was of benefit in providing child-care places not only for its work force but also for the neighbouring community.

By 1995 there will be a quarter of a million funded child-care places, including long day and before and after school care programs. Recently two after school care programs were commenced at Norris Bank Primary School and Diamond Creek Primary School in my electorate as a joint project with the State Government. These are examples of successful implementation of what is seen as an important type of child-care.

The fee relief system in particular has ensured affordable child-care to low and middle income families. During 1990 the upward ceiling for fee relief was raised. This benefits some 90,000 families. In addition, a further 30,000 families will benefit from the decision to allow commercial child-care centres to participate in the fee relief scheme. The Government will introduce a national accreditation scheme to ensure that high standard, quality care is given in the centres.

The third theme I wish to turn to is the provision of services to the ethnic communities. Some 31 per cent of the population of the electorate of Scullin was born overseas. In 1989 the Government outlined a continuing commitment to access and equity in its multicultural agenda for Australia. We must renew our efforts to pursue the goals of the national agenda. All Australians should enjoy equal life chances and have equitable access to and an equitable share of the resources which governments manage on behalf of the community. All Australians should have the opportunity to participate fully in society and in the decisions which directly affect them. A great deal more work is needed before it can be said that these objectives have become a reality.

Economic hardship strikes hardest at those most disadvantaged. Often people from migrant communities are among the most disadvantaged job seekers. In the present economic climate that is most clearly illustrated. Many of the people who are subject to redundancies and loss of jobs from my electorate are migrants who came here in the post-Second World War period. They are people who have been at their places of employment for 20 to 30 years. They are often people who will have difficulty re-entering the work force because of their lack of literacy skills. Whilst they have been part of a company for 20 or 30 years which has engendered a family spirit that has given them a sense of belonging and a sense of being able to cope with their limited skills, now that they are out in the competitive world trying to make the best of limited job opportunities they are very much a disadvantaged group that stands out and calls for attention.

The Government is tackling the difficult issues such as the recognition of overseas qualifications, as well as optimising migrants' English levels, with a greater emphasis on English acquisition immediately on arrival. It must be emphasised that there is a need for further significant strengthening of the access and equity strategy. I am pleased to note that currently the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hand) is conducting community consultations on the settlement needs of migrant Australians. I think that is an appropriate way in which the views and needs of migrant Australians, and the ethnic communities in general, can be assessed. I hope that out of this community consultation the Minister is able to put together proposals that can be considered by the Government that will ensure that the hopes and aspirations of migrant Australians can be achieved.

The fourth theme that I spoke about in my maiden speech was occupational health and safety. It was in the context of a problem within the Public Service with repetition strain injury, which was reaching epidemic proportions. The Government has demonstrated a commitment to improving the standards of occupational health and safety by reducing the incidence and severity of occupational injury and disease. One of the most important initiatives has been the establishment of Worksafe Australia-the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission. Worksafe Australia has a number of important tasks which include developing common approaches to occupational health and safety legislation, coordinating national preventative strategies, conducting research, education and training, and collecting and disseminating information to workplaces.

Worksafe Australia has developed strategies to attack major occupational health and safety priorities such as occupational back pain, noise-induced hearing loss, occupational skin disorders, the management of chemicals at work, and mechanical and equipment injury. Whilst the honourable member for O'Connor berated the comment of the honourable member for Oxley (Mr Les Scott) about the return to sweatshop conditions, one has only to consider the Hoechst Australia Ltd dispute in the western suburbs of Melbourne to remember the problems with incorrect and careless management practices in the handling of dangerous chemicals.

I do not say that what we engender by the talk of sweatshops is a picture of late last century and before, but certainly industrial practices such as have been seen earlier this year at Hoechst indicate that there is a real need to ensure that work practices and the occupational and health considerations of Australian workers are very much to the fore.

The fifth theme that I spoke about in my maiden speech was foreign policy, especially matters of peace and disarmament. The dramatic events of recent years have led to what many regard as a new world order based on greater cooperation between nations and, in particular, an enhanced role for the United Nations. This new order, such as it is, has yet to stand the test of time and meet the challenges of peace, more importantly, as well as war. Just as Australia played a role through H.V. Evatt in the founding of the United Nations, Australia can play a role in ensuring that the United Nations rises to the challenges and fulfils the role originally intended for it.

This is also an historic opportunity for Australia to assert its independence on the world stage, an independence that perhaps has not been clearly demonstrated of late but that certainly is one we can work on and establish in global and international discussions on a wide range of foreign policy issues. On the morning of my maiden speech in 1986 there was an incident involving the bombing of Libya. The Middle East is still very much in our thoughts. I welcome the decision of the Government yesterday to send medical teams to assist in the Kurdish refugee camps.

The sixth theme that I touched upon in my maiden speech was a call for the adoption by the Government, especially the Australian Labor Party, at a national level, of a social justice strategy. At the conference that was held in June of that year the Party adopted a social justice policy. Subsequently, the Government adopted a comprehensive social justice strategy. The significance of this strategy has been increasingly felt in all aspects of government administration. There is the importance of social justice impact statements not only in the Budget but also in legislative processes. That is an indication of the Government's ongoing commitment.

Social justice issues become even more critical in hard times. Some of the aspects of the policy that have not been picked up as yet perhaps need emphasising because they are important and they will be important to the longer term goals of our social justice strategy. One is the notion of a national planning advisory council that could assist government by giving appropriate advice and feedback from the community about those goals that the community sees as very important.

To build on the basis of what we have done already over the past three years in the social justice area, we need to look at our goals and priorities for the next decade to the turn of the century. One of those key priorities is to address the problems of the ever-increasing urban areas of Australia. There is often a mismatch between the opportunities that are presented in those areas and the needs-a mismatch between the location of employment and the location of prospective employees, and between the location of training centres and those that can attend them. We have to make cities more equitable for the life expectations and chances of our community.

There is a need to develop a national revenue strategy to ensure that government revenue over this decade will be adequate to meet the designated social justice goals. In my first speech in this place, I quoted the words of James Henry Scullin, after whom my electorate is named. He said:
Justice and humanity demand interference whenever the weak are being crushed by the strong.

In the type of economic climate we have at the moment, I believe those words can be no more important than when James Henry Scullin wrote them back in the 1920s and 1930s. We need to be pro-active, we need to look at the types of policies that will create jobs and we need to look at ways in which we can encourage investment. I believe that, if we leave it to the private sector alone, we will not see the appropriate and needed type of investment injection into a number of things that will see Australia through to the twenty-first century. I have often talked about the need to direct in a small way superannuation investment as superannuation becomes an important income support source.

TALK.START.PARA: -Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford Mr F.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 1990-91, in particular page 58 of the Bill, divisions 668 and 669, Department of Transport and Communications-the Waterfront Industry Reform Authority and the Shipping Industry Reform Authority. The appropriation on these two items totals $107,829,000, yet the accompanying statement of savings nominates savings of a bare $218,000, a minor 0.2 per cent. Considering the lack of progress in these areas, it is scandalous.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to remind the House what these appropriations cover. The explanatory notes on this portfolio say:

This Program enhances the competitiveness of the maritime and other sectors through promoting change directed to the safe, reliable, efficient and cost-effective carriage of freight and passengers to and from Australia and around Australia's coast; and the provision of more productive and reliable shore-based shipping operations.
That may have been the intent, but nothing has happened. The policy got lost-like the J-curve, like the bacon that never got home, and like the $8 billion surplus. They were all lost.

A little while back we had a statement called Building a Competitive Australia. That was also a fizzer, mainly for what it did not say. It did not address unemployment, interest rates, real taxation reform, our disastrous foreign debt or our over-regulated businesses. It did not adequately address dumping of products on our markets. It did not say, `We are the sick man of the Pacific'. It did boast, however, of success on the waterfront, and that is drivel. It is $108m down the drain.

The Government is congratulating itself on the deal, which it claims is a good deal for both employers and employees. What about the customer? There is no thought for or consideration of the most important people of all. The deal was not even accepted by all employees. Some do not like it. I quote from the 6 May `Wharfie Bulletin':
Tas Bull, John Coombs and the three Sydney Federal councillors Jim Donovan, Ron Anderson and Ken Rowsthorn owe it to the members to resign.
In other words, the `Bulletin' is disgusted with the deal that has been negotiated.

The $108m for waterfront reform is scandalous. Nothing is being achieved. People need only look at the other sectors of the community not receiving this sort of funding. Many people throughout this nation are desperate-in particular, farmers and small business people-their whole lives shattered through no fault of their own. They face ruin. They have lost everything, including, in some cases, even the will to struggle on. They are hurt, their health suffers, they are angry, they cannot sleep, they believe their plight has been ignored. And they are right. This institution has failed them completely.

All they hear and read from this Government is, `We are on track, our performance is the envy of the OECD'. Like me, they do not believe it. They still have to pay taxes. They still have to pay a myriad of State taxes. They still have to pay 50 per cent duty on their fuel and outrageous freight and handling charges. These charges are over and above the $107m appropriation in this Bill.

The whole country knows that Australia is the sick man of the Pacific and that micro-economic reform has not been implemented. The honourable member for Scullin (Mr Jenkins) admits that even in his electorate there are huge problems, especially unemployment.

When historians reflect on the record of this miserable Government, the area they will undoubtedly select for greatest condemnation is its abysmal record on micro-economic reform. Indeed, there are few matters which are more deserving of the attention of this Parliament than the structural flaws inherent in the Australian economy. The monumental incompetence of a government which has presided over the economic mismanagement of recent years will long remain testimony to its own self-serving greed and the supine attitude of its industrial masters, the trade union bosses and high flying financial subscribers.

Let us reflect for a moment on the record of the past few years. In September 1987, during an interview on the Midday Show, the world's greatest Treasurer, demonstrating his usual modesty, announced that he had engineered the great coming of age of Australia. According to the Treasurer (Mr Keating), the future was to be the golden age of economic change. As the Duke of Wellington replied when approached by a stranger in Hyde Park and asked whether he was Mr Smith, `Sir, if you believe that, you will believe anything'.

Nowhere is the pathetic posturing of the Hawke Government more evident than in its failure to confront the fundamental question of labour market deregulation, rising levels of national indebtedness, waterfront and land transport reform, dumping of imported products, inflation, and the insidious influence of the monopolistic union power. Australia must face the fact that our prosperity and living standards depend on our ability to compete successfully in the global economy.

The enormous economic potential of this nation and the resourcefulness of its people are being slowly strangled by an ever-tightening noose of statutes and regulations. Labor's pandering to vocal, unrepresentative, single-minded interest groups further adds to the growing burden of bureaucratic interference-the cost to business, disincentives to invest, and penalties for the hardworking and the thrifty.

At the beginning of the century, when this Federal Parliament was first constituted, five million Australians enjoyed the highest standard of living in the world. Since then, and particularly since 1960, our relative wealth and prosperity have been in marked decline. At the same time, national indebtedness has reached alarming levels-33 per cent in 1989 compared with less than 2 per cent in the early 1970s.

Nations that we once regarded as poor relations and that made inferior products are now amongst the world's most productive and efficient economies. At the same time, large sections of our economy, particularly those not exposed to international competition, are grossly inefficient and are handicapping Australia's exporters and those sectors competing against imports.

Over the past year, business confidence has been adversely affected by the deepening recession and the policies of this Government. Despite claims to the contrary, the Government is well aware that business profitability and cash flow have been severely affected by what is quite obviously the worst recession since 1930. Once again, the Government stumbles about and Australia remains the sick man of the Pacific.

As ordinary Australians are thrown out of work and businesses are sent into bankruptcy, this miserable and inept Government can only babble about `the recession we had to have'. In contrast, however, nothing is too good for the mates on the waterfront. While farmers slaughter their flocks and organisations such as the Salvation Army are besieged by people in desperate circumstances, 55-year-old wharfies with 25 years experience receive redundancy packages of 247 weeks pay. These are the workers whose efforts have earned Melbourne the unenviable reputation of the world's third worst port, exceeded in awfulness only by Leningrad and Genoa. Indeed, there are few more telling examples of the depths to which Australia has sunk than this tragic juxtaposition of farmers and wharfies. Even the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) has been forced to concede that the protests of miners and farmers about problems on the waterfront are justified.

Australian prosperity, which was built on the sheep's back, has been undermined by the ball and chain of an uncompetitive waterfront, inefficiencies in land transport, attacks on small business and an industrial relations system which emerged from the utopian dreams of the 1890s and the early Commonwealth era. It is widely recognised that our farmers and miners are amongst the most productive in the world. Our farmers sell their wool and wheat on competitive world markets and must be constantly mindful of the vagaries of international commodity prices. However, traditional labour myths of `the hungry mile' and oppressive work conditions `under the hook' continue to surround the waterfront and maritime unions.

In 1991, organisations such as the Waterside Workers Federation of Australia (WWF) are still characterised by their attachment to what is essentially a nineteenth century view of craft unionism. It is therefore no surprise that Australian ports are renowned for their inefficiency and restrictive work practices. They are only 50 per cent as productive as European ports and 40 per cent as efficient as ports in Asia, yet just a 20 per cent improvement in productivity would boost the nation's gross domestic product by $1,100m. Why does it require between 103 and 107 pieces of paper to get one container through the Port of Melbourne? The Circumlocution Office of Charles Dickens looks like a model of business efficiency in comparison with our waterfront.

Research by the Inter-State Commission found that the average productive working week of many waterside workers is a mere 20 hours. However, demonstrating its usual weakness, the Government rejected key recommendations put forward by the Commission; just to make absolutely sure the Commission did not stray from the Party line again, the Government axed it altogether. Nothing, of course, must be done to offend the sectional interests of the Australian Council of Trade Unions and one of its most powerful constituents, the Waterside Workers Federation.

Only a few weeks ago the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy admitted to a Herald-Sun journalist that waterfront reform was moving at a grindingly slow pace. Evoking visions of Haig's flawed and costly strategy on the Somme in July 1916, Kerin went on to say:
I'm sure we'll break through this year-or not at all.
Yet another triumph of hope over experience, although, unlike Haig, I think it is unlikely the Minister will ever be rewarded with an earldom.

In 1988 the Business Council of Australia found that port inefficiencies in handling bulk cargo were costing $300m annually, while inefficiencies in the handling of containers and roll-on, roll-off cargoes cost a further $400m. Chronic overmanning, demarcation disputes and inflexible rosters typify the problems afflicting the Australian waterfront. How can a government which beats its breast and claims to represent the workers of this country allow the pampered thugs of the WWF to institutionalise work practices such as the following? When a contractor requires his own driver to operate his own equipment, a WWF driver is also employed, but does nothing; when members of a work gang draw straws for an expensive prize-nicking off home on full pay-while in some cases two drivers must be employed in derrick cranes which have three operational levers and only one seat. The cranes are designed for one operator, yet the union insists on two. Another example is that of trucks queuing outside the Port of Melbourne, which costs the community $21m a year, when the introduction of a modern computer system on the waterfront would save $500m a year.
The problems plaguing the Australian waterfront and the snail's pace of reform were recently summed up by Ivan Deveson, the Chairman of the Australian Shipping Users Group, when he said:
In my life I have never seen an industry where the customer is so irrelevant as I do in Australia's waterfront.
Deveson went on to describe the waterfront as:
. . . the most rampant cost-plus structure I have ever seen.

Perhaps the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) or even the world's greatest Treasurer could tell the House how the overburdened taxpayers and small business people of this country can afford to subsidise the inefficiency and waste that they know only too well is endemic on the waterfront. Why is it that the first 500 exits from the industry under the redundancy packages are now almost five months overdue? Could the answer be that this Government is just too cowardly to do anything that might upset the already overindulged wharfies?

When we examine the record of other countries we see that the task of micro-economic reform is not all that difficult, providing one can muster the political will in the first place. In Britain, Associated Ports, which controls 22 ports, was established when the Thatcher Government sold the British Transport Docks in 1983. Needless to say, productivity and efficiency in British ports has improved dramatically in recent years. In New Zealand the leadership of Roger Douglas has resulted in a successful program of reform on the waterfront. These reforms included an enterprise employment system, the abolition of the New Zealand Port Authority and the formation of port companies to buy and operate the commercial facilities of the harbour board. Additional legislation allows the privatisation of these companies so that New Zealand ports are now able to operate on a competitive and commercial basis.

Why can we not do the same? Why has this Government been prepared to embrace so enthusiastically the deregulation of financial markets but is unrelenting in its refusal to touch what is surely one of the world's most over-regulated economies and one of its most over-regulated labour markets? As Terry McCrann put it recently:

The whole of the 1980s is a picture of the distortions that emerge when you do things piecemeal. Deregulating the financial market and leaving everything else rotten in place sent money straight into assets speculation, not industrial development.

Fundamental to this whole debate is the question of the proper role of government in a modern democracy. Why do governments in Australia feel compelled to do so much? Indeed, if we examine their record of management in respect of ports and harbours, railways, telecommunications, electricity and so on, we see that in general it has been one of inefficiency, bureaucratic meddling and waste. Much of the traditional rationale for public ownership in Australia relates to the argument that ports, railways, telecommunications, electricity and so on constitute natural monopolies which can be run only by government. In practice, however, the disease of public ownership has resulted in the gradual impoverishment of this nation. The dead weight of the public sector, coupled with high interest rates and an anti-business, anti-savings tax regime has seen this country sink once again into a deep recession.

The Appropriation Bills have again evaded the question of our horrendous foreign debt. Since the election of this Government in 1983 our foreign debt has increased by over $100 billion. This means we have borrowed over $1 billion per month on average for the past eight years. This $1 billion per month is approximately 10 per cent of the nation's wages bill; that is, 10 per cent of our work force is effectively being paid by overseas creditors. At the end of last year our foreign debt had risen to a new high of $131 billion. It is imperative that this situation is reversed, but the words of the Prime Minister and the Treasurer hardly inspire us to believe that the Government has the fortitude to tackle this problem. Australians have the right to ask where the tangible benefits of the investment boom of the 1980s are. The answer is that a large proportion of the borrowing has directly or indirectly been used to finance consumption rather than adding to our productive capacity. Moreover, the present decline in investment is occurring against the background of a continued current account deficit.

It is hardly surprising, therefore, that in the lifetime of this Government, Australia's credit rating has twice been downgraded. There is little prospect that these assessments will be reversed in the near future. The net result of this is that Australian borrowers have to pay an extra premium on their external borrowings while the higher costs are passed on to all borrowers, from home owners to business people.

The Appropriate Bill (No. 4) 1990-91 and the statement of savings reveal all in the micro-economic reform. This Government continues to spend huge sums of money for what? A Conaust deal that has now fallen apart. It is scandalous and the Government stands condemned as the worst this century.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bevis Mr A.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have just heard from the honourable member for Dunkley (Mr Ford) a confirmation of the Opposition's policies in relation to economics and industrial relations. This has once again reaffirmed that its views and rhetoric are bedded deeply in the 1960s and that it has failed to understand any of the changes that have occurred throughout the 1980s.
—The 1860s.

—As the Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories, who is at the table, says, it may well have been the 1860s. Some of the comments that were made earlier today in fact would reinforce that view. I hope to find time later in this debate to comment in some detail on questions of micro-economic reform and industrial relations. I can assure the honourable member for Dunkley that, if time does not allow me to do that in this debate, I will certainly do so during discussion on the industrial relations Bills that will come before this Parliament shortly.

SPEECH.PARA: The Appropriation Bills before the Parliament this evening provide a timely opportunity to review economic policy and the direction of our economy. The Appropriation Bills themselves deal directly with Government fiscal policy. In my address this evening, I will discuss some fiscal policy aspects.

This Government, whilst addressing the difficult economic times we are in, has maintained a social security system which has ensured that those in less well off positions, those most hurt by the current difficulties, are in fact provided with some assistance and are able to maintain a quality of life and a standard of living which would otherwise be denied to them. We have been able to ensure that pensions have increased to what is now their highest level since 1949. Age pensions now are at a level in excess of 25 per cent of average weekly earnings-a long held target of the Australian Labor Party and one that has been reached historically only under Labor governments.

It is a fact that during the term of the previous Liberal Administration in Canberra the Fraser Government reduced age pensions as a percentage of average weekly earnings. This Government has turned the tide on that trend and in fact we have now seen an increase to what is the highest level since the end of the 1940s.

The August Budget, of which these Appropriation Bills in a sense form part, provided for tax cuts for all wage and salary earners. These cuts were, in the end, increased and implemented from 1 January. Mr Deputy Speaker, you might recall that the cuts were increased as a result of negotiations with the trade union movement and employers following release of the consumer price index (CPI) figures at the end of last year. The Australian Council of Trade Unions decided to forgo a wage increase application before the Australian Industrial Relations Commission and in return the Government introduced some increased taxation benefits. It is that sort of responsible approach to industrial relations and economic management which those opposite have clearly failed to come to grips with and which the honourable member for Dunkley obviously has no understanding of, given the comments that he has just made in this place.

The bottom rate of taxation has been slashed from 30 per cent when we came to office to a 20 per cent level at present, with the top rate being cut from 60 per cent to 47 per cent. As I mentioned, extra savings were provided as a result of the September 1990 CPI figures. Those reductions in tax rates have been of benefit to all wage and salary earners and have only been able to be offered because of the efforts of this Government in closing the various tax loopholes which were built into the system over a period and which, during the life of the former Liberal Government, became something of a growth industry.

Quality child-care is now available to thousands of families throughout Australia at affordable prices because of initiatives which this Government has taken. Working parents may now be eligible for fee relief of up to $85 a week for a maximum of 50 hours supervision. Working parents may now earn up to $56,200 and still be eligible for part fee relief. The Hawke Government has raised the income test ceiling for maximum fee relief from $270 a week to $370 a week. These represent major improvements to the provision of quality child-care, which is a substantial benefit to ordinary working families throughout the country.

The Hawke Government has, in addition, improved the benefits available to families for the support of their children by way of the family allowance and the family supplement. There are now some 3.7 million children benefiting from these schemes. The family allowance varies from $20 a fortnight for one child to $113 a fortnight for five children. The family allowance supplement, introduced by this Government as an additional means of assistance to low income families, is worth $53 a fortnight for each child under 13 years of age and $77.30 a fortnight for children aged 13 to 15 years. Both of these payments are tax free. They represent very substantial improvements in the quality of life of those families whose ordinary wages and salaries are not able to provide them with a standard of living which we in Australia would regard as acceptable.

I should add that they represent an improvement in the standard of living which does not show up in the sorts of surveys that we saw published recently which referred to income gaps between the rich and the poor. These measures constitute the social wage and in many cases are directly attributable to the accord. They are a testament to the benefit that the accord has provided to ordinary Australians and their families.

The unemployment benefit in these times of difficulty has been maintained at realistic levels by the Hawke Government. Of course, these payments continue for the long term unemployed. Importantly, for those in ill health, the Government has maintained Medicare for all Australians no matter where they live, how poor they are or how old they are. When we consider the fiscal situation within this country, it is important to note that this Government has returned three surplus Budgets in a row. No other government in the history of this country can lay claim to that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not counting this one.

—I will deal in a moment with the Liberal Party's record in government and its policies. In fact, I should start by referring to the position of the Liberal Party in regard to fiscal management. What would the Opposition do if it had the opportunity to act in this area? In February, only a few months ago, the shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith), announced that we should reduce expenditure by $3 billion. The Australian of 19 February reported as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Reith's clarification of the Opposition's stance on fiscal policy-that it would both increase taxes and cut spending during a recession-means there is now a growing gulf between the positions of the Government and the Coalition on the role of government spending during a recession.

That is very true-there is an enormous gulf between the position of the Opposition and the Government in these matters. I might say on that point that there is an enormous gulf between the Opposition and every economist in the country. No-one else in this land is going around saying that we should reduce government expenditure by $3 billion and increase taxes. It is economic lunacy in times of difficult employment circumstances and during a recession to advocate that policy, as the Liberal spokesperson on tax matters did only a few months ago. This demonstrates the total lack of understanding of our current situation and/or a total disregard for the welfare of ordinary Australians. But it gets better. The Australian went on to say:
Mr Reith would not say yesterday when the Opposition's new tax plan would be released, other than that it would be `all in due course'.

That is a bit reminiscent of the old health policy that the former health spokesmen on the other side of the House was going to introduce prior to the last Federal election. It was in the top drawer as well. The sums on that had been worked out, and of course they did not add up either. Now we find that the tax policy is in the same drawer and it will come to light in due course, but it will involve cuts of $3 billion.
In the same article we learnt a little bit more about the Opposition's plans for the administration of our fiscal policy. It read:
Mr Reith said the Opposition was concerned about the `loosening of fiscal policy (that has taken place) and in our view, that is a lever that they (the Government) ought to be pulling'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Look at your record.
—This is the Opposition's policy; members opposite should listen carefully to this. It goes on:

SPEECH.PARA: Tightening fiscal policy would provide some real benefits and it's one of the things, one of the policy prescriptions, that they ought to be employing.

The Opposition's policy is to cut expenditure. Every time members opposite get up in this place and complain about the lack of expenditure for the rural sector, the roads, the health scheme, the defence budget, they should bear in mind their own policy to reduce by $3 billion the outlays in this financial year. They should have a look at the Appropriation Bills that are before us now and identify which $1 1/2 billion they want to cut out, because that is the only honest position they can put in this place, rather than come here with the hypocritical positions they have advanced throughout the last few weeks on a range of issues. They should hop up now and tell us which is the $1 1/2 billion they want to cut out. When they have identified that $1 1/2 billion, we will go to the people. And I know who will win there, because the people will not wear that sort of lunatic economics in times of economic difficulties.

But of course it does not end there. We turn to the difficulties of the unemployed. We have heard so much from those opposite telling us about their deep concern for the unemployed. What is their policy towards the unemployed?

TALK.START.PARA: —Cut their benefits.

—Their policy towards the unemployed is to eliminate the benefits. They say, `If you are long term unemployed, you are guilty; it is all your fault and we are going to cut the benefit out. You can survive on the Salvation Army, St Vincent de Paul or wherever you think you might be able to get a meal'. Those opposite who hop up here and shed crocodile tears about the difficulties of ordinary working Australians who are hard pressed to find a job say the next day that we should eliminate unemployment benefits. It is yet another example of the hypocrisy of members opposite and when it is exposed to the people of this country, they will reject them out of hand.

SPEECH.PARA: But of course we have heard the tough rhetoric, and some of it is worth repeating. I think one of the most notable comments we have heard in the last few months about government expenditure has to do with Medicare. I mention Medicare as one of the great achievements of the Government and a great benefit to all Australians because it is universal; it is available to all; and there is no health risk rating. It is a good scheme, and Australian people know it is a good scheme.

The honourable members on the opposite side of the Parliament are not too sure about it, though. They still want to abolish it. It was only a couple of months ago that their health spokesperson was telling us, `We'll do away with Medicare and we'll introduce health vouchers'. When he was quizzed about that on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation, he said, `Well, yes, some people will be worse off, but worse off by choice'. Now, think about that. The people out there are going to be worse off by choice. They are going to want to be worse off. We have a country of masochists who are just waiting for members opposite to take Medicare off them so they can choose to be worse off. That was the quote from the Opposition's own health spokesperson.

I think the final nail in the Opposition's coffin when it comes to fiscal policy was the comment of the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) about company tax. There was that famed interview in which he said, `Well, the goal, the aim that we're seeking to reach is in fact to eliminate company tax. And where are we going to raise our revenue? We'll raise revenue from a broad based consumption tax'. That will be a broad based consumption tax that affects all people in this country on every single thing they buy; not selective, but a broad based consumption tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —It will catch up with the BBs of the world who do not pay any tax.

—The honourable member should go out to the people in his electorate and tell them that he intends to increase the price of the bread they buy every day of the week, their milk, their eggs, their clothes, their petrol, their car. Every single purchase they make will have an additional charge on it. All of the service charges will go up: their taxi fare, their bus fare-the entire works. It will be a broad based consumption tax that will hurt the poor more than anybody. Yet in debates such as this members opposite stand here with crocodile tears and express their concern for the unemployed.

SPEECH.PARA: I think something should also be said about monetary policy because, in terms of economic management, we all know that there are three important arms to proper economic management: fiscal, monetary and, of course, wages policy. I do hope time allows me to speak about wages policy because it is in that area where the differences between our Party and the Opposition's are demonstrably great and where the people of Australia will choose to support our policy because it provides them with a protection. But let me speak first about monetary policy.

In recent times, in spite of the history that honourable members opposite want to refer to-and there have been increasing interest rates that have caused harm to a lot of people and have not brought joy to anybody in this place or elsewhere-it is a fact that interest rates are falling. That is something that those opposite bemoan. They had hopes beyond hope that the economy will get worse and worse, for their own political gain. They have not at any stage in the last 18 months demonstrated any concern for the people of Australia in these matters. They have throughout sought to make political gain at every single announcement, at every single opportunity. I will speak about a couple of those opportunities, but before I do I just want to bring the House up to date on what has in fact been occurring with interest rates. We have seen a fall in interest rates of some 7 per cent in the last 14 months. The short term interest rates have come down by 7 per cent. The long term rates are now at a 10-year low. So I ask members opposite not to talk to us about high interest rates. I ask them to read the latest economic bulletins and to understand that interest rates have trended down for the last 14 months and that long term rates are now at a low for the decade.

What is more, as those rates have come down, home loans have also reduced and we are now witnessing a situation in which many commentators are speculating that home loan interest rates will fall below the old fixed rate of 13 1/2 per cent. Inflation is falling, trending down to its lowest level for 20 years. The Australian Financial Review of today quoted Westpac's acting chief economist. It said that he:
. . . yesterday predicted that the March-quarter CPI figure, due for release on May 15, could be the `lowest for a generation'.

We are now entering a phase where inflation will reach a low level that we have not seen since the 1960s and will provide us with the opportunity to have a sustained recovery that will be of long term benefit to all Australians. But the Liberal Party has in fact opposed this Government's efforts to reduce interest rates. It sits on the other side of the House in debates such as this and complains about high interest rates that we have had to endure.

Let us see what members opposite actually said when interest rates started to come down. The shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith), on 29 November last year when interest rates were coming down, said:

Well, I in the end come to the view, yes, if we were loosening off on monetary policy without fiscal policy changes, then you would end up with higher interest rates. In other words, I would not take the rates off.

That is what the shadow Treasurer said in November of last year: he would not take the rates off. Keep the interest rates up was the Opposition's policy in November last year, as we were bringing them down. Yet members opposite sit in this place and complain about high interest rates. I ask them to reconcile those two things.

Finally, in the minute or so available, I do wish to say something about wages and micro-economic reform, although clearly I will not be able to address the issue properly. The accord has provided this country, the workers of this country and the employers of this country with wage stability, a fall in unit labour costs in real terms-and that is something people opposite have failed to acknowledge throughout the last five years. It has provided a dramatic fall in industrial disputes and, of course, it has facilitated award restructuring and micro-economic reform, which has not yet been universally applied but which is progressively being applied throughout industries on an industry by industry basis.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., I propose the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the House do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Goodluck Mr B.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have tried to contact the honourable member for Denison (Mr Kerr)-I think one should always play fair-but unfortunately he was not available; he was not in his room. I wish to mention the royal commission in Tasmania. The honourable member for Denison is not a bad fellow-I have always respected him, and still do. He is quite a good, honest member, and he seems to be doing the best he can for the people he represents. Philosophically I do not agree with him at all, but we all understand that.

SPEECH.PARA: But I could not for the life of me understand why he became involved in the royal commission, why he suddenly tried to be something that he is not-a head-kicker. All of a sudden he said that Robin Gray should resign. He was really saying that the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) should influence Robin Gray to resign. As we all know, we on this side thought that Brian Burke should resign in view of the implications that were coming out of the Royal Commission into Commercial Activities of Government and Other Matters in Western Australia. We thought his behaviour extreme, to say the least. But Brian Burke is an ambassador; he is not a politician. Robin Gray is a politician.

I found it quite surprising that Duncan Kerr became involved in this political muck-up, if I can call it that. He got a lot of publicity over it in Tasmania. As a matter of fact, I tried to get equal time, but unfortunately I could not get the time, to defend Robin Gray. He is a politician, like all of us. Duncan Kerr was trying to say he should resign--

TALK.START.PARA: —Could I suggest to the honourable member for Franklin that he refer to members by their correct title?

—The honourable member for Denison-I am sorry. It is quite out of character; he is trying to create the image of a head-kicker. He is not a head-kicker. If the honourable member for Denison kept away from the murky side of politics he would get on a lot better, and I would greatly respect him. To try to imply that Robin Gray should resign, to try to involve politics in the royal commission down in Tasmania even before it is touched upon, I find quite incredible. His comments are reported as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Kerr said Mr Tronson had admitted Mr Gray held on to a substantial cash donation from Edmund Rouse which was not formally handed over to the Liberal Party until about two months after the election.

He was making no judgment on issues before the Tasmanian royal commission other than on those matters already put on the record by Mr Gray's political advisers. I suggest $10,000 is a lot different from $1.5m. I know the allegations against Mr Brian Burke are yet to be proven, but I cannot see the comparison. Politicians are going through that royal commission ad infinitum. Every day there is a different one going through. To point the bone at Robin Gray, and to bring it into the political arena, is to make a mockery of what Mr Field has said in Tasmania-that the Commission is out to find whether there are guilty people, but it is not a political game to try to catch politicians.

I am afraid the honourable member for Denison has done himself a lot of harm in Tasmania. He has also brought the royal commission down to the dirty part of politics where an attempt is being made to implicate somebody before a decision has been made. I leave it at that. I hope the honourable member for Denison will come into the House and explain why, out of character, he should get involved in such a messy affair, and explain why he was trying to implicate the former Premier of Tasmania, just one politician, when there are other politicians who will appear before the royal commission.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: State of Origin Rugby League Matches

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bevis Mr A.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tomorrow night marks an important event on the sporting calendar of the nation, that being the first State of Origin rugby league match for 1991, to be played at Lang Park in Brisbane. The State of Origin rugby league match is regarded throughout Australia as one of the premier sporting events, evoking deep and committed emotions from spectators and viewers around the country. It has become something of an international spectacle as well, now being broadcast to the United Kingdom.

SPEECH.PARA: It is seen not only as a great emotional event by those of us here in Australia who have seen the game evolve from the old Queensland versus New South Wales matches to the current State of Origin matches, but it is also seen as the best exposition of rugby league football at the highest level and of the highest quality. In many respects, it is sad to see it has tended to take that role away from some of the test matches because we would all like to see the wearing of the green and gold jersey as the greatest achievement to which a sportsperson could aspire.

Within the rugby league code of football the State of Origin competition has all but surpassed test match activity as the pinnacle of the game. Tomorrow night we will see the first of this year's matches.

Queensland has a very proud history in State of Origin football. Queensland has managed to win most of the matches which have been played since the inception of State of Origin games. The concept was pioneered and in fact drawn up by a Labor senator, the late Senator McAuliffe-Rugby Ron-who, as President of the Queensland Rugby League and as a vice-president of the Australian Rugby League, was a great administrator with the foresight which enabled this contest to be organised.

It is a contest which Queensland has been fortunate enough to dominate, by and large, throughout the years it has been played. I am a bit sad to say that in recent years Queensland appears not to have been up to the task of beating the Blues, and I must give credit to New South Wales. That State has produced some excellent football teams in recent years.

When one looks at the teams being fielded for tomorrow night's match, one would have to concede that New South Wales is again favourite for the game as it has a very strong array of test players and many seasoned footballers who are well accustomed to State of Origin football. Unfortunately for Queensland, approximately half of our team is playing a State of Origin match for the very first time. That is going to place some significant burden on those players.

We have the experience, of course, of one of the greatest footballers ever to put the jersey on-Wally Lewis, who is captain of the Queensland side. At 31 years of age he has no doubt lost some of the pace that he had, but as a general on the football field I think he would rank with the best in any era of the game. He is truly one of the top rate footballers the nation has produced.

I have had the good fortune to attend many a game at Lang Park to watch the State of Origin games. Regrettably, that will not be my lot tomorrow night. Having been at those games, and having enjoyed the atmosphere of the Lang Park crowd on State of Origin night, I hold great hopes for the ability of the members of the Queensland team to do wonderful things with the maroon jersey on their back. In front of a Lang Park crowd, with Wally Lewis as captain-in what may in fact be his final series as captain for Queensland-we will find a Queensland rugby league team committed to its task tomorrow night. Queensland will make a very good game of it. It will, I think, be the great spectacle that we have come to expect from State of Origin rugby league over the years.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid The Hon N.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise an issue which is of great concern to people in rural Australia. I am pleased that the Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories (Mr Simmons) is at the table so he may report to his colleague, the Minister for Resources (Mr Griffiths), who is not with us at the moment, on the price of liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) in country areas of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to refer specifically to the price variation between the city of Melbourne and country areas like Bendigo, where the price difference was 13c per litre last weekend. I know that the market has been deregulated, and I have no argument with that, but I raise this issue with the Minister because it is of concern to country people. The price of LPG in Melbourne last week was 18.3c per litre. Yet, in country Victoria, particularly around the Bendigo area, it was 13c per litre higher at 30.9c per litre.

TALK.START.PARA: —How much?

—That is correct: 18c per litre in Melbourne, yet in country parts of Australia we are looking at 30.9c per litre. To give an example, with unleaded petrol there is about 4c per litre difference between city and country. In those areas freight charges are around 2c per litre for petrol from Melbourne to Bendigo. I understand that freight charges for LPG can be slightly higher because of the smaller payload and the specialised pressurised vehicles which carry that gas, but 13c per litre difference between Melbourne and Bendigo seems to be an enormous difference.

SPEECH.PARA: It begs the question of what margins the companies are operating on that enable them to have a price differential like that. It is causing great concern to people in country areas who rely on LPG for their heating and the operation of their cars which have been converted to LPG. I know that the Trade Practices Commission and the Prices Surveillance Authority are carrying out an investigation into LPG prices but, according to a recent newspaper report, it was stated that officers from the Trade Practices Commission and the Prices Surveillance Authority would be expected to visit Bendigo in a few weeks. I would have thought they could get there a little quicker than that. I ask the Minister to ensure that they investigate those matters quickly, because 13c a litre is too big a difference and the impost that that is placing upon country people is quite marked.

I am receiving a tremendous number of complaints about this. There is a need to look at the margins some of these companies are operating on and whether they are using LPG as a loss leader in some types of situations, as some of our supermarkets do. The sooner this matter is investigated and some resolution is obtained the better it will be for people who use LPG gas in country Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crawford Ms M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to pay tribute to a wonderful group of women, the Logan Netball Association, who hosted the Queensland junior age championships over the weekend. The Logan Netball Association is located in one of the most disadvantaged areas of our State. It has struggled against a very hostile city council, the Logan City Council, which is well known for turning down moneys from this Federal Government simply because it does not wish to have money from a Labor government. So women, particularly, and men in that area have had great difficulty in organising any kind of recreation and sporting facilities. The newly elected council will no doubt continue that tradition, since it seems to be more of a progress at any price type of council.

SPEECH.PARA: However, despite all of this, the Logan Netball Association has worked enormously hard; and I am delighted to say that I am its patron. I have also been responsible for getting for the Association a small grant which has enabled it to build very modest toilet facilities and a small canteen, which surely is not very much to ask for the young people who gather there on weekends-usually in the region of 2,000 to 5,000 of them.

Most of this work has been done through the instigation of a very energetic and very versatile president, a lady by the name of Phyl Grant, and her secretary, Janelle Moorehead, plus the hard work that has been done by the Snell family. Mr and Mrs Snell, over 14 years, have hung in there to ensure that this organisation has grown from a very small group of 10 or 15 people to the kind of organisation which it is now.

The opening of the championships on Saturday morning was presided over by the international president of women's netball, Miss Deidrie Hyland, who also lives in my electorate. We had the Queensland president, Pat Winton, and our local Logan president, Phyl Grant. People came from all over Queensland-from Mount Isa, Townsville, Herbert River, from as far west as Biloela, and from the south, the Tweed and Tweed Heads, to participate in the Queensland championships. We had people from under 13 to under 17. It is very important to acknowledge that this sport is the most popular sport in Australia. It is the sport which has the most participants, and on any one weekend in Australia 1 1/2 million people play netball--

TALK.START.PARA: —How many?

—On any one weekend 1 1/2 million people play netball. I know that our newspapers would not indicate that. We see photographs of horse races and of the three codes of football, but the two sports in which most people participate are netball and ladies bowls. That is something which perhaps our sporting commentators should take more notice of. However, I am pleased that the ABC at long last has acknowledged the immense skill and excitement that there is in the game of netball. It now shows-usually at about 5 p.m. on a Saturday-some of the netball finals. The games are very exciting and, if people watch, they will learn the skills and experience the terrific thrill one gets in following a team. Certainly, there was no shortage of thrills and excitement on the weekend at the Queensland age championships.

SPEECH.PARA: I was delighted when the Logan under seventeens came home to glory. That is an indication of how hard they have trained and how much work they have put in and the kinds of skills which they have. It gives me great pleasure to commend the Logan Netball Association for the enormous work it did over the weekend in the provision of fantastic facilities and fantastic support and in providing an opportunity for a couple of thousand people to explore their skills and their friendships, and to have a healthy and wonderful weekend.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cowan Mr D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I generally try to use the adjournment for matters which concern me within my own electorate. I do not want to be classed as being too parochial, but weeks ago I did raise a matter in the House concerning the Buladelah Fire Brigade and the Buladelah Rescue Squad. I want to thank the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Beazley) for his response to me concerning a beeper that both organisations are seeking and that will work in that particular locality in New South Wales. It has been pointed out to me that, because there is not a transmitter on the mountain adjoining the township, both organisations are finding great difficulty in advising their voluntary members of an accident or a fire.

SPEECH.PARA: I have no great objection to Telecom being made a corporation, but we are finding today that, every time we make representations concerning a public telephone booth or a letterbox, we get the answer that from the commercial point of view it cannot afford to put one in. The same thing is occurring here and I am very concerned about it. I am told by the Department that it will cost approximately $10,000 to place a transmitter or equipment on the mountain to make this service available. I again appeal to the Minister-because I have not received a direct reply to the representations I made to the Department-to see that the matter is reviewed.

I appreciate the fact that he is the Minister and that there is a corporation there and that they are controlling their own domestic affairs. But thousands of vehicles pass through this township on the Pacific Highway every day. It is a bad piece of road and there are many accidents. Many people are killed within the vicinity of Bulahdelah. Many people damage themselves and their vehicles in that area. In this case the Department should make available the necessary equipment so that these beepers can work properly. I speak of Mr Kevin Johnson, the Chairman, and Mr Lansdowne, another man associated with the bush fire brigade. They work voluntarily for 24 hours each day. They make available a service not only to local people in the community but also to many thousands of people travelling from the metropolitan areas in Brisbane through the township each day.

I am very concerned about it. I want to help them. I know the work that they are doing. They do not seek a lot of publicity. As I said earlier-and this is the important thing-they are giving voluntarily their time to save the lives of people and property damaged by accident or by fire. I therefore appeal to the Minister-to date he has been cooperative-to convince his Department to look at the situation sympathetically as these people are doing voluntary work. They are saving lives and they are serving the community. Money is what seems to matter, but to me it is saving lives and property that is important. Whether a Department is a commercial enterprise or not, it should give some consideration to these problems in country areas. I am sure that the Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories (Mr Simmons), who is at the table, has similar situations in his electorate of Calare where a department says, `No, it is not a commercial thing therefore we cannot approve it'. I want the situation at Bulahdelah re-examined so that something can be done to help these people who are doing voluntary work 24 hours a day. These men and women make their services available to save lives on a highway. I appeal to the Minister to do something about it.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Access to Coastal Areas: Crayfishing: Radio Australia

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The first matter I speak about tonight is an environmental concern. There is a tendency around the coastline of Australia for many fishing and surfing spots to be purchased privately. People are then denied access to those places. Increasingly-it is an unfortunate trend-areas that were once available to the public on a relatively free basis are now often closed to the public. The answer is relatively straightforward; that is, where there are particular recognised surfing and fishing spots used by members of the public, that State governments gazette them and, in effect, declare them as places for which there shall be permanent access for the public. It has to be understood that good surfing and fishing places are a very scarce resource. They should not be prejudiced by the private purchase of those places. That problem is emerging. It has been drawn to my attention in Western Australia. It is a big problem. People have been accustomed to going somewhere but because a new owner has acquired the property access has been denied because the new owner has simply decided to deny access. I can understand the owner's concern about the proper management of the area so that it does not degrade. But by gazetting it, State governments would take responsibility under their conservation and land management program to look after that.

SPEECH.PARA: The second matter I refer to is the concern in the crayfishing industry in Western Australia. Many of the fishing people who use bait bags throw those over the sides of the boats. These bait bags are all over the coastal regions of Western Australia, where crayfishing is very prolific. So far, without success, I have taken this matter up at both the industry level and at State government level. I recommend that State governments simply pass a regulation which requires that cray fishermen remove the bait from the plastic bag before they go out to sea and leave the plastic bag on shore. That would then eliminate the carriage of the plastic bag and the bait straps, which are even more of a threat to the environment. These would have to be left on shore. The bait would then be put into very large bins and then used. This matter needs to be addressed because it is a very serious concern to the marine and coastal environment.

The third matter is that currently Radio Australia provides services. On a Saturday it takes 3LO feed from Melbourne and provides that service around the world. On Sundays it takes the 2BL feed from Sydney and provides that service around the world. In effect, on Saturday there is an Australian rules football coverage mixed with a coverage of races and on Sunday there is the rugby league coverage from Sydney. That is a very successful service, only inhibited by the deficiencies in Radio Australia transmitters around Australia. That needs to be addressed. Radio Australia is a very cost efficient and effective organisation on a worldwide basis.

I am alarmed-I have had correspondence with Radio Australia-as it is proposing to remove those services. It believes that it ought not to be providing a service for Australian expatriates. That is very short-sighted. Australian expatriates need a link with the Australian mainland. Sometimes they have not gone overseas of their choosing. That is the first thing to recognise. The second thing to recognise is that Australia is known for its sport, particularly our proficiency in Australian rules and rugby league is known worldwide. By projecting those sports into these various regions of the world and by having them as a topic of conversation, we in fact advance Australia's interests.

I am often very concerned about this tendency to pocket Australia's interest into something specifically about information or cultural programs. I understand that they are very important. But it is a very narrow definition of culture that says that I can remove the role of sport from the definition of culture. As I said earlier, sport is a very significant phenomenon in Australia. Those two sporting codes are known on a worldwide basis. I also acknowledge that rugby union has a worldwide appeal but we ought to make sure that this coverage is provided for Australian expatriates.

Incidentally, many people on the Australian mainland who cannot get very effective radio or television transmission rely on Radio Australia coverage. As a by-product of that service, people in remote localities are being serviced. The net effect is that Radio Australia currently provides a very good service. I am alarmed that it might cut back that service. We should press it to continue that service. We should also assist by improving its transmitter facilities. That would be of assistance to people.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Taylor Mr W.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Recently in the township of Gatton in the Lockyer Valley of Queensland I met the daughter of Mrs Win Davson, who has been a leading light in the arts and drama for four decades. I take the opportunity to salute Win for her irreplaceable contribution to local youth activities and, in particular, for her contribution to the Mercury Theatre.

SPEECH.PARA: Galleries and establishments worldwide are supporting an art initiative by Win's daughter, Sharon. The initiative is called Artists for Life. For the first time the world's artists are collaborating on a common theme to focus attention on the plight of the earth's endangered species. As a central focus of this event a major art exhibition will tour the world commencing in 1993 and will feature paintings, drawings, prints, sculptures and ceramics by distinguished artists from many countries. This is the first time that artists of this calibre will have cooperated to create a collection on a single theme on a global basis. The impact of such an art experience progressively touring the world will also help to consolidate a common purpose in countries of differing political and philosophical doctrines.

I am delighted that the Minister responsible, the Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories (Mr Simmons), is at the table. I say to the Minister that already over 40 prominent international art galleries have assisted and have expressed an interest in holding supporting art exhibitions. Similar support has been expressed by 100 art galleries in Australia as well as many art societies, et cetera. The Premier of New South Wales, Mr Nick Greiner, has given early support, as indeed has my senatorial colleague from New South Wales, Senator Bishop. I urge anyone who can contribute in financial or artistic terms to write to Sharon, at Post Office Box 306, West Ryde, New South Wales, 2114. I ask the Parliament and the Minister at the table, in particular, to lend their support to this important project.

The following answers to questions were circulated:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Community Services and Health, upon notice, on 19 September 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: With respect to each of the Departments and agencies for which the Minister has portfolio responsibility, (a) when (i) was the first round Access and Equity Plan published and (ii) will the second round Access and Equity Plan be published, (b) what mechanisms have been set up, including at the regional level, to ensure ongoing consultation on access and equity with community organisations, (c) which community organisations or representatives are involved in such mechanisms, (d) which officer has major responsibilities for access and equity in the Department or agency and what is the officer's position and (e) what are the names and contact telephone numbers of the access and equity officers in each region.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) (i) The Department of Community Services and Health's first round Access and Equity Plan was published in April 1988.
(ii) The second round Access and Equity Plan will be published in 1991.

(b) In October 1988 an Access and Equity Unit was established in Central Office to facilitate the development and coordination of the Government's policy and to monitor the implementation of social justice objectives in each departmental program. The Unit provides advice and assistance to program managers who are responsible for achieving these objectives in relation to disadvantaged groups.
Mechanisms established to ensure ongoing consultation on Access and Equity with community agencies include:

Rural and Remote Steering Committee, development of a consumer consultation protocol for Departmental staff; Aboriginal Task Force on cross-cultural training, recruitment, and effective consultation; and the Multicultural Information Strategy.
National and State Advisory Committees and Planning Committees.

Home and Community Care (HACC) Advisory Committees; HACC Forums; Aged Care Advisory Committees; Ethnic Aged Advisory Committees; Aboriginal Aged Care Services Committee; Standards Review Panels; Aged Consumer Forums; Care Aggregated Module Funding Monitoring Committees; Standards Monitoring Teams.

Disability Advisory Council of Australia; State Disability Services Advisory Committees. Selected Commonwealth Rehabilitation Service units employ Aboriginal rehabilitation liaison officers and caseworkers.

State Ministerial Advisory Committees for Supported Accommodation Assistance Program/Crisis Accommodation Program; Local Government &Community Housing State Advisory Committees; Emergency Relief State Advisory Committees; Aboriginal Rental Program State Advisory Committees; Youth Health Advisory Committees.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport and Communications, upon notice, on 10 October 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What was the total cost of the Four Corners program, ``The Wood for the Trees'', shown on ABC television on Monday, 18 June 1990.
