(4) When did the ABC decide to produce the program.
(5) How many persons were (a) consulted or (b) interviewed by the ABC during the production of the program and what are their names.
(6) When was the first contact made with the CSIRO scientists who appeared in the program.
(7) On how many occasions were the CSIRO scientists who appeared in the program contacted or interviewed and on what dates.
(8) When did Dr Beth Schultz, who acknow- ledged that she assisted Four Corners to plan the program, first contact the ABC about producing a program on the south-west forests of Western Australia.
(9) On how many occasions were contacts made between the ABC and Dr Schultz with respect to the program and on what dates.
(10) Does the ABC have a file on forests or forest management in the south-west of Western Australia.
(11) Has the ABC completed its formal inquiry into the complaints about the program.
(12) Who complained about the program and which of the complaints were dealt with under section 82 of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation Act 1983.
(13) Has the ABC dealt with all errors of fact that were made in the program.

(14) Did Mr Peter Manning, the Manager of the current affairs program of the ABC, advise persons who complained about the program that the ABC had concluded that there were only two issues that were raised which were of concern to the ABC management and which had been referred to the community affairs officer as required under section 82 of the Act.
(15) Who (a) was responsible for conducting the inquiry in the ABC into the program and (b) wrote the report of the inquiry.
(16) Were persons outside the ABC contacted concerning complaints about the program during the inquiry; if so, who was contacted.
(17) Does section 82 of the Act require the ABC to deal promptly with errors of fact in a program, if so, has the ABC met that requirement.
(18) If the ABC has not met the requirements of section 82 what action will be taken.
(19) Is he satisfied with the procedures which have been adopted by the ABC to deal with complaints about the program.
(20) Did any persons or organisations claim to have been slandered by the ABC in the program; if so, what action will he take to ensure those persons or organisations have proper redress.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question, based on information provided by the Australian Broadcasting Corporation, is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The total cost of `The Wood for the Trees' was $51,725 (including overtime and penalties, excluding salaries).
(2) The cost of the hire of the helicopter was $4,554.

(3) (a) 34 minutes and 40 seconds of film were shot from the helicopter, of which 3 minutes and 1 second were used in the finished program. Unused footage has been retained in the Four Corners archives; (b) no film was shot from the ground during the helicopter hire.
(4) The ABC decided to produce the program on 21 May 1990.

(5) (a) Approximately 45 people were contacted by `Four Corners' during production of `The Wood for the Trees'. I am advised that ABC practice is not to name sources of information obtained in the preparation of programs.

(b) Mr J Briggs, Mr R Bunning, Dr G Chittleborough, Mr A Drake, Mr M Johnson, Dr J Leigh, Mr P Llewellyn, Dr E Schultz, Dr S Shea, Mr A Syme, Mr P Toyne, Mr E Valom and Mr A Walker were interviewed during the program.
(6) The first contact with CSIRO scientists was made on 29 May 1990.
(7) There were several contacts after 29 May 1990. The two scientists were interviewed by `Four Corners' on 7 June 1990.

(8) Dr Schultz did not help `Four Corners' to plan `The Wood for the Trees'. Like other people contacted during preparation of the film, Dr Schultz provided information, contacts and documents-a fact she has publicly acknowledged.
Contact with Dr Schultz during production of `The Wood for the Trees' was initiated by `Four Corners', whose reporter Mark Colvin spoke with her on 23 May 1990.
(9) Contact was made with Dr Schultz on several occasions between 23 May and early June 1990. ABC records do not show the dates.

(10) The ABC does have a file on forests and forest management in the south-west of Western Australia. As a standard practice in journalism, research files maintained by `Four Corners' cover a wide range of subjects.
(11) Yes. The ABC has completed investigation of all complaints.

(12) Complaints were made by the Western Australian Department of Conservation and Land Management (CALM), the Western Australian Minister for the Environment, representatives of professional forestry organisations, forest industry bodies, Bunnings Ltd, a conservationist, a trade union, academics from a tertiary institution, and a number of members of Parliament and members of the public. Of these, six complaints alleging errors of fact in `The Wood for the Trees' have been dealt with under section 82 of the ABC Act.
(13) Yes. The ABC has dealt with all errors of fact that were made in the program.

(14) The Controller of TV News and Current Affairs, Mr Peter Manning, answered letters from members of the public praising or criticising `The Wood for the Trees'. His replies referred, inter-alia, to the findings of the ABC's internal inquiry into detailed allegations made against the program by CALM. Those allegations had been the subject of considerable publicity. Of the 44 complaints from CALM, the ABC inquiry subsequently found two to have been sustained. Mr Manning included this factual information in his responses.

In addition to the complaints handled as part of the internal inquiry, six separate complaints alleging errors of fact in `The Wood for the Trees' have been formally investigated under section 82 of the ABC Act. The Act requires that such investigations be undertaken independently by the ABC's Principal Community Affairs Officer. Mr Manning did not comment on either the formal section 82 complaints, or the independent investigations of each that were then in progress.

(15) (a)``The ABC's internal inquiry into CALM's allegations against `The Wood for the Trees' was conducted by the Assistant Managing Director, Mr Stuart Revill, and the Acting General Manager Corporate Relations, Mr Derek White, assisted by the Head of Legal and Copyright Division, Ms Judith Walker.
(b) The report was written by them, except for material identified in the report as being written by other parties, for example Appendixes A and B.
(16) No persons outside the ABC were contacted about the complaints during the inquiry.

(17) Section 82 of the ABC Act requires that complaints in relation to errors of fact be dealt with as soon as practicable by the Principal Community Affairs Officer, and that, where a complaint is justified, the Managing Director ensure publication of a prompt retraction or apology in appropriate terms. The ABC has advised me that it has met these requirements.
(19) Within the framework of existing complaint procedures the ABC appears to have fulfilled its statutory obligations.
(20) Claims were made that the program had slandered persons or organisations. These persons are free to seek redress through the Courts.

QUESTION.PARA: Has the Trade Practices Commission (a) received any complaints about or (b) been made aware of any instances of Telecom using undue pressure to dissuade businesses from using the products or services of Telecom's competitors; if so, (i) how many instances are involved (A) in total and (B) originating from the south-west of Western Australia, (ii) what action was taken in each instance and (iii) were any instances referred from Austel; if so, how many.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: I have sought from the Trade Practices Commission the information requested by the honourable member, and have been advised as follows:

(i) the TPC has received 5 complaints which would fall within the scope of the honourable member's question-one from Western Australia and the remainder from elsewhere. (ii) the nature of each complaint, and the action that has been taken in relation to the complaint is as follows:

(a) A complainant in NSW alleged that Telecom had improperly interfered with a contract that it had previously negotiated with a customer. Following discussions between the TPC and Telecom staff, Telecom reimbursed money to the complainant.

(b) An allegation was made that Telecom in Melbourne had discriminated in favour of its own operations in the allocation of exchange lines for the supply of competitive equipment and services to the detriment of the complainant. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Woods Dr R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Community Services and Health, upon notice, on 12 February 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the nature of the factor required for weighting to allow the Dental Statistics and Research Unit of the Australian Institute of Health to calculate weighted caries severity rates for 12 year old children for (a) 1986, (b) 1987, (c) 1988, (d) 1989 and (e) 1990.
(2) Is a representative national figure available of caries severity rates for the years listed in part (1).
(3) What is the weighted caries severity rate for South Australia for (a) 1988 and (b) 1989.
(4) Will he explain the formula developed by the Unit head, Professor John Spencer, some years ago to predict the future rates of dental decay.
(5) How do Professor Spencer's predictions compare to the results of the Child Dental Health Survey on an annual basis.
(6) With respect to the Unit, (a) when was it set up, (b) how is it funded, (c) what role does it play and (d) what are its aims and priorities.
(7) What is the importance of the calculation of dental caries severity rates for 12 year old Australian children.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Caries severity has traditionally been measured by the Decayed, Missing and Filled Teeth (DMFT) Index. Observations for this measure are collected as part of the care of children by the School Dental Services of each State or Territory in Australia. When DMFT measures are being calculated for an age group, say 12 year olds, within a State or Territory, no weightings are required to estimate the mean score for children in the State or Territory under the care of the School Dental Service. However, when scores from all States and Territories are combined to calculate a national or Australian estimate, the scores from each State and Territory are weighted.

The weights are numeric in nature and reflect the proportion of the Australian child population (aged 4-13 years) resident in each State or Territory. In the preliminary estimates of caries severity presented in the answer to question (2), the same weight has been used for each of the years 1986, 1987, 1988 and 1989. These weights were: NSW 0.343; VIC 0.271; QLD 0.152; SA 0.086; WA 0.090; TAS 0.030; NT 0.010 and ACT 0.018. For 1990, the nature of the weighting will be similar, however, no national weighted estimates have been compiled for 1990.
(2) No national figure of caries severity rates for 12 year old children has been published for the years 1986 (not for full year), 1987, 1988, 1989 or 1990.

The Dental Statistics and Research Unit assumed responsibility for the Child Dental Health Survey data in March 1989. It has since obtained, from the Commonwealth Department of Community Services and Health, the necessary data for 1986, 1987 and 1988 to calculate the national figure for the DMFT of 12 year olds. The sampling, data processing, analysis and reporting of caries severity was redesigned when the Dental Statistics and Research Unit assumed responsibility for the data collection. One State, Western Australia, delayed introduction of the new data collection methods. Data have recently become available from all States and Territories allowing calculation of the national figure for 1989. The processing and analysis of data for 1990 will not be completed until mid 1991. The figures for those years where they are available are presented below:
Caries severity at 12 years old (Mean DMFT)

(4) Professor John Spencer is a nationally and internationally recognised oral epidemiologist and dental health services researcher. Professor Spencer has qualifications in Children's and Preventive Dentistry, Public Health and Research. It was as part of Professor Spencer's research for a Doctor of Philosophy degree that work was undertaken on prediction of rates of dental decay.
This work was completed in 1984, although some scientific papers arising from it appeared in 1986 and 1987.

Professor Spencer established a data set comprising all findings of mean caries severity of samples of Australian adolescents over the period 1965 to 1978; these included 21 studies involving surveys, clinical trials and analysis of service records of dental programs. Professor Spencer hypothesised that the age-specific DMFT scores, and in some cases scores for socio-economic groups at an individual age, could be explained by a number of predictor variables related to fluoride exposure such as proportion of lifetime exposure to water fluoridation, regular use of fluoride supplements and use of fluoride containing toothpaste. Hence, each mean DMFT score was linked in the data set to mean estimates of these fluoride predictor variables.
The resultant cross-sectional time series data were analysed by multiple regression procedures and the results of how predictors had behaved in the past were used to extrapolate into the future.

In order to estimate the caries severity in future years, Professor Spencer attempted to track patterns of exposure to the fluoride predictor variables, extrapolate their trends and apply estimates of their likely magnitude within the multiple regression model. In this way, estimates of future caries severity of Australian adolescents up to 1990 were calculated.
The following table presents the comparison of Professor Spencer's prediction of caries severity against the results of the Child Dental Health Survey for 12 year old children.
Caries Severity 12 year old children (Mean DMFT)
These data commence at 1979 because the last year of data used in the research was 1978.
The results can be seen to initially be lower, then gradually higher than caries severity obtained in the Child Dental Health Survey.

In Professor Spencer's report on this work in 1984, he pointed out that his predictions were built on data reflecting all children, while the Child Dental Health Survey captures data only on children under the care of the School Dental Services. Hence, although the comparison is convenient, it is not necessarily an apt comparison. Biases may exist in terms of the children who are included in the dental care program of the School Dental Services. As the School Dental Services in most States and Territories were expanding, the nature of the social mix of the children whose caries severity was captured in the Child Dental Health Survey also changed across these years.

In an article in the Australian Dental Journal in 1986, Professor Spencer reported that the steeper decline in the Child Dental Health Survey data between 1979 and 1983 than predicted for all Australian 12 year old children may have indicated that factors other than fluoride, not included in the predictive model, may be associated with the greater decrease observed in the Child Dental Health Survey data. It was, therefore, well recognised by Professor Spencer that ``the future national predictions presented in this study are conservative'' (Spencer Australian Dental Journal 1986; 31(4)262-7). Other factors which may have been operating across that time (and on through the intervening period) to reduce caries severity include
* use of professionally applied fluorides (not modelled)
* an increase in the use of fissure sealants in School Dental Services to prevent caries on occlusal (biting) surfaces
* greater targeting of School Dental Services to higher risk children, maximising the potential to effectively prevent caries, and
* a change in Dentistry toward a philosophy of minimum intervention, ie., when faced by uncertainty about disease presence, not intervening with restorative services.

In the spirit of a statement made by Professor Spencer in 1984 that ``this study will be kept under review to further validate its findings and also identify areas within the research that may be improved'' Slade, Spencer and Dooland conducted in 1989 further research on changing patterns of caries severity in South Australia. Dr Slade is the Consultant Oral Epidemiologist to the Dental Statistics and Research Unit, while Dr Dooland is Director, Statewide Dental Services, South Australian Dental Service.
This research is different from Professor Spencer's earlier work in three fundamental ways:
1. As it was conducted in 1989, it used more recent data in order to understand changes in caries severity and predict future caries severity;

2. It used only data from the School Dental Service in South Australia. It is, therefore, entirely appropriate in this case to compare the research predictions with the subsequent data available from the South Australian School Dental Service which has, in the late 1980s, provided care for a relatively constant percentage of the child population at 12 years old.

3. Whereas Professor Spencer's earlier work was on understanding and tracking changes in fluoride exposure which in turn determined future caries severity, this more recent research uses changes between ages and across time to predict future caries severity. Hence, it does not seek to explain why caries severity is changing; it seeks only to understand how caries severity is changing.

The data assembled for Slade, Spencer and Dooland's work were again a sequential time series of cross-sectional surveys covering children aged six to 12 years cared for by the South Australian School Dental Service between 1976 to 1988. Multiple regression analysis was used to estimate age, cohort and period effects within Adelaide and non-Adelaide parts of South Australia. The outcome was again a formula that could be used to predict future caries severity in each part of the State. The following table presents the comparison of Slade, Spencer and Dooland's prediction of caries severity against the results of the Child Dental Health Survey for all South Australian 12 year old children.
Caries severity 12 year old children (Mean DMFT)

These predictions appear to be tracking closely the actual caries severity of South Australian 12 year old children. However, it should be noted that although this approach captures past changes in caries severity associated with age, cohort and period effects, it cannot anticipate fundamental changes in the antecedents of caries, or the manner in which it is observed and treated in the School Dental Services. Such changes would be bound to reduce the accuracy of the predictions.

A further note of caution is necessary when interpreting estimates which are based on extrapolated data. It is always the case that a single estimate for any year represents a point within a range of figures, and any other figure within that range would constitute a statistically valid prediction. In many instances, the true range of any single predicted estimate (cited above) encompasses the actual observed caries severity, or the range within which another predicted estimate would fall.

(6) (a) The Australian Institute of Health's Dental Statistics and Research Unit was set up in 1987 and began operating in 1988. The Dental Statistics and Research Unit is an external unit of the Australian Institute of Health, being located within the Department of Dentistry at the University of Adelaide.
(b) Its core funding comes from the Australian Institute of Health. Additional funding is obtained through competitive application for research funds and contracted research.

(c) The role of the Dental Statistics and Research Unit is to improve the range and quality of information available on the dental workforce, oral health, use of services and dental practice in Australia.
The aims of the Dental Statistics and Research Unit are:
1. To establish a national minimum data set on dental personnel and provide descriptive statistics on labourforce activity;
2. To establish and maintain the national child dental health survey;
3. To provide information on all data available in Australia on the dental labourforce, dental practice, use of dental services and dental health status, facilitating reviews from time to time; and
4. To conduct supplementary research as deemed necessary.

The priorities for the Unit reflect the aims. The areas of data collection, preparation, analysis and reporting on the dental labourforce and oral health status equally have highest priority, followed by supplementary research and the broader `clearing house' role on dental statistics.

(7) The ready availability of basic planning information on the potential requirement for services is a major factor needed to improve the delivery of dental care and the dental health of Australian children. Monitoring the caries severity of Australian children and predicting future caries severity is an integral aspect of preparing information for such planning. This has become a major feature of the School Dental Services in Australia, through their evaluation and planning systems which draw upon the Child Dental Health Survey data.

The School Dental Services seem to have overcome three common deficiencies in the use of caries severity data for service planning. First, there is a general awareness of how such data might be used to improve the delivery of dental services within the School Dental Services. Second, the data which are collected are made accessible to the potential users, in an appropriate form, and without undue delay. Third, the skills necessary to manipulate and interpret such data are usually available within the service environment.

Data on dental caries severity are used to provide new insights and descriptions of what is known and what is predicted about the potential requirement for dental care for use in the planning of dental services. Improved data sources, methodology, and techniques of analysis and prediction provide a basis for better elucidation of the service delivery issues. The data also identify issues that require further study to gain a better understanding of problems, encouraging others to dispute and discuss findings. This process not only improves the information generated, but improves decision-making on the delivery of dental services.

Effective planning is possible only if the circumstances under which decisions on the future are made can be predicted with reasonable accuracy. This is always difficult in the long term planning of dental health services. Estimates of the size and the structure of populations may be in error, while new understanding and developments in dental care may change patterns of disease and service requirements in fundamental ways. On the other hand, the provision of key resources in the delivery of dental health care, i.e. facilities and a trained dental labourforce, are subject to substantial lead times. This paradox can only be resolved if the preparation of plans incorporates a wide range of assumptions about the future, and is an activity which is kept under continuous review as more recent information becomes available.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Airlines: Liability for Damage and Injury

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jull Mr D.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport and Communications, upon notice, on 6 March 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Following the decision of the High Court of Australia to reject an application by Qantas for the Court to hear an appeal from the NSW Court of Appeals in the case of SS Pharmaceuticals v. Qantas, what action will the Government take to determine the value of the ``gold franc'' in Article 22 of the Warsaw Convention, governing liability of airlines for damage and injury to persons and cargo during international air carriage.
(2) Will special legislation be required to establish the value of the ``gold franc'' if so, when is that legislation likely to be introduced to Parliament.
(3) Will Australia now ratify the Montreal Protocol of 1975 to bring into force the increased limitations of Article 22 of the Warsaw Convention; if so, when will the Protocol be signed.
(4) What are the limitations for (a) personal injury or death and (b) damage to cargo on international airline services to and from Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) In November 1990 the Government decided to:

- Amend the Civil Aviation (Carriers' Liability) Act 1959 (the Act) to enable Australian ratification of Montreal Protocols 3 and 4 of 1975, which introduced increased liability limits given in terms of the International Monetary Fund's Special Drawing Right (SDR); and,

- Amend the Act to fix the Australian dollar equivalents of the gold franc liability limits established in Article 22 of the Warsaw Convention (as amended by the Hague Protocol) in terms of the SDR (1 gold franc equals 0.0664 SDR).
(2) Yes, the Civil Aviation (Carriers' Liability) Act is to be amended as soon as practicable.
(3) Australia will ratify Montreal Protocols 3 and 4 as soon as the Act has been amended.
(4) The limits of liability for personal injury or death are currently:
- for contracts of carriage to which the unamended Warsaw Convention applies-125,000 gold francs;
- for contracts of carriage to which the Hague Protocol applies-250,000 gold francs.
The limits which apply to damage to baggage and cargo were not amended by the Hague Protocol. These are:
- for registered baggage and cargo-250 gold francs; and,
- for objects in charge of a passenger-5000 gold francs.

One of the main reasons for amending the Act is to provide a more certain basis for converting these gold franc limits into Australian dollars. Currently, the dollar value of the limits depends on the price of gold selected by the courts in conversion, which could be either the last official price or the current market price.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McGauran Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, upon notice, on 12 March 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: Further to his answer to question No. 448 (Hansard, 18 February 1991, page 815), (a) what form do the conflict of interest guidelines applying to the Industry Research and Development Board (IRDB) and its committees take, (b) with respect to the various interests reported in his answer, which, in the context of the conflict of interest guidelines, constitute (i) a significant conflict of interest and in each case why and (ii) an insignificant conflict of interest and in each case why and (c) does he intend to strengthen or change in any way the conflict of interest guidelines applying to the IRDB and its committees.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Crean The Hon S.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) Sections 16 and 24 of the Industry Research and Development Act 1986 provide guidelines for the conduct of Board and Committee members when handling matters involving conflict of interest. These guidelines require Board and Committee members to disclose direct and indirect pecuniary interests in matters considered or about to be considered by the Board and its Committees. Members are required to leave the meeting during discussion of such matters and not to take part in determining such matters. The Act also requires such disclosures be recorded in minutes of meetings.
At the time of appointment, Board and Committee members are required to sign a declaration that they will comply with the requirements of sections 16 or 24 respectively, of the IR& Act 1986.
In addition to these guidelines, the IRDB has established``Procedures for the handling of matters involving conflicts of interest''. A copy is at Attachment A.

(b) Details of successful grant applications and favourable tax concession decisions involving significant conflicts of interest are itemised at Attachment B. Corresponding details about insignificant conflicts of interest are at Attachment C.

Each of these attachments consists of two parts: an earlier part from July 1986 to December 1988 and a later part from January 1989 to December 1990. The methods of collection and presentation of data differed between the two periods.

A conflict has been treated as `significant' if a direct beneficial link exists between a project and a member. This includes not only substantial shareholding and employment with a company grant applicant or generic grant collaborator, but also high position in a research organisation which is a grant applicant.

In each of the two periods seven per cent of successful grant applications or favourable tax concession decisions involve a significant conflict of interest. Insignificant conflicts occurred with fifteen per cent of successful grant applications or favourable tax concession decisions during the combined periods.

(c) As can be seen when examining Attachments B and C, in most cases the nature of the conflict is a remote association between a member and an applicant. This reflects the fact that the Board is scrupulous in its handling of conflict of interest issues. Members are excluded from all discussion or decision making of matters in which they have declared an interest. Their position on the Board or Committee should, in no way, unfairly assist or prejudice an application.
The Board's procedures have been enhanced several times in recent years and I will ensure that this vigilance is maintained.
Accordingly, I consider that the current conflict of interest guidelines applying to the IRDB and its committees are appropriate and do not require strengthening.
[The attachments are too lengthy to be published in Hansard. Copies are available at the House of Representatives Table Office].

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Webster Mr A.P.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support, upon notice, on 12 March 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: What action has been taken to implement each of the nine recommendations at pages 89-91 of the ``Report of investigation into the search and rescue incident for the yacht Rockin Robin'' which was presented to the House on 18 October 1990.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support has supplied the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The Federal Sea Safety Centre, which co-ordinated the search for the Rockin Robin, is now part of the newly established Australian Maritime Safety Authority (AMSA). I am informed by AMSA that the following action has been undertaken to implement each of the nine recommendations arising out of the Report.
RECOMMENDATIONS RELATING TO FEDERAL SEA SAFETY CENTRE ALONE

(1) Arrangements should be established to ensure that a person occupying the position of Director (Sea Safety Centre) or the position of Controller (Sea Safety Centre) is available to maintain oversight of the conduct of a search from start to finish.

The Sea Safety Centre continues to be manned by experienced search and rescue (SAR) operational personnel on a 24-hour basis. In addition, roster arrangements have been established by AMSA, whereby one of the persons occupying the position of Director or Controller of the Sea Safety Centre is available to oversight the strategic direction of a continuing search from start to finish. Appropriate out-of-hours arrangements, including remuneration aspects, have been recently approved by the Department of Industrial Relations.
(2) Operational procedures for the Federal Sea Safety Centre should be reviewed to ensure that appropriate emphasis is given to:
* the need for active pursuit and analysis of information from all relevant sources (including crews on scene)
* the need for active consideration and periodic review of all possible measures for effecting rescue and for supporting persons in distress pending the completion of a rescue
* the need for liaison with the CAA to ensure that aircraft crews involved are briefed and debriefed with respect to any specifically maritime aspects of a particular incident
* the need to periodically check that all reasonable measures have been undertaken, or at least considered, by crews on the scene, and
* the specification of checks to be undertaken as preliminary to any consideration of a possible discontinuation of a search.

All procedures and associated documentation for the Sea Safety Centre have been reviewed and updated. Emphasis has been given to the recommended principles for the conduct of searches, including the need for active pursuit of relevant information from all sources and a thorough analysis of information obtained. All search and rescue staff of the Centre have been reminded of their obligation in this regard.

(3) Training arrangements for Federal Sea Safety Centre staff should be reviewed with the aim of ensuring that staff are encouraged to adopt a rigorous and broad ranging approach to incident analysis.

Training arrangements have been reviewed and updated and are designed to ensure that staff take a wide ranging approach to the analysis of problems. All staff have attended an initial training course, with more advanced courses programmed for the near future.

(4) Management of the Federal Sea Safety Centre should periodically assess staff capabilities and performance and consider appropriate re-training opportunities where this is likely to assist the maintenance of staff performance levels.

The management of AMSA and the Centre are aware of the need to assess staff capabilities periodically, particularly of persons in key SAR roles within the Centre. Retraining of staff to update knowledge and assist the maintenance of performance levels is being undertaken when necessary.

(5) Public education campaigns relating to small boat safety should continue to emphasise the importance of persons on a distressed craft remaining with the craft as long as possible and regarding any lifesaving equipment (e.g liferaft, dinghy) as nothing more than a last resort means of survival.

A comprehensive Safety Education Article entitled `Abandoning ship and rescue phase' was issued by AMSA in January 1991 and widely distributed to fishing vessel and pleasure craft organisations and owners. The article emphasises the importance of persons on a distressed craft remaining with the craft as long as possible and reiterates the techniques of survival in a survival craft. When appropriate, this theme will continue to be emphasised in future education programs and material.
RECOMMENDATIONS AFFECTING OTHER SEARCH AND RESCUE ORGANISATIONS
(6) Procedures governing information flow between SAR organisations should be reviewed with a view to ensuring in particular that
* the full contents of oral reports from the aircraft on scene are communicated to the Federal Sea Safety Centre
* the Federal Sea Safety Centre is a standard addressee on all formal debriefs submitted by crews of search aircraft
* debriefs are despatched as soon as possible after the completion of a search task and not later than the end of the same day.

The Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) and the Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF) have revised relevant internal documentation to reinforce procedures to ensure that the information flow to the Sea Safety Centre is efficient and that full information from crews on scene is despatched to the centre in a timely manner. Sea Safety staff now utilise phone-patch facilities to talk direct to crews on scene when appropriate.
(7) The standards for Air Sea Rescue Kits should be reviewed with a view to providing for the inclusion of appropriate homing devices in all kits used by SAR organisations.

Standards for Air Sea Rescue Kits have been examined and tests on the inclusion of homing devices have been carried out recently. Radio beacons are being progressively included in all kits used by the RAAF and CAA. These beacons operate on different frequencies to the normal Electronic Position Indicating Radio Beacon (EPIRB) but will enable positive identification and tracking by aircraft subsequent to the dropping of liferafts.
(8) The feasibility of establishing supplies of pumping equipment suitable for dropping to small craft in distress should be investigated.

Several pumps and associated equipment capable of being dropped to vessels taking water and in distress have been purchased and established at strategic locations around the country. The pumps are intended to be dropped to assist vessels taking water and in distress to remain afloat pending the arrival of a rescue craft. Training of aircrews in the specialised dropping techniques has been undertaken and is now part of CAA ongoing training.
(9) The feasibility of more regular liaison between SAR staff at the working level in the Federal Sea Safety Centre and the Civil Aviation Authority should be explored

* including the suggestion by CAA that, where possible, an appropriate liaison officer be provided from SeaSafety to a Rescue Coordination Centre (RCC) and from CAA to SeaSafety to assist in relevant matters during a major incident.

Opportunities for liaison between operational staff of the Sea Safety Centre and regional staff of the CAA are being taken whenever possible and will continue to receive priority. AMSA and the CAA have agreed that liaison officers will be made available to assist in incidents where considered necessary and when appropriate officers are available.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 14 March 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: Have additional places in Australia's immigration program been reserved for refugees and applicants on humanitarian grounds from the Middle East since the Gulf crisis; if so, how many.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hand The Hon G.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: 1,320 places were initially allocated early in 1990/91 to the Middle Eastern component of the Refugee and Humanitarian Program. Overall, the Program was set at 11,000 places, including a contingency reserve of 1,000 places.
In response to changing requirements for refugee and humanitarian places in late l990/early 1991, I adjusted the allocations for individual regional programs and activated the contingency reserve.

The Middle Eastern component of the Program now stands at 2,839 places. As a result, it is now the second highest component after Indochina. It provides for people from a range of countries and situations in the region, including needs which may emerge as a result of the crisis in the Gulf. Within the overall numbers, flexibility will be maintained to respond to changing needs and priorities arising from the unpredictable nature of political events which give rise to refugee movements.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Cobb Mr M.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 14 March 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: If all existing sales taxes were abolished and replaced with a flat, goods and services tax type of consumption tax with no exemptions, what rate would be necessary for the replacement to be revenue neutral.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: A simple calculation suggests a single rate of around 7 1/2 per cent applied to an adjusted private final consumption expenditure base would raise sufficient revenue to replace that presently collected by the existing wholesale sales tax.

The base used here excludes from private final consumption expenditure on health, education, financial services and dwelling rent, however, inputs into these exempted categories are included in the base. It is further assumed that no net revenue is collected from excisable products (petrol, tobacco and alcohol) following the introduction of a consumption tax, effectively excluding them from the base.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister Representing the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, upon notice, on 9 April 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the use of the ``Advance Australia'' and ``Australian Made'' logos designed to improve domestic and overseas consumption of Australian made goods.
(2) Is the fee imposed on Australian manufacturers for the use of the logos an imposition on the manufacturers' cost competitiveness.
(3) Will the Minister act to allow Australian manufacturers to use the logos at no cost.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Crean The Hon S.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question.

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The ``Advance Australia'' and ``Australian Made'' logos are an integral part of the ``Advance Australia'' and ``Buy Australian'' campaigns administered by the Advance Australia Foundation. The Foundation is a non-political non-profit organisation. The objectives of the campaigns are:
- To heighten community awareness of Australia and Australian skills, achievements and potential.
- To highlight the role of the individual in the economy.
- To encourage improvements in quality, design, marketing and other characteristics of Australian industry.

(2) About 2000 businesses are licensed to use the logo on their products. Obviously these firms believe that the benefits of using the logo exceed the cost of the licence. The licence fee is equal to 0.1% of the turnover of the products endorsed to bear the logos, with a minimum of $200 and a maximum of $10,000.

(3) No. Licence fees are a major source of revenue for the Advance Australia Foundation's support of the ``Buy Australian'' campaign. The Government recently announced that it will also provide two million dollars to support the campaign.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Honours and Awards: Members of Parliament

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Scholes The Hon G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 15 April 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: Are members of (a) both Houses of the Australian Parliament and (b) State and Territory Parliaments barred from being considered for the award of all Australian honours; if so, (a) what is the legal basis of the bar and (b) is the bar discriminatory.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: There is no legislative bar. However, I am advised by the Secretary of the Order of Australia that the Council for the Order of Australia determined at its first meeting in 1975 that, as a general rule, it would not recommend awards to incumbent Members of Parliament. This was done to avoid the Order being viewed by the public as an instrument of political patronage and to preserve the independence of the Council and the Order. There have, however, been exceptions to that general rule.
